title: Down the Fairy Tale Road: 200 Years of Brothers Grimm in English
description:
Celebrating the 200th anniversary of the first English translation of the folk and fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm. Featuring tales collected by German linguists and folklorists Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm. Beloved tales including Snow White, Little Red Riding Hood, Hansel & Gretel and many more.

Explore the enchantment of cautionary and classic tales, and remember the magic at the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books.


Free. All are welcome.

Located in the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books, on the 4th floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Osborne Collection's open hours: Monday - Friday 10-6, Saturday 9-5, closed Sunday.

Image of Cinderella from The Arthur Rackham Fairy Book, by Arthur Rackham.

title: Tower of Banned Books
description:
What's at stake when Big Brother exercises control over bookshelves? Canadian artist Kelly McCray's six-foot-tall sculpture considers the repercussions of literary control and censorship. The installation comprises 400 used books, many of which have been challenged, censored or banned over time.

**

This art installation is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened, and is part of TPL's commitment to promote and defend intellectual freedom.

title: Become Pen Pals with an Oklahoma Bison
description:
Would you like to become pen pals with a bison?
This lovely herd of bison in northeastern Oklahoma are getting a lot of fan mail, and they are even sending out postcards and letters back to their fans! These buffalo enjoy receiving mail and would like for you to send them a letter. Come in branch, we have all your writing needs! You can ask questions or just tell them about yourself. Who knows you might start a friendship!
Drop-in

All material will be provide. Letters will be posted on Nov 16!

title: Handmade Humanoids: A Merril Collection Exhibit
description:
Whether they're made of metal, mud or magic, fiction is full of fantastic human-shaped creatures that aren't quite human. There are golems and robots, puppets and clones, magical constructs and more. Come and explore their stories at this exhibit!

Free. All are welcome.

Located in the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy, on the 3rd floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Merril Collection's open hours: Monday-Friday 10am-6pm, Saturday 9am-5pm, closed on Sunday.

Are you an educator or group leader? We also offer group visits and exhibit talks! Contact the Merril Collection at 416-393-7748 or email lsmestaff@tpl.cafor more information.

title: Adult and Seniors Colouring
description:
Leave your stress and electronics behind and drop into the Victoria Village library to color: that is right, colour!

Colouring is known to be highly relaxing and meditative. The library will provide supplies.

Drop in! No registration is required.

Join us every Tuesday at Victoria Village from 1:00-3:30 p.m.!

Dates:
Oct 3
Oct 10
Oct 17
Oct 24
Oct 31

title: Branch Art Exhibits: Colours of Life by Mah Noor Khan
description:
Colours of Life reflects the realities of life. Mah Noor Khan explains "art has always been a medium for me to externalize my deepest emotions and perceptions regarding varying aspects of life/society. I believe my art is something many can relate to, whether as a person of colour, as a woman, or as a practicing Muslim in today's world. In fact, when an established artist saw my artwork for the first time a while back, she found it inspirational and said I give women a voice through my work."

Mah Noor Khan started her creative journey with acrylic painting as a youth and now focused on sketchbook coloured pencil drawings. Mah Noor is a Toronto woman with a background in RECE, humanities and committee member in establishing the Youth Hub at Malvern branch.

This exhibit is part of TPL'S Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during open hours. Please check the Agincourt branch page before your visit.
Free. All are welcome.

Image Credit: May Noor Khan. Hamaara Istaqbaal: Coloured Pencil on Paper: 23 x 30.5 cm

title: Residential School Survivors: Honouring the Memory
description:
Residential School Survivors: Honouring the Memory is an interactive exhibit created by Weengushk Film Institute and 360 Storylab. It uses augmented reality (AR) to educate Canadians about the history and legacy of residential schools. Visitors may use iOS and Android devices to access images from residential schools and hear stories from residential school survivors. The library does not have devices to distribute. Visitors are encouraged to bring headphones to use with their devices.

Content Warning: This exhibit features information about residential schools and the survivors' personal experiences. The National Indian Residential School Crisis Line (1-866-925-4419) is available 24/7 for survivors and their families who are experiencing pain as a result their experience in Residential Schools.

*Toronto Public Library does not operate or control any aspect of the websites that host the AR content in this exhibit. Toronto Public Library does not review, endorse or approve these sites and is not responsible for them in any way. When accessing these websites, you agree that Toronto Public Library is not liable for any resulting damages.*

TThis exhibit is facing outward from the program room and can be viewed Ethennonnhawahstihnen's open hours. Please check the Ethennonnhawahstihnen branch page before your visit.

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Henry Vanderspek: Go Wide
description:
Throughout October, artist Henry Vanderspek's work is on display at Don Mills branch. The exhibit is called: Go Wide: Wide Angle Views of Toronto.GO WIDE shares 15 wide angle and panoramic images by Toronto photographer Henry VanderSpek. Created with film and digital cameras, GO WIDE features distinctive scenes captured around Toronto between 2012 - 2023. Come and discover some unique visual moments and vistas of our great city. Henry VanderSpek is an art and documentary photographer who loves to celebrate the people, and the unique moments and visuals, of Toronto. Some of his past exhibits include Taxi Drivers of Toronto, Old World Shoes, On Notice and Redacted City. This is his fourth exhibit in a Toronto Public Library Branch.

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Don Mills branch's open hours. Please check the Don Mills branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: "Woodbine Beach" Artist: Henry Vanderspek

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Creativity in the Time of COVID by Ann Hollingworth
description:
Ann Hollingworth earned a BFA from the School of Visual Arts in New York and worked as an advertising art director and creative director in both Canada and the United States.

Artist statement:

"My art encompasses both historic textile design and my love of natural forms found in flora and fauna. I am reviving old North American textile design into canvas floor cloths that can be used as practical decor today. In my painting I am experimenting with mixed medias and various textures to bring flowers and trees and nature's forms to art."


This exhibit is part of TPL'S Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.


The exhibit can be viewed during open hours. Please check the Yorkville branch page before your visit.


Free. All are welcome.

title: Branch Art Exhibits: Philippe McNally
description:
"Philippe McNally is a self-taught and classically-trained mixed-media artist. He began working with digital art and 3D animation before going back to
school to study ne arts and illustration at George Brown College, where he began to focus on permanent and dynamic physical media including penand-ink, watercolour, distressed materials, and photographed textures. He was born on Manitoulin Island in 1982, and has lived in Toronto since 2001,
and maintains a large garden on his balcony."


"Drawing with pen-and-ink began as way of working through the anxiety of changing my environment. Because every mark is permanent, it must be
worked with, or worked around, but never removed. Each mark is 'digital' - on or off - but controlled with the analog motion of the hand, wrist, arm,
breath, and eye. Each mark is only as important as the mark or the empty space next to it, where every aspect is in contrast and opposition to its
neighbour. My work is an attempt to use opposition to render new life growing out of decay, and the ways that the natural and articial world are
intertwined."


This exhibit is part of TPL'S Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.


The exhibit can be viewed during open hours. Please check the Bloor / Gladstone branch page before your visit.



Free. All are welcome.

title: Google Docs for Beginners Part 2
description:
Learn how Google Docs can be a useful free tool when you don't have access to Microsoft Word. In this follow-up class to Part 1 use more formatting tools such as bullets, numbered lists, text alignment, margins, page numbers, and Help. Use will also learn how to copy and paste text and images from the internet and explore templates for resumes.

Registration is required. Please call York Woods at 416-395-5980 to register for this program.

Prerequisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min] 

Accessibility: Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

title: Computers for Beginners 4:  Use Google Search and Maps
description:
A class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fourth session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.
- Compare several search engines

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Computers for Beginners 1, 2 & 3 or basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Registration opens September 28th. Space is limited.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Malvern Library or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

title: A Trip to Fogo Island Newfoundland
description:
Fogo Island is the largest island off the north coast of Newfoundland. With a long maritime history, this island is a gentle world of bright-colored clapboard houses, sea-cliff footpaths, lush forest, and warm hospitality set against a striking coastline. In this program, experienced travel talk convener David Crichton will present his recent visit to the island with photos and illustrations of this Canadian cultural heritage. The highlights include Fogo Island Inn, Shorefest, and a story of a woman's strenuous endeavor to sustain the culture of the island.

This program is designed for adults. Drop in. No registration is required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. description:

Participants will learn about priming, base coating, drybrushing and clearcoating 3D Prints.

title: Panel Pandemonium: A Comics Workshop
description:
In this hands-on comics workshop, participants will experiment with different comic panel layouts and compositions, reflecting on how the use of panels affect storytelling in comics. This workshop is for those new to comics and experienced comic makers alike! Though the workshop will involve a lot of doodling, no previous drawing experience is required.

This program is presented by Jamie Michaels, TPL's Fall 2023 Writer in Residence whose focus is Graphic Novels. Learn more about TPL's Writer in Residence program, including upcoming programs and one-on-one consultation sessions.

Registration required, spaces are limited. To register call 416-393-7085 or email trllanglit@tpl.ca

**

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the Albert Campbell library.

title: Véronique Sylvain et la poésie contemporaine
description:
Originaire du nord de l'Ontario, Véronique Sylvain habite à Ottawa, où elle occupe le poste de responsable de la promotion et des communications aux Éditions David depuis près de dix ans. Son premier recueil de poésie, « Premier quart » (Prise de parole, 2019), lui a permis de remporter le Prix de poésie Trillium, le Prix du livre d'Ottawa, en 2020, le prix Champlain et le Prix littéraire émergence AAOF 2021. « En terrain miné », son prochain recueil de poésie, paraîtra à l'automne 2024.

Véronique nous parlera de l'entrée de la poésie dans sa vie, de sa démarche d'écriture et de son attirance naturelle à ce genre littéraire. Elle expliquera aussi comment elle arrive à concilier l'édition et l'écriture (la création littéraire). Enfin, elle abordera les thèmes qu'elle explore dans son écriture, dont la lutte, l'Ontario français, les rêves, la solitude, l'amour, la famille et le passage du temps.

En conversation avec Lamara Papitashvili qui oeuvre depuis dix ans dans l'industrie littéraire et culturelle. Lamara est romancière et anime des ateliers d'écriture à Toronto.

Crédit photo : Mireille Messier

Diffusion sur la plateforme Crowdcast. Pour y participer, il faut s'inscrire à l'avance.

****

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca
Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines à l'avance.

title: Grow Your Own Native Plants From Seeds - *Rescheduled*
description:
*Please note that this program was originally planned for October 28, 2-4 pm. The rescheduled session is on November 23, 6:30-8 pm. We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.*

Native plants have a long relationship with this land. Not only are they beautiful, they are also homes and food for other beings. Join Earthworker Joce Two Crows Tremblay and EnvIR Jenny Davis to learn everything you need to know to grow your own native plants from seed. You will learn what cold stratification means and why the fall is the best time to plant native plants. Come dressed to get dirty for this hands on workshop.

To register please visit Parliament Street Branch or call 416-393-7663.

This Environmentalist in Residence program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

Accessibility

description:
A class on essential basic Windows skills for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fifth session you will:

- Become familiar with the Windows (10) operating system
- Practice using common Windows features: File Explorer, Desktop, Taskbar, Windows, Applications

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to create and organize files in the Windows environment.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 & 2 or basic mouse and keyboarding skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Excel Basics 3: Tables, Pivots and Formula
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Excel 2019 skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this third session you will:

- Sort and filter the data in tables
- Learn the basics of Pivot Tables
- Create and format charts
- Practice IF, VLOOKUP and IFERROR functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using Pivot tables and formulas.

Pre-requisites: Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

title: *REGISTRATION FULL* Play Reading Circle
description:
Join us on the last Monday of every month as we gather to read a play aloud together.

October's play: The Crucible by Arthur Miller

Based on historical people and real events, Miller's drama is a searing portrait of a community engulfed by hysteria. In the rigid theocracy of Salem, rumors that women are practicing witchcraft galvanize the town's most basic fears and suspicions; and when a young girl accuses Elizabeth Proctor of being a witch, self-righteous church leaders and townspeople insist that Elizabeth be brought to trial. The ruthlessness of the prosecutors and the eagerness of neighbor to testify against neighbor brilliantly illuminates the destructive power of socially sanctioned violence.

Space is limited so registration is required.

For more information contact the Toronto Reference Library Arts Department at trlarts@tpl.ca or 416-393-7157.

title: Together Time with MFRC
description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. Sand, water play, painting, cut and paste, markers, crayons, circle time, and free play are all part of this program. Children are free to rotate between activities throughout the room. title: Computers for Beginners 6: Use Email
description:

In this class you will:
-Learn how to sign-in and sign-out of a Gmail account
-Learn how to read an email, write and send an email, reply to an email, forward an email, delete an email, and open or send attachments
-Review the basics of Gmail's security and privacy policy

description:

Kanopy is a streaming service for quality, thoughtful entertainment. Find movies, documentaries, foreign films, classic cinema, independent films and educational videos that inspire, enrich and entertain. Kanopy partners with public libraries and universities to bring you an ad-free experience that can be enjoyed on your TV, mobile phone, tablets and online. Kanopy Kids is included!

Free. Space is limited to 10. To register please call 416-393-7660 or register in person at the branch.

description:
An introductory class on Excel PivotTables for beginners with some Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use PivotTables and Conditional Formatting

In this third session you will:

- Use Conditional Formatting to visualize data
- Explore the power of PivotTables for data summary and analysis
- Practice your skills with take home exercises

Upon completion of this class students will have a foundation upon which to build their PivotTables skills.

Pre-Requisite: Excel 1 and 2, or equivalent knowledge. Mouse and keyboarding skills required.

No registration. Drop-in only.

Inspired by Persian Miniatures, she will weave a contemporary and personal approach into her paintings.

Doodling is a form of art that helps you keep calm, releases/reduce stress, helps with concentration, remembering things and enhances your creativity.

Artists will be chosen through a formal selection process before the start of the project. The youth participants who identify as First Nations, Inuit, and/or Metis from across Canada will lead the development of the project.

To submit an interest to participate, questions and more information email Tyana Chiblow at projects@counterstory.ca or click the related link below.

Participants will learn the basics of photography using a mirrorless camera (if you do not have one, a camera will be provided), including the lighting triangle, editing and more. The program is led by Sanjeev Kugan.

Food and TTC tickets will be provided. This program is in partnership with the Toronto Public Library and supported by the Toronto Arts Council.

title: Computers for Beginners: Use the Keyboard

A class providing keyboard knowledge and practice for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this second session you will:

- Familiarize yourself by practicing the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)
- Practice proper keyboarding posture

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and will know how to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 or basic mouse skills

title: Canadian Citizenship Education Mentoring Circle
description:
Join a 10-session mentoring program whose aim is to help newcomers learn more about Canada. All 10 sessions are facilitated by a CultureLink staff member and a team of trained citizenship education mentors. Mentors review and discuss the Discover Canada study guide in easy English in small group settings.

Please note: there is no session on October 9 (Thanksgiving, the library is closed).

To register call Hashem Rahin, Program Worker, CultureLink at 437-288-4915.

title: Mexican Monsters: Narco Vampires, Werewolves, Avenging Gods, and Spooky Castles
description:
Writer Alejandro Soifer (Ph.D. Latin American literature, University of Toronto) introduces contemporary Mexican and Latino horror fiction and film. Soifer will discuss Narco Vampires in Mexican-Canadian author Silvia Moreno-Garcia's novel Certain Dark Things, avenging Aztec Gods in American-Mexican author V. Castro's novel Queen of the Cicadas, and dark castles in Yuri Herrera's novel Kingdom Cons. Films in the Mexico Barbaro shorts anthology will also be discussed. Books will be available for purchase following the program.

Program hosted by the Language and Literature Department. For more info, email trllanglit@tpl.ca.

Drop in, no registration required.

title: Monday Night at the Movies
description: Join us every Monday night for a movie! We will be showing some old favorites and newer releases.  This is a drop in program.  For more information call the Port Union Library:  416-396-8885.

title: Eran Katz: Secrets of a Super Memory
description:
With a load of humor, excitement and motivational surprises, Eran Katz, renowned memory trainer and bestselling author, reveals extraordinary techniques to boost memory power, develop efficient (yet fun) studying habits and successfully improve your memory and achieve your study goals. Eran Katz is an award winning bestselling author, entertaining speaker, and seminar leader on memory and intelligence. He is a popular guest on TV and radio shows and has delivered his lectures and seminars to hundreds of leading multinational companies and organizations. His books have been translated to 17 languages and have sold more than 500,000 copies. Katz also holds the Israeli Guinness Book of World Records title in memory stunts.
This is a drop-in program.
Questions? Please contact TRL Humanities and Social Science department at trlhss@tpl.ca

title: Movie: Frankenstein
description:
Join us for a screening of Frankenstein (1931).

A mad scientist creates a monster from scavenged body parts, with horrifying consequences. This is the classic 1931 version of the film, starring the great Boris Karloff as the Monster. Wear a costume or answer a Frankenstein trivia question and win a (small) prize!

Directed by James Whale. Run time 70 minutes. Movie will be shown with English captions/subtitles.

This free screening will be held on the lower level of the Lillian H. Smith Branch in the Auditorium. Doors will open at 6:15pm and the movie will start at 6:30pm.

No registration is required. Everyone is welcome.

This event is a tie-in with Handmade Humanoids: A Merril Collection Exhibit, located upstairs on the third floor in the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Merril Collection's open hours: Monday-Friday 10am-6pm, Saturday 9am-5pm, closed on Sunday.

Are you an educator or group leader? We also offer group visits and exhibit talks! Contact the Merril Collection at 416-393-7748 or email lsmestaff@tpl.ca for more information.

title: Inclusive Futures: Futures of Women and Work
description:
Join us for two compelling presentations on the Futures of Women and Work, discussions on feminist futures, and learn from two women professionals working in the field of strategic foresight.

Presenters:
Stephanie Kwan, MDES: Feminist Visions of the Future of Womens Work: A systemic exploration of the past, present, and future of women at work in Canada.

Patricia Zawada, MDes: Play with Purpose: Exploring digital games to encourage gender equity in STEM.

Inclusive Futures Series:
Embark on an illuminating journey with the Toronto Public Library's Inclusive Futures series, as we venture beyond the boundaries of conventional narratives to delve into futures often overshadowed. Guided by a commitment to authenticity, our series goes beyond what's easy or comfortable, inviting you to envision bold, transformative paths. Join us in challenging norms, igniting conversations, and shaping a tapestry of inclusive, vibrant, and interconnected tomorrows.

title: Author Talk: Mark Creedon
description:
Author Mark Creedon presents a selected reading and discussion of his book 'Caught Between Two Devils' which looks at a possibly lesser-known story of World War II: the forced labour used along the Eastern Front. There were six million people compelled to work for the Third Reich. Despite great hardships, many of these people survived the war and a high percentage of those from Eastern Europe emigrated. They came to countries like the United States, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.​ Books available for purchase.
Drop in, no registration required.

description:

title: Developing an Illustration Style
description:
Children's book author and illustrator, Carey Sookocheff talks about the development and progression of an illustration style, and how your art practice can lead to developing a personal illustration style. She looks at some of her own work, as well as taking a look at contemporary illustration, and the wide variety of styles in picture book illustration.

Carey Sookocheff is TPL's 2023 Illustrator in Residence. The Joanne Fitzgerald Illustrator in Residence Program is a joint program of IBBY Canada, Toronto Public Library, the Canadian Urban Libraries Council, and the Young Family.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay until November 7, 2023.

Register and receive a reminder, or watch live via Crowdcast on October 30.

Read Crowdcast's Privacy Policy

Questions about Illustrator in Residence programs? Please contact the North York Central Library - Children's Department at 416-395-5630.

title: Tim O'Brien: America Fantastica
description:
Tim O'Brien - acclaimed author of The Things They Carried, a New York Times Book of the Century - joins us to discuss his first new novel in two decades, a brilliant and rollicking odyssey in which a bank robbery by a disgraced journalist sparks a cross-country chase through a nation corroded by shameless delusion and deceit.

America Fantastica charts the adventure of Boyd Halverson - star journalist turned notorious online disinformation troll turned JC Penny manager - and his irrepressible hostage, Angie Bing. Haunted by his past and weary of his present, Boyd has one goal before the authorities catch up with him: settle a score with the man who destroyed his life. By Monday Boyd and Angie reach Mexico; by winter, they are in a lakefront mansion in Minnesota. On their trail are hitmen, jealous lovers, ex-cons, an heiress, a billionaire shipping tycoon, a three-tour veteran of Iraq, and the ghosts of Boyd's past. Everyone, it seems, except the police.

Tim O'Brien speaks with journalist and author Michael LaPointe about America Fantastica, a book which puts a mirror to a nation, and a time, that has become dangerously unmoored from truth and greedy for delusion.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

This event is free and will take place on the main floor Atrium stage at Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge St). Registration is not required.

About this event's guests:
Tim O'Brien
Michael LaPointe

Read more:
America Fantastica
The Things They Carried
The Creep

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

description:

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to create and organize files in the Windows environment.

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 24 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
October 31 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 7 - Elder Abuse
November 14 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 21 - Physical Health and Exercise During
November 28 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Register in person or call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

title: Adult Afternoon Movie: Hitchcock/Truffaut (2015)
description:
Join us every first and last Tuesday of each month for a free afternoon movie.

Drop-in.

Based on the original recordings from the week-long meeting between Alfred Hitchcock and François Truffaut in 1962--the same ones used the basis of the book Hitchcock/Truffaut--this documentary film explores the skill and talent of Alfred Hitchcock on film and includes analysis and commentary from some of today's premier filmmakers.

In English with segments in French subtitled in English.

PG

80 minutes

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 1. Formes documentaires : le style
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions d'esthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Cet atelier questionne la forme à travers la narration : quels sont les modes narratifs visuels employés, comment sont-ils construits et quels sont les enjeux de ces usages ? À travers des exemples de films comme Le Joli Mai de Chris Marker, Les Glaneurs et la glaneuse de Agnès Varda ou Risk de Laura Poitras, le documentaire offre une multitude de possibilités.

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 10 octobre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Culture and Technology Book Club: Energy and Civilization
description:
The Culture and Technology Book club brings readers together once a month to discuss new and classic books that raise important questions about the way technology transforms our cultural and political lives. The group will read on relevant topics related to social-media, innovation, surveillance and infrastructure.

This month:

We read "Energy and Civilization: A History"

Canadian Scientist and interdisciplinary researcher Vaclav Smil traces out a packed history of energy use from pre-agricultural society up to our present power hungry global civilization. Smil unpacks the technological, political, economic and environmental dimension of humanitys energy use, using data to reveal our past and present industrial paradigms in depth. Regardless of how one feels about the scale of contemporary technological society, Smils work provides a powerfully grounding account of just how we got to our current state of affairs.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Introduction to 3D Printing
description:
This class/lecture is DROP-IN.

Learn how 3D printers work and how you can print at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs. This class includes instruction with PrusaSlicer, the software used to prepare your 3D object file for printing on an Prusa MK3S printer.
Note: Customers are no longer required to attend a mandatory 3D printing class prior to using a 3D printer at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs.
This class is for those who are interested in learning more about 3D printing and how to use the PrusaSlicer software and understanding how to get started with our 3D printing service.

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you have a request for accommodation. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. Phone 416-393-7009 or email accessibilityservices@tpl.ca.

title: 1-on-1 Career Consultations with ACCES Employment *PROGRAM FULL, JOIN WAITLIST*
description:
Are you feeling stuck in your job search? Look no further! Explore the incredible resources and expertise offered by ACCES Employment. Step into a world of endless possibilities as you connect with their dedicated team of Employment Consultants, ready to transform your career trajectory. Unleash your potential with tailored resume reviews, invaluable interview tips, and a wealth of additional support. Book a free 30-minute appointment with an Employment Consultant and embark on a remarkable journey toward your dream job.

Consultations are limited to 1 per person. Registrants will receive an email reminder a week before their appointment and are required to confirm their attendance. If attendance has not been confirmed by 5 PM two days before the appointment date, the spot will be released to the waitlist.

Consultations will take place in the Business, Science and Technology Department (4th Floor). Appointment slots are currently fully booked for the rest of 2023. To be added to the waitlist for one or more of the remaining consultation dates, please call the North York Central Library's Business, Science and Technology Department at 416-395-5613.

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 1

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 2

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Google Docs 1: Create and Edit a File
description:
Learn how Google Docs can be a useful free tool when you don't have access to Microsoft Word. In this introductory class you will learn how to open, create, save and delete Google Docs. Features such as highlight, bold, italics, underline, font colour and font size will be covered as well as how to use spell check, print, and download as Word document.

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at Albert Campbell Library.

description:
Poetry Saved Our Lives is an eight-week spoken word series for teens to explore their creative voices and make friends. Develop your writing, poetry and stories with a supportive and experienced coach.

Coach Desiree Mckenzie is an award-winning poet, National Poetry Slam Champion and photographer from Toronto. Desiree has led community poetry programming with JAYU, VIBE Arts and more.

The program is relocated to Evelyn Gregory branch from Oakwood Village branch.

This is an in-person program. For more information, call the branch at 416-394-1040.

title: Mesdames of Mayhem: Crime Writing Talk
description:
Join the Mesdames of Mayhem as we share the hills and valleys of our crime writing journeys to publication. Well talk about lucky breaks, how to create your own good luck when things arent going your way, and our best and worst experiences in the field. Plus, what it was like being filmed for a CBC Gem documentary, as well as writing tips and how to get ahead when the competition is fierce. In addition, we'll take a look at how much writers really earn, the role of social media, the benefits of writing groups, the role of AI and traditional versus independent publishing.

This is a drop-in program. For more information visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

If you live with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Visual Arts Workshop: Paint the Water and Sky
description:
Looking at the paintings of artists who painted the sky and water as inspiration, we'll create paintings of Lake Ontario and the city of Toronto. Participants will learn how to create the horizon line between water and sky while looking at images of the Toronto waterfront, and apply washes and details.

Hosted by the Artbarn School.

This is an in-person program.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Introduction to HR: Getting Help to Build Your Business
description:
Join Joëlle, our 2023 Entrepreneur in Residence, to learn about when, who, and how to hire for your business. In this session, participants will learn when to identify onboarding needs, what roles will create the most impact on their business and how to lead your team to success. Dont think you need to hire? This session will also cover how to get low to no cost talent to help grow your business as well as discuss the essential core team roles every business should have. (Previously called Talent Management: Building and Leading Your Team).

Part of the 2023 Entrepreneur in Residence series.

Joëlle Jacqueline is the founder of Couler Consulting, a business development solutions company.
Joëlle helps aspiring and early-stage entrepreneurs holistically navigate the entrepreneurial journey; both professionally and personally.

Register on Eventbrite

Registration is encouraged. Sign up here on Eventbrite, or contact the North York Central Library, Business, Science and Technology Department (4th floor) at 416-395-5613.


Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-395-5613 or email eir@tpl.ca.

title: Cercle de conversation en français
description:
Vous voulez améliorer votre français ? La meilleure façon est de pratiquer ! Joignez-vous à notre cercle de conversation en ligne pour échanger avec d'autres passionnés de la langue française et de la culture francophone. Une connaissance de base de la langue est recommandée.

Adulte de 18 et plus. Le nombre de participants est limité.

9 réunions, chaque semaine, les mercredis à 18h. Veuillez vous inscrire sur Eventbrite pour chaque date séparément.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca.

title: Drama Club for kids! (6-8 years old)
description:

title: Futures Club: Horizon Scanning - Futures of Work
description:
In each online horizon scanning gathering, we'll exchange signals of change related to The Futures of Work, delving into potential impacts and exciting new possibilities.

No previous foresight or futures experience necessary. While no one is an expert about the future, everyone has valuable expertise related to the future! Consider joining us for one or all of our horizons scanning gatherings.

Futures Club Series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

Pop, rock, jazz and blues influenced, each song is distinct from what follows or precedes it and often involves improvisation. The trio performs a musically engaging combination of Radeffs time

Spaces are limited, submit applications to trllanglit@tpl.ca for consideration. Applications will be considered as they are received. The final deadline to apply is October 20th. Applications should include:

-a brief description of the project (1 paragraph in length)

title: A Prisoner's Right to Information
description:
What's at stake when states, provinces or even prison officials ban books or limit prisoners' communication with the outside world? Is it morally right to prevent prisoners from accessing certain information and prevent them from pursuing their own education? What are the implications when society sees prisons not as places of punishment, but as places of rehabilitation?

In 2018, the Canadian Federation of Library Associations adopted "The Right to Read" statement, which affirms incarcerated Canadians do not relinquish their guaranteed rights and freedoms  under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, noting how these freedoms provide prisoners with a rare and critical connection to the outside world. Kirsten Wurmann, chair of the Manitoba Library Association's Prison Libraries Committee, joins Garrett Felber, an organizer with Study and Struggle and the Martin Sostre Institute, and Kyon Ferril, a former immigration detainee and founding member of Migrant Detainee Support Coalition, to discuss the impacts of censorship in Canadian and American prisons. Moderated by human rights lawyer Fathima Cader.

Who decides what information prisoners have access to? What's at stake when prisoners' relationships with the outside world are censored? How does our opinion and perception of prison and prisoners inform our society's values? 

Join the conversation.

About this event's guests:
Kirsten Wurmann
Garrett Felber
Kyon Ferril
Fathima Cader

Read more:
The Right to Read
Study and Struggle
Martin Sostre Institute
Those Who Know Don't Say: The Nation of Islam, the Black Freedom Movement, and the Carceral State

***
This event is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened.

***
This event will take place on the main floor Atrium stage at Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge St.). Registration is not required.

***

description:

This program is part of the online program series Caregiver 101: The Fundamentals of Dementia Caregiving, developed by Baycrest@Home.
Whether you are a spouse, partner, adult child, family member, friend, or neighbour and find yourself thrust into the role of caregiving for someone living with dementia or memory changes - knowing what to do and how to plan can feel overwhelming. Caregiver 101 was developed to help you care with confidence, and specifically designed to equip family caregivers with the tools, knowledge and skills to become a care partner.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay for one week.

title: Our Dance of Revolution Film Screening
description:
Join us for a special screening of the multiple award-winning film, Our Dance of Revolution (2019), which follows the powerful and dynamic history of Toronto's Black Queer Community. The film features legendary Black Queer DJ, Mykel Hall aka DJ Blackcat. DJ Blackcat will be present during the film screening and will be interviewed by Hollywood Jade after the film.

DJ Blackcat will be spinning a short set between 6:00 - 6:30 p.m. while attendees take their seats at Palmerston Library's theatre. The film will start at 6:30 p.m. and a Q&A will follow immediately after.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on October 10 at 9:00am. If you need assistance with booking a ticket on Eventbrite, please contact Palmerston Library staff at (416) 393-7680.

"Our Dance of Revolution tells the story of how Black queer folks in Toronto faced every adversity, from invisibility to police brutality, and rose up to become a vibrant, triple-snap-fierce community. Capturing first-person accounts across a span of four decades, this feature-length documentary is more than a previously untold oral history, more than a reclamation of unsung people and events.

Our Dance of Revolution is a human-scale reckoning of how audacious individuals find themselves by finding others, and how they muster the courage, tenacity, and creativity to prevail against the forces of marginalization." - ourdanceofrevolution.com

***

title: Learning to Screen Print in the North York Central Library Concourse
description:
Kicking off an evening of conversation about the art of the Sistine Chapel, join us for a special TPL Screen-Printing Mini-Workshop inspired by the art of the Sistine Chapel. Facilitated by a professional screen printer, participants will learn basic techniques of screen printing and will create their very own tote bags. This Pre-Show Activity is open to all backgrounds or levels of experience, and supplies will be provided.

This 45-minute Pre-Show is followed by Jeannie Marshall: Learning to Look in the Sistine Chapel. In it, Marshall takes us through her new memoir All Things Move, a deeply personal search for meaning in Michelangelo's frescoes and an impassioned defense of the role of art in a fractured age. The conversation is an exploration of the past in the present, the street in the museum, and the way a work of art can both terrify and alchemize the soul.

Ticket registration for this event is required: if you plan to attend both the Pre-Show at 6pm and the main event at 7pm, you must register for both events. Both tickets are available to book via Eventbrite beginning on October 19 at 9:00am ET. Registration is free for both events.

About the Facilitator: Krista Pettipas is the main teaching partner with Peach Berserk, a fabric and fashion design studio that hosts silkscreen workshops and art events. She holds energetic silkscreen workshops for children as well as brilliant company screen print experiences and everything in between. She has a strong background in art and design as well as being a Red Seal hair stylist. She also holds successful art-based fundraisers to support Ukraine.

*﻿**

About Salon Pre-Show Activities: Our Salon Pre-Shows are presented before select Salon Series events and are an opportunity for audiences to have fun and connect in significant ways. As with most of our Salon Series events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted). Linked in theme or topic to the main event immediately following, come prepared to engage, listen, take part and enjoy yourself.

*﻿**

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the event starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

*﻿**

description: Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. title: Jeannie Marshall: Learning to Look in the Sistine Chapel (North York Central)
description:
Writer Jeannie Marshall joins us to discuss her new book - a deeply personal search for meaning in Michelangelo's frescoes, and an impassioned defense of the role of art in a fractured age - at the North York Central Library Concourse, TPL's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming.

In All Things Move: Learning to Look in the Sistine Chapel, Marshall tells the story of her relationship with one of our most cherished artworks. Interwoven with the history of its making and the Rome of today, it's an exploration of the past in the present, the street in the museum, and the way a work of art can both terrify and alchemize the soul.

Jeannie Marshall speaks with journalist and deputy editor of Inuit Art Quarterly, Sue Carter, about All Things Move, a quietly sublime meditation on how our lives can be changed by art, if only we learn to look.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

If you're interested in attending this event, you may also be interested in the Pre-Show event at 6:00pm, Learning to Screen Print in the North York Central Library Concourse, where you can take part in a specially-designed TPL Screen-Printing Mini-Workshop inspired by the art of the Sistine Chapel. Separate registration is required for this event, and both events are free. Register for the Pre-Show event here.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on October 19 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Jeannie Marshall
Sue Carter

Read more:
All Things Move: Learning to Look in the Sistine Chapel

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

title: Financial Literacy and Career Success
description:

Financial worries are a stressor for many individuals. Staying financially literate can boost your work and personal well-being. It can help you to plan and allocate resources for the future including how to manage money better. Join us to learn about financial literacy, its importance and benefits, and its correlations with career success.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener, Ted Rogers Community Grants and Google Canada.

If you are 14 years or older, no age limit, join us for four small learning circles consisting of three participants led by a professional pianist. You will learn the basic piano including note recognition, finger placing, and simple songs. There will be opportunities for one-on-one instruction for each participant on a baby grand piano.

For absolute beginners only.

Registration will begin on Thursday, September 14, 2023 in person at the 3rd floor Information desk or by calling 416-395-5639. Space limited.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred.

title: How to Conduct Informational Interviews
description:
Join career coach Catherine Crawford to learn how to conduct an informational interview.

In today's competitive job market, networking and knowledge are your most powerful assets. Informational interviews offer a unique opportunity to gain invaluable insights, build connections, and explore potential career paths.

Discover the art of crafting compelling questions that uncover hidden career gems. Learn how to approach professionals, build meaningful relationships, and leverage these interactions to open doors to your dream job.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener, Ted Rogers Community Grants and Google Canada.

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 20 - Financial Freedom in Retirement (CANCELLED)
October 27 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
November 3 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 10 - Elder Abuse
November 17 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 24 - Physical Health and Exercise
December 1 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Registration is required for each session. Register in person or call Centennial Library at (416) 395-5490.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

October 6
Cubas Wild Revolution
Cuba is home to some of the most unusual creatures in the world. From the tiniest bird, the bee hummingbird to the smallest frog, jumping crocodiles and thousands of migrating crabs. The island has remained untouched until recently when the pressure to develop has increased. Will Cuba be able to save its wildlife? Closed Captions.55 minutes. 2020

October 13
Planet Food: Malaysia
Travel the country of Malaysia and discover just how multicultural it is by exploring their rich variety of foods. Whether you like spicy Laksa soup, mackerel curry or food cooked in a blowpipe, the adventure is delicious.
50 minutes. 2011

October 20
Worlds Greatest Engineering Icons: Civic Buildings
Throughout history, people have strived to make monumental buildings that communicate power, wealth and great architectural accomplishments. This film showcases many of these extraordinary achievements highlighting structures places such as Red Square, Petra, the United States Capital and the pyramids among others. Closed captions. 55 minutes. 2021

October 27
Cameroon
Explore Cameroon in western Africa. Join an adventurer as he struggles to climb Mount Cameroon, meet a pygmy tribe and take part in some of their celebrations, meet a chief with 50 wives and track lions in Waza National Park. Closed captions. 59 minutes.2020

November 3
The Green Planet: Tropical Worlds
Sir David Attenborough takes a plants-eye view of life in a rainforest, a world of stunning beauty but also fierce competition. From fast-growing trees to flowers that mimic dead animals, this is a journey into a magical world that operates on a different timescale to our own. Closed Captions. 50 minutes. 2022.

November 10
Secrets of the Sky Tombs
The Himalayas are among the most difficult places to live. Who were the people who chose to live at impossibly high altitudes surrounded by sheer cliffs. What strange rituals did they have that required gold masks and Chinese silk to ward off the spirits of the dead? 60 minutes. Closed Captions, 2017

November 17
Edible Insects
From crunchy crickets to nutty fly grubs, NOVA takes a tasty look at using insects as food and gives us insight into how they benefit us. Besides building larger and therefore smarter brains, insect protein actually makes us healthier and even helps to protect the environment by reducing meat consumption Closed Captions. 55 minutes .2021.

November 24
Worlds Greatest Natural Icons: Fire
Fire has created some of our most memorable and beautiful icons as well as destroyed some of our most valuable places. This film captures many of the worlds most magnificent volcanoes such as those in Hawaii and Japan as well as bubbling hot springs and mud baths in Iceland. However, it also shows us the dark side of fire especially land that has been laid to waste.2021

December 1
The Story of Cats: Asia to Africa
Discover how the first cats began in the forests of Asia and how they spread across the continent, eventually conquering Africa. How did they evolve from lions and tigers to house cats? What special adaptations do they need to survive in so many different environments? Closed Captions. 60 minutes. 2017

December 8
Can we make Life?
Science fiction movies show scientists bringing ancient creatures back to life. Is this a possibility? Can science really use DNA to resurrect extinct animals? Furthermore, can genetic biology improve our lives by eradicating disease? Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2018.

December 15
Canada: Surviving the North
Behold some of the world's most astonishing wildlife, and see how they live, from Canada's high arctic and tundra to the boreal forest. Each animal has innate abilities that allow it to hunt and survive in all seasons. These capabilities range from astounding hearing, to incredible speed and to patient silent stalking.
Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2022

title: CANCELLED Dr. Jean-Gabriel Castel, French Resistance Fighter
description:
We regret to inform your that this program is now cancelled. Please watch for updates for future programs from the Speakers Bureau.



In honour of Remembrance Day, please join us for a very special presentation by Dr. Jean-Gabriel Castel.

Born in Nice in 1928, Dr. Castel joined the French Resistance in 1943. Sharing rare photos and personal stories, Dr. Castel will discuss his role in several important World War II missions, including the liberation of Nice.

After the war, Dr. Castel received numerous military decorations. He became a respected jurist, academic, writer and international arbitrator; amongst his many accolades, he was made an Officer of the Order of Canada in 1985.

Please register in advance at the front desk or by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

January 12
Engineering Our World
This inspiring film follows engineers who have devoted their lives to seemingly impossible challenges and against all odds have made them happen. It is a story about human ingenuity and innovation. Closed Captions.45 minutes..2017.

January 19
The Megafalls of Iguaca
Follow the lives of animals that live in the Iguacu National Park, near the largest waterfalls on earth. This Atlantic rainforest houses swifts, who fly through the massive quantities of falling water, as well as spotted jaguars and a family of coatis. The film also shows the park rangers who battle to keep the reserve from destruction. Closed Captions.60 minutes. 2016.

January 26
Age of Stars
The sun is the source of our light, heat and energy. This film explores the birth of stars like our sun as well as their exit as exploding supernova .Billions of years from now our sun will die and will usher in the age of darkness. Closed Captions.55 minutes.2021.

February 2
Wild Metropolis: Residents
As cities grow larger, many residents have been pushed out of their homes in the wild and are adapting to their new urban habitat.in the city. From pythons in Bangkok to otters in Singapore, many animals learn adjust to these unlikely conditions. Closed Captions. 55 minutes.2019


February 9
Destination Northern Australia: Queensland
Enjoy a trip to Queensland in Northern Australia with the magnificent sunny beaches that draw surfers from all over, the oldest tropical forest in the world and the Great Barrier Reef.
60 minutes. 2002


February 16
Dynasties: Chimpanzees
David, the alpha male chimpanzee in his troupe in Senegal, tries to overcome threats to his leadership by younger males and by doing so ensure an heir. His determination to hang on to his position in the light of drought conditions and other difficulties is moving. Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2019


February 23
Secrets of Lost Empires 2: Roman Baths
Ancient Roman baths were used not only to stay clean but to socialize. However, the technology behind the baths was lost more than 2,000 years ago. What did the Romans do when there was no soap and how did they remain fashionable with hairless bodies? How did the Romans manage to pipe enough water for the community and control the temperature? Using ruins as a guide, scientists set out to recreate a Roman bath as the Romans did. 53 minutes.2008

March 1
Natures Great Race: Zebras
Follow Africas longest migration as scientists track thousands of zebras through the Botswana wilderness on their way to the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. It is a harrowing journey as the animals and their young face starvation, wild dogs , lions and drought. Closed Captions. 54 minutes.2017


March 8
Alien Solar Systems
Is our solar system unique? How was our solar system created? Since the first discovery of a planet orbiting another star, some 280 alien solar systems have been identified. It's only by looking at solar systems far beyond our own, that we can understand how remarkable our universe is.
Closed captions. 48 minutes. 2011


March 15
India: Natures Wonderland
Our guide starts in the Gir Forest, home to the worlds last Asiatic lions, tracks elephants as they travel an old path through a tea plantation, and observes gibbons that begin each morning by singing. This is an unusual view of Indias rarely seen natural world. Closed Captions. 60 minutes.2016


March 22
Royal Myths & Secrets 11: George IV and the Regency
Lucy Worsley reveals how mental health problems forced King George to relinquish power to his debauched and extravagant son. Was this really an era of extravagance and regal splendour or was it a darker time of concealed revolution? Closed captions. 53 minutes.2020

description:

He will touch upon the service and sacrifice of His Majesty's Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) today and every day, on standby and in conflicts hot and cold, from the Great War to the Present.
Having last served in 1980, Mr. Cotter went on to a 35+ year civilian career - becoming a senior publishing executive and later, in film and television, an Executive Producer, prior to retiring in 2019.

title: Python Data Science: Introduction to Regression Analysis
description:
In this tutorial you will learn how to perform simple and multiple linear regression analysis with Python on Google Colaboratory. Regression analysis is a common machine learning tool for testing relationships between numerical variables and predicting future values.

Some knowledge of Python or coding is encouraged. For participants that have no prior Python knowledge, TPL offers on-going user education tutorials on Python you can enroll in here. While Python knowledge is encouraged, the core functions will be explained from the ground up in the class. Participants also need a valid google account.

The workshop will take place at the Toronto Reference Library, Learning Centre 1, located on the first floor right by the stairwell at 789 Yonge Street, North York. Registration required, as space is limited.

The program is open to everyone. For further information please contact trlbus@torontopubliclibrary.ca.

title: Spadina Social Circle
description:
Are you are looking to get together with a group of like-minded friends? Come join our Friday Socials at Spadina! Every Friday, we will offer a series of activities that will focus on social interaction and fun.
Each week is a new opportunity to:
- Meet new people and make new connections
- Play cards, board games, bingo, knit (bring your own), colour, crafts, puzzles and so much more!
- Learn a new skill while having fun
- Benefit from social interaction

All supplies are provided. No need to bring anything other than a smile and a good attitude. All are welcome!
This program is drop-in. No registration required.

title: Computers for Beginners Series
description:
The Computers for Beginners Series are introductory classes on how to use the mouse, keyboard, web, Google Search and Maps, and Windows 10. They are geared towards absolute beginners with little to no computer experience. Each class will build on skills learned in previous classes to help you become more comfortable using the computer.

November 3: Computers for Beginners 1 - Use the Mouse
November 10: Computers for Beginners 2 - Use the Keyboard
November 17: Computers for Beginners 3 - Use the Web
November 24: Computers for Beginners 4 - Use Google Search and Maps
December 1: Computers for Beginners 5 - Use Windows 10

Registration is required and begins on October 20th. Register at the information desk on the second floor or call 416-394-5240.

If you live with a disability, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Misconceptions about the Universe: From Everyday Life to the Big Bang
description:
A misconception is a belief that is strongly held, but factually incorrect. In this profusely-illustrated, non-technical presentation, a gentle overview of astronomy will be provided by touching on a wide variety of common misconceptions, from everyday life (e.g. the cause of the seasons) to black holes, UFOs, and the Big Bang. The talk will emphasize the many causes of these misconceptions, since these same causes are responsible for much of the other societal misinformation.

John Percy is Professor Emeritus, Astronomy & Astrophysics and Science Education, at University of Toronto.

This is a drop-in program. For more information, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

title: Make A Will with the Ontario Bar Association
description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Lisa Laredo, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will what happens if you don't have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

No Registration required.

jnoufissa@centrefranco.org ou tbamanthia@centrefranco.org

description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Word 2019 for absolute beginners.

In this first session you will:

- Understand how to use Words Tabs, Groups, and Commands
- Create, save, print and delete Word documents
- Practice basic text formatting and style features

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Word at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

description:
Join us for an in-person workshop at Toronto Reference Library.

You will learn how to:
- create your MyAccesstoHousingTO client account
- manage your account
- apply for subsidized housing (or Rent-Geared-to-Income) listings.

Find out more or register at: https://reservation.frontdesksuite.ca/torontoprod/housing

Note: A valid email address, proof of status in Canada and most recent Notice of Assessment (NOA) are required to apply or register for subsidized housing or Rent Geared to Income (RGI) housing.

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

title: The Fires of Fate: A Morality Play that is Bad Medicine
description:
The Friends of the Arthur Conan Doyle Collection present the 2023 Cameron Hollyer Memorial Lecture, featuring guest speaker Dana Richards.

Dana Richards is a professor of Computer Science at George Mason University. His first Sherlockian publication was as a graduate student in 1979. He has published in the Baker Street Journal, Canadian Holmes, Sherlock Holmes Journal, Baker Street Miscellanea and numerous other places.

Professor Richards' lecture explores two separate threads regarding Conan Doyle's unpublished play based on his novel, "The Tragedy of Korosko" - the play at length, based on a rare copy of the script and Conan Doyle's holographic notes on the play.

The event will be simultaneously broadcast online via CrowdCast. Access is available via the following link: https://www.crowdcast.io/c/4n3q5sl1ucp3

description:

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds
