title: The Warrior Librarians of Ukraine
description:
What's at stake when a country's cultural heritage and structures are threatened with destruction?

Since the beginning of the war in Ukraine, hundreds of libraries have been damaged or completely destroyed by invading forces, equaling close to 40% of all damage to the country's cultural heritage infrastructure. In the face of these intentional attacks, the Ukrainian librarian community mobilized and transformed themselves into "warrior librarians," working tirelessly to preserve artifacts, national treasures, state archives and priceless manuscripts to protect Ukrainian national identity and Slavic history.

In this compelling discussion, Valentyna Pashkovam, Ukrainian Library Association (ULA) founder, Oksana Brui, ULA president and Yaroslava Soshynska, ULA executive director, discuss the staggering task of protecting Ukrainian libraries. Moderated by author and cultural commentator Stephen Marche.

What's at stake when libraries are one of the first targets of falling bombs? Why are these seemingly harmless spaces even targeted in the first place? And what can we do to ensure that all libraries prevail in the face of war and conflict?

Join the conversation.

About this event's guests:

Valentyna Pashkovam
Oksana Brui
Yaroslava Soshynka
Stephen Marche

***

This event is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library

We are committed to making our content accessible to as many Torontonians as possible. title: Monday Movies for Seniors
description:
Prosecuting Evil: the extraordinary world of Ben Ferencz

Summary: Barry Avrich's gripping documentary tells the fascinating story of one of the Holocaust's most heroic figures. Ben Ferencz, age 98, is the last surviving Nuremberg trial prosecutor and he is on a life-long crusade in the fight for law not war. After the Holocaust camps were liberated, Ferencz became a lead prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials. He prosecuted 22 Einsatzgruppen Nazis responsible for murdering over a million Jews. Called the biggest murder trial in history, Ferencz was only 27, and it was his first case. He would go on to advocate for restitution for Jewish victims of the holocaust and later the establishment of the International Criminal Court. His fight for justice for victims of atrocity crimes continues today.

Light refreshments provided.

Registration required.
Please register by calling Barbara Frum Library at (416)395-5440.


Accessibility
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

-Build on tools and experience from Computers for Beginners 3: Use the Internet
-Explore advanced search strategies
-Implement new skills by using the mouse, browser, scolling, zoom, help, tabs, and search filters
-Experiment with interactive and multimedia sites

description:
This is a class on how to use a mouse for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this first session you will:

- Review basic keyboard functions
- Use the mouse for basic Windows functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: No computer experience required.

title: Kimmapiiyipitssini: The Meaning of Empathy
description:
Elle-Máijá Tailfeathers' film witnesses radical and profound change in her community. Kímmapiiyipitssini: The Meaning of Empathy is an intimate portrait of survival, love and the collective work of healing in the Kainai First Nation in Southern Alberta, a Blackfoot community facing the impacts of substance use and a drug-poisoning epidemic.

Community members active in addiction and recovery, first responders and medical professionals implement harm reduction to save lives. This work is contextualized within the historical and contemporary impacts of settler colonialism; Kímmapiiyipitssini: The Meaning of Empathy draws a connecting line between the effects of colonial violence on Blackfoot land and people and the ongoing substance-use crisis.

Held in love and hope for the future, Kímmapiiyipitssini: The Meaning of Empathy asks the audience to be a part of this remarkable change with the community.

This program is a drop in film from the National Film Board.

title: Visual Arts Workshop: Illustrating Toronto Storefronts
description:
Toronto is one of the most multicultural cities where diverse cultures and communities live. In this workshop, we will explore our diverse restaurants, bakeries, and storefronts. We will learn about composition and cropping, how to apply watercolour wash and pen to create an illustration of your favourite Toronto shop.

Hosted by Soyeon Kim (김소연), a Korean-born Canadian artist living in Toronto, Ontario. Her main medium is three-dimensional dioramas, where she creates a world by carefully arranging the painted and texturized paper cutouts. She is also the illustrator of the picture books: "You Are Stardust", "Wild Ideas", "Is This Panama?", "Sukaq and the Raven", "You Are Never Alone", "A Last Goodbye", "Once Upon an Hour", and "When Sunlight Tiptoes".

This is an in-person program. Registration required in-branch or by phone at 416-396-8979. Spots are limited.

title: OpenToonz Animation III: Paper-to-Digital
description:
OpenToonz is a free and versatile open-source animation program. In this class we will explore the tools that OpenToonz has optimized for scanning and rendering pencil line art as part of an animation workflow. Registration is required. Registration begins October 23 at 12:30pm. Note: Your spot will not be guaranteed after 5 minutes of the start of the program.

While this workshop is for beginners, it is not easy. Animation is a complex skill, and animation software can be challenging to learn. If you interested in animating, and willing to take on engaging challenges, this workshop is for you. Although this workshop is second in a three-part series, it is designed to stand on its own.

Computers and drawing tablets will be provided for this class.

title: Panel Talk with Recently Elected Black City Councillors and TSDB Trustees
description:
Recent Toronto municipal elections have ushered in a historic number of successful Black candidates into political office. While meaningful gains have been achieved, significant issues of Black political underrepresentation still exist.

TPL and Operation Black Vote Canada (OBVC) are excited to host a panel talk featuring recently elected Black city councilors and TDSB trustees! Bring your questions and get ready to discuss the importance of Black political participation in Toronto and the challenges and experience of running as a Black candidate.

Eventbrite registration encouraged. Drop-ins welcome.
Event Brite link: https://tinyurl.com/3da9zvca

This event is free and will take place in Beeton Hall, located on the first floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge St).

Events Guests:

Amber Morley (Toronto City Councilor)
Chirs Moise (Toronto City Councilor)
Jamaal Myers (Toronto City Councilor)
Alexis Dawson (TDSB Trustee)
Debbie King (TDSB Trustee)
and more...

title: Social Media 101 for Small Businesses & Entrepreneurs
description:
Social Media 101 is a concise and beginner-friendly workshop designed to equip business owners with a solid foundation and practical strategies for leveraging social media effectively.

Participants will learn how to identify and reach their target audience, develop a strong brand presence, and create engaging content. The workshop also focuses on leveraging social media to generate leads, nurture customer relationships, and ultimately drive sales conversions. By the end of the workshop, business owners will be equipped with practical knowledge and actionable techniques to make a positive impact on their social media presence and drive business results.

The Social Media 101 workshop is the perfect opportunity for business owners to gain valuable knowledge and skills in a short time frame, enabling them to kickstart their social media efforts and make a meaningful impact on their business growth.

Hafsa Taher is a Certified ICF Business Coach with over 10 years of business experience while running two small sized businesses in Canada. Hafsa has coached and mentored over 200 aspiring entrepreneurs all over the world. She is currently running a mentorship mastermind for women in business, evaluating business ideas and plans for success.

Drop in, no registration required.

title: Wellness Exchange: Discussing Mental Health
description:
Join us for a community conversation about mental health led by Rebecca Higgins, a mental health educator with over 20 years of experience working in the field. This program will provide a space for participants to develop social connections and engage with their fellow community members by sharing their own perspectives, experiences, and stories in a safe and welcoming environment. This 90-program will consist of an informational presentation, followed by breakout groups based around facilitated conversations about mental health, its impacts, and how we can best support each other. A brief mental health resource guide will also be made available for participants.
Rebecca Higgins has been working in community and social services for 20 years, specializing in mental health education since 2010. In addition to designing and facilitating workshops, she has served as a panelist and presenter at conferences, delivered keynote speeches on mental health, and provided consultation support to community mental health initiatives. *** To register, please call the Jane/Dundas branch at 416-394-1014.
*** Accessibility at Toronto Public Library. We are committed to making our content accessible to as many Torontonians as possible. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. description:
Public speaking is important for youths! It helps build confidence and helps their voices be heard in the playground, home, classroom and beyond. This workshop will include activities that introduce key aspects of public speaking such as eye contact, volume, body language, preparation, and the importance of a smile!

description:
Beginning Tuesday, September 19th, join us weekly for a drop-in knitting and crochet circle! Bring your yarn, needles and crochet hooks and enjoy the company of other knitters and crocheters.

Drop-in. No registration required.

This program will be held downstairs at the Childrens Department.

title: Word Basics 1: Write a Letter
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Word 2019 for absolute beginners.

In this first session you will:

- Understand how to use Words Tabs, Groups, and Commands
- Create, save, print and delete Word documents
- Practice basic text formatting and style features

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Word at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Malvern Library or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred.

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 24 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
October 31 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 7 - Elder Abuse
November 14 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 21 - Physical Health and Exercise During
November 28 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Register in person or call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

title: Together Time with MFRC
description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. Sand, water play, painting, cut and paste, markers, crayons, circle time, and free play are all part of this program. Children are free to rotate between activities throughout the room. Co-sponsored with Malvern Family Resource Centre (MFRC). DROP-IN PROGRAM.

title: Rent Geared to Income Subsidy - Navigating MyAccesstoHousingTO (MATHTO)
description:
Join us for an in-person workshop at Toronto Reference Library.

You will learn how to:
- create your MyAccesstoHousingTO client account
- manage your account
- apply for subsidized housing (or Rent-Geared-to-Income) listings.

Find out more or register at: https://reservation.frontdesksuite.ca/torontoprod/housing

Note: A valid email address, proof of status in Canada and most recent Notice of Assessment (NOA) are required to apply or register for subsidized housing or Rent Geared to Income (RGI) housing.

title: Get F.R.E.S.H. at the Library - Crafting a Community
description:
Take a moment out of your hectic week and unwind at the library with relaxing activities, and good conversation. Meet new folks, build connections, and tell us about programs and services you would like to see in the neighbourhood!

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's F.R.E.S.H. initiative.

Each Tuesday participants are welcome to put their crafting skills to use! All materials will be provided.

description:

November 7-The Push
December 5- The Four Winds

If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099 or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. title: Adult Afternoon Movie: The Quiet Girl (2022)
description:
Join us every first and last Tuesday of each month for a free afternoon movie.

Drop-in.

In 1981, a quiet neglected girl named Cait (Catherine Clinch) is sent to live with a childless couple in rural Ireland for the summer. She blossoms in their care, but in this house where there are meant to be no secrets, she discovers one. The film is a sensitive and moving exploration of family, loss, and the power of love.

PG 13

94 minutes

title: Cash Chat - Make Sense of Managing Your Money
description:
These days, with so many options available, how can a person make sense of managing their money? Where can people find sound advice so they can reach their financial goals, especially if they are on their own? Regardless of your age, life stage, or financial situation, it's important to be informed and learn how to make the best decision for yourself regardless of what the media and your friends may be promoting.

title: Employment Standards in Ontario
description:
Did you know that Ontario's Employment Standards Act protect employees by setting out minimum wages, hours of work, overtime pay, etc.? Make sure your rights are not violated by attending this important presentation. This talk is especially appropriate for young people starting out their careers, or those returning to work after a break.

This session will be presented by Samuel Michaels, a lawyer with a background in employment law and corporate law. He has worked in diverse environments ranging from legal aid clinics to law firms.

Registration encouraged. Drop-ins welcome.

Register on Eventbrite

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 2. Formes documentaires : les images et les sons
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions desthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et dexpérience du spectateur. Cet atelier questionne le documentaire à travers les images et les sons : les choix effectués par les cinéastes donnent aux films leur singularité. Les matériaux disponibles sont nombreux et relèvent des choix de réalisation, du tournage à la post-production, nous explorerons leurs emplois.

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 17 octobre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Runnymede Tuesday Book Club
description:
Join us for a staff moderated discussion of Amita Parikh's, The Circus Train.

Set during the Second World War, Amita Parikh's debut novel steals the show with a cast of characters from a travelling circus troupe across Europe. It explores a star-crossed romance and centers around a young girl's coming-of-change journey during a dark period in human history.

Pick up a print copy at the Runnymede Branch Reference Desk, while quantities last. Other formats are available: Large Print
eBook
eAudiobook.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: How Yorkville Inspired a Mystery Novel
description:
Join author Dianne Scott as she vividly describes the scenes in her mystery LOST AND FOUND, set in 1960s Yorkville. Discover Yorkville's past, from its indigenous roots to its bricks and beer industries and evolution into a counterculture mecca. See the streets and music clubs where fictional officer Christine Lane goes undercover to navigate a world of gangs, bikers, and drug dealers.

In this presentation, Dianne Scott will share how how this eclectic neighbourhood inspired her writing, from characters to plot choices and themes. Even though Yorkville has changed, there remains traces of a time when young people gathered to listen to music, smoke drugs and debate politics. Dianne's presentation will connect the fictional world of LOST AND FOUND with the real-life history of Yorkville.

The author will sell and sign copies of her three-book mystery series, Final Look, Missing and Lost and Found, after 7:30 p.m.

Drop in. No registration.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: ***FULL*** Python 1 Learning Circle
description:
***This program is now full and registration has closed***

This learning circle will meet on every Wednesday afternoon from 2 - 3:30 p.m. from November 8 to December 20. In-person at Deer Park Library.

Participants will learn together in a peer-supported environment through a learning circle, a lightly facilitated study group guided by staff for people who want to take a free online course together in a welcoming space. Participants are expected to commit to the duration of the course and attend all learning circle sessions. 10 hours of independent course work per week will be required to complete the course on time.

Why should you learn Python?
Python is a versatile programming language used by startups and enterprises such as Google, Facebook, Dropbox and IBM. This is also the language of choices for developers who work in data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence, networking and IoTs (Internet of Things). This course will help participants learn basic coding in Python, as well as general computer programming techniques and concepts.

Python Essentials curriculum aligns with Python Institute's PCEP (Certified Entry-Level Python Programmer) certification. You will get a digital badge to add to your LinkedIn profile after you complete the course successfully. This learning circle will cover Part 1 of the Python Essentials course.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: **CLASS FULL** Computers for Beginners 3: Use the Internet
description:

- Practice using web addresses
- Search for information using a search engine
- Explore a web site in detail to understand its key components

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use the internet at a beginner level and complete simple searches.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 & 2 or basic mouse and keyboarding skills

In this first session you will:

- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files

- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average

- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets


Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.


Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

title: November Movie Night, showing "1917"
description:
During the month of November, we observe Remembrance Day. Join us on Wednesday, November 8th for a special showing of Sam Mendes' 2019 movie "1917"(loosely based on true events).


1917

Directed by Sam Mendes
Starring: Dean-Charles Chapman, Colin Firth
1 hour 59 minutes
Rating: 14A

At the height of the First World War, two young British soldiers, Lance Corporal Schofield (George MacKay) and Lance Corporal Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman), are stuck with 1,600 other British soldiers in the trenches of the Hindenburg Line on April 6, 1917. Their superior, General Erinmore (Colin Firth), assigns them a challenging and dangerous task to personally deliver a letter to Colonel Mackenzie (Benedict Cumberbatch), commander of the 2nd battalion.

In a race against time, they must cross enemy territory and deliver a message that could potentially stop a deadly attack on hundreds of soldiers, one of them being Blakes own brother.

Drop-In

title: Futures Club: Horizon Scanning - Futures of Work
description:
In each online horizon scanning gathering, we'll exchange signals of change related to The Futures of Work, delving into potential impacts and exciting new possibilities.

No previous foresight or futures experience necessary. While no one is an expert about the future, everyone has valuable expertise related to the future! Consider joining us for one or all of our horizons scanning gatherings.

Futures Club Series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

title: Ken Dryden: The Class (North York Central Library)
description:
Bestselling author Ken Dryden discusses his riveting new book - a memoir of a place, a time, and so much more - at the North York Central Library Concourse, TPL's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming.

In The Class, we are introduced to the "Selected Class," a group of thirty-five students at Etobicoke Collegiate Institute who, having written special exams, assembled for the first time on September 6, 1960 and would stay together through high school, with few exceptions.

Their ancestors were almost all from working-class backgrounds. Their parents had lived their formative years through depression and war. They themselves were born into a postwar world of new homes, new schools, new churches. New suburbs. Of new classes like this one. Of boundless possibilities.

Ken Dryden was one of these thirty-five. In his varied, improbable life, he had wondered often how he had gotten from there to here. How any of us do. He decided to try and find his classmates, to see how they are, what they are doing, how life has been for them. They talked many long hours, in a way they had never talked before.

Ken Dryden speaks with journalist and author Carol Off about The Class, a book which asks us to consider, when almost anything seems within reach, what do we reach for?

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on October 25 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Ken Dryden
Carol Off

Read more:
The Class
The Series: What I Remember, What It Felt Like, What It Feels Like Now

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7pm, but doors open at 6pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all North York Central Library Concourse events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:
Welcome to Northern District's book club. This is an in-person program. We meet on the second Wednesday of each month for a lively discussion on a group-selected book.

On November 8, we will be discussing the book Son of Elsewhere: A Memoir in Pieces by Elamin Abdelmahmoud, the culture critic and CBC personality about his arrival in Canada with his family at age 12 from Sudan and his education about Canada and Western culture and how they intersected with expectations and assumptions around race, faith, and language.

Print copies are available at Northern District's reference desk. Copies of the title are also available in the formats below:

eBook
eAudiobook
DaisyTalkingBook

Our next meeting dates are the following:

December 13, 2023 - Miss Benson's Beetle
January 10, 2024 - My Name is Lucy Barton
February 14, 2024 - The Strangers

Questions? Please email ndstaff@tpl.ca or call Northern District branch at 416-393-7610.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Raising Confident Kids: Learning the Skills of Effective Communication
description:
Join Kylah Harrington from the Parent Education Network for this program all about effective communication. Learn how to become a better listener by discovering the feelings behind your child's words. You'll learn to determine when it's appropriate to listen and when it's important to communicate your feelings. You'll also learn the art of questioning to help your child explore alternatives in dealing with the challenges they face in their lives.

This program is part of the Raising Confident Kids: Workshops for Parents Series.

Questions about online programs? Please email us at programproposals@tpl.ca.

title: Dementia Caregiving: Caregiver Stress and Self Care
description:
Family caregivers are often at risk for burnout and compassion fatigue. Join a team of Baycrest@Home social workers to learn how to identify risks for stress, develop coping strategies and advocacy skills.

This program is part of the online program series Caregiver 101: The Fundamentals of Dementia Caregiving, developed by Baycrest@Home.
Whether you are a spouse, partner, adult child, family member, friend, or neighbour and find yourself thrust into the role of caregiving for someone living with dementia or memory changes - knowing what to do and how to plan can feel overwhelming. Caregiver 101 was developed to help you care with confidence, and specifically designed to equip family caregivers with the tools, knowledge and skills to become a care partner.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay for one week.

Register and receive a reminder, or tune in live on November 9

title: Dive into Documentaries - Human Flow
description:
Twice a month, we present an engaging and thought-provoking documentary. We will explore the social, political and historical aspects of issues important to the state of our world today. Engage with complex social conditions, complicated events, and their consequences, while watching revealing documentaries from around the world at the Toronto Reference Library (with closed captions.)

In this beautifully crafted film, celebrated artist Ai Weiwei delves into the phenomenon of mass migrations of people around the globe. He follows their journeys of suffering and indifference.
Drop-in, no registration.

title: Computers for Beginners - Practice session
description:

title: Spend an hour in Italy with author Maria Coletta McLean
description:
Privacy is a Foreign Word in Supino (September 2023, Inanna Publications) features the story of three women who secretly want to be more than housewives and mothers, set against the backdrop of the traditional Italian village of Supino. The presentation will include an introduction and a reading followed by Q & A with the author.

Maria Coletta McLean is the author of the best-selling memoir, My Father Came From Italy (due to be produced as a feature film) and the sequel Summers in Supino: Becoming Italian. In 2002, she was awarded the Queen's Golden Jubilee Medal for her contribution to the Canadian literary landscape.

title: Word Basics II
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively. In this class you will:
 Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
 Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
 Format text as columns
 Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
 Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus
Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.
Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Visual Arts Workshop: Portraits of Toronto's City Animals
description:
Toronto is a place where we live with our animal neighbours. In this workshop, we will explore our city animals and create a pen and ink portrait. Together we will examine the characteristics of the animals and learn the pen and ink techniques, such as hatching, contour, and stippling to create realistic portraits of animals.
Hosted by Soyeon Kim (김소연), a Korean-born Canadian artist living in Toronto, Ontario. Her main medium is three-dimensional dioramas, where she creates a world by carefully arranging the painted and texturized paper cutouts. She is also the illustrator of the picture books: "You Are Stardust", "Wild Ideas", "Is This Panama?", "Sukaq and the Raven", "You Are Never Alone", "A Last Goodbye", "Once Upon an Hour", and "When Sunlight Tiptoes".

This is an in-person program. Registration required in-branch or by phone at 416-394-1014. Spots are limited.

title: Faire un testament
description:
Novembre est le mois du testament !

Saviez-vous que 65 % des Canadiens n'ont pas de testament à jour ? De plus, saviez-vous qu'un testament ainsi que des procurations pour les biens et les soins personnels correctement rédigés sont essentiels et contribuent à éviter des dépenses, des retards et des conflits à l'avenir ?

Chaque année, l'Association du Barreau de l'Ontario et la Bibliothèque publique de Toronto collaborent afin de mettre en relation les professionnels du droit avec la communauté pour des discussions informatives et pertinentes sur ce sujet.

Rejoignez-nous le 9 novembre 2023 pour découvrir l'importance d'avoir un testament et des procurations pour vous et votre famille. Nous aborderons les éléments d'un testament, les conséquences de l'absence de testament, l'utilité des procurations, ainsi que les considérations spéciales à prendre en compte lors de votre planification successorale.

Cette présentation sera animée par Angela Ogang, avocate bilingue spécialisée en droit des fiducies et des successions, membre du Barreau de l'Ontario et du Conseil de l'Association du Barreau de l'Ontario pour la région de Toronto.

Inscrivez-vous dès aujourd'hui pour réserver votre place !

This program is a part of the Make a Will series presented in collaboration with Ontario Bar Association.

****

Pour toutes questions concernant ce programme, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca


****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'engage à l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes malentendant(e) ou avez un handicap quelconque et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez-nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. title: Romance Book Club
description:
Join us online for a lively discussion of Relentless in Texas, by Kari Lynn Dell. Copies are available in various formats, including regular print in branches, as well as eBook copies through OverDrive.

About this month's book:

Once rodeo's biggest hotshot, Gil Sanchez is now thirteen years sober and free from the pain that ended his skyrocketing career. He's been given a chance to return to rodeo glory, and has no time for distractions, even if the distraction is Carmelita White Fox!

Carma may come from a Blackfeet family noted for its healing abilities, but she knows better than to try to fix this scarred, cynical, and incredibly sexy cowboy. Yet she's the only one who can reach past Gil's jaded armor, and the fiercely loyal heart buried underneath is impossible to resist. As the pressure builds and the spotlight intensifies, they'll both have to fight like hell to save the one thing neither can live without.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book club/book discussion. Registration is limited and specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to the registrants one day before the book club meeting.

For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

description:
A Death Café is a gathering of people, often strangers, who will drink tea, have a snack and discuss death together. The aim is to increase the awareness of death with a view to helping people make the most of their lives. Discussions will be in small groups with no agenda, no objectives, and no particular theme. Prepare to hear and tell stories. This is not a grief support or counselling session. The facilitator for this Linda Hochstetler.

Death Cafes are a global movement. To learn more, visit the Death Café website.

Drop in Program. There is no registration.

title: Toronto in Literature Book Club
description:
Join us each month as we meet in person to discuss literature set in Toronto. See our city in a new light through stories about its past and present in works of fiction and history.

November's book is The Mother of all Degrassi : A Memoir by Linda Schuyler.

When a young schoolteacher decides to teach her Grade 8 class about filmmaking and creates a documentary that ends up being broadcast internationally, she sets in motion a career of storytelling for an age group largely ignored by TV executives...and creates one of the most-loved television franchises of all time.

Linda's deep fondness for teenagers has made her a champion for adolescents. In The Mother of All Degrassi, she shares her strong belief that television is all about the story, and a good story is all about making the political personal. Through anecdotes and introspection - and some great behind-the-scenes stories for Degrassi fans - Linda examines her philosophy to dream big, think small, meet life head-on, and always keep an open heart. [Source]

Thursday, December 14 - Much Ado About Nada by Uzma Jalaluddin

title: Jewish Anti-Racist Comics: Resistance and Constraint
description:
In this lecture Jamie Michaels will discuss how comics can challenge racism in ways that are not possible in other forms, such as novels or films. Prominent Jewish comic creators such as Will Eisner, Art Spiegelman and Horst Rosenthal's works will be examined in terms of their use of stereotypes and caricature within the constrictions of the comic form. This lecture unpacks how Jewish comics draw attention to, employ, resist and wrestle with the conventional use of stereotype and how we can better understand what insights their practice might hold for both creators of anti-racist comics and comic studies as a discipline.

This program is presented by Jamie Michaels, TPL's Fall 2023 Writer in Residence whose focus is Graphic Novels. Learn more about TPL's Writer in Residence program, including upcoming programs and one-on-one consultation sessions.

Drop in, no registration required.

title: Maria Popova: The Path to War Between Russia and Ukraine
description:
TPL and Toronto Metropolitan University presents Associate Professor with the McGill University Department of Political Science, Maria Popova in conversation with Sanjay Ruparelia and Arne Kislenko, at Toronto Reference Library's Appel Salon space.

The war between Russia and Ukraine has ignited fierce debate on its causes as well as how it might end around the world. Realists claim that it was the result of great power rivalry between Russia and the United States. The expansion of NATO membership to former members of the Warsaw Pact, according to this view, instilled a sense of insecurity that provoked President Vladimir Putin and his regime. Yet this view has been undermined by Putin's calm acceptance of NATO's most recent expansion to Finland and Sweden, right up to Russia's borders. The view also discounts how the states that emerged from the collapse of the USSR diverged in their aspirations and institutions since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Russia slid back into authoritarianism and imperialism, while Ukraine consolidated a competitive political system and fledgling democracy, determined to pursue European integration as a sovereign nation-state.

How did the expansion of autocracy and democracy shape each country over the last two decades? Why has Ukraine resisted Russia better than many had anticipated? What are the prospects for peace, recovery and democracy in each polity in the years ahead?

The distinguished political scientist Maria Popova examines these debates in conversation with Sanjay Ruparelia and Arne Kislenko.

Question and answer session to follow.

***

Read More:

About Maria Popova
About Sanjay Ruparelia
About Arne Kislenko

***

About the series:

On the Frontlines of Democracy is a public lecture series to analyze the trajectory of democracy in the twenty-first century. In every region, the prospects of democracy face serious challenges, old and new. Can we protect constitutional rights and renew collective self-rule in an era of popular mistrust, severe partisanship and resurgent nationalism? Can they reduce inequalities of power, wealth and status, defend deep diversity and confront climate change in the new digital age? Can we develop innovative strategies to revitalize civic engagement, empower public institutions and resist autocratic threats? And what can we offer, learn and do to promote the prospects of democracy in our increasingly post-western global order?

***

This event is part of our signature On Civil Society series, where we host local and international authors, activists and academics in conversation about the most critical topics of our time. Generously supported in part by Chris M. Reid.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 20 - Financial Freedom in Retirement (CANCELLED)
October 27 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
November 3 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 10 - Elder Abuse
November 17 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 24 - Physical Health and Exercise
December 1 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Registration is required for each session. Register in person or call Centennial Library at (416) 395-5490.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

October 6
Cubas Wild Revolution
Cuba is home to some of the most unusual creatures in the world. From the tiniest bird, the bee hummingbird to the smallest frog, jumping crocodiles and thousands of migrating crabs. The island has remained untouched until recently when the pressure to develop has increased. Will Cuba be able to save its wildlife? Closed Captions.55 minutes. 2020

October 13
Planet Food: Malaysia
Travel the country of Malaysia and discover just how multicultural it is by exploring their rich variety of foods. Whether you like spicy Laksa soup, mackerel curry or food cooked in a blowpipe, the adventure is delicious.
50 minutes. 2011

October 20
Worlds Greatest Engineering Icons: Civic Buildings
Throughout history, people have strived to make monumental buildings that communicate power, wealth and great architectural accomplishments. This film showcases many of these extraordinary achievements highlighting structures places such as Red Square, Petra, the United States Capital and the pyramids among others. Closed captions. 55 minutes. 2021

October 27
Cameroon
Explore Cameroon in western Africa. Join an adventurer as he struggles to climb Mount Cameroon, meet a pygmy tribe and take part in some of their celebrations, meet a chief with 50 wives and track lions in Waza National Park. Closed captions. 59 minutes.2020

November 3
The Green Planet: Tropical Worlds
Sir David Attenborough takes a plants-eye view of life in a rainforest, a world of stunning beauty but also fierce competition. From fast-growing trees to flowers that mimic dead animals, this is a journey into a magical world that operates on a different timescale to our own. Closed Captions. 50 minutes. 2022.

November 10
Secrets of the Sky Tombs
The Himalayas are among the most difficult places to live. Who were the people who chose to live at impossibly high altitudes surrounded by sheer cliffs. What strange rituals did they have that required gold masks and Chinese silk to ward off the spirits of the dead? 60 minutes. Closed Captions, 2017

November 17
Edible Insects
From crunchy crickets to nutty fly grubs, NOVA takes a tasty look at using insects as food and gives us insight into how they benefit us. Besides building larger and therefore smarter brains, insect protein actually makes us healthier and even helps to protect the environment by reducing meat consumption Closed Captions. 55 minutes .2021.

November 24
Worlds Greatest Natural Icons: Fire
Fire has created some of our most memorable and beautiful icons as well as destroyed some of our most valuable places. This film captures many of the worlds most magnificent volcanoes such as those in Hawaii and Japan as well as bubbling hot springs and mud baths in Iceland. However, it also shows us the dark side of fire especially land that has been laid to waste.2021

December 1
The Story of Cats: Asia to Africa
Discover how the first cats began in the forests of Asia and how they spread across the continent, eventually conquering Africa. How did they evolve from lions and tigers to house cats? What special adaptations do they need to survive in so many different environments? Closed Captions. 60 minutes. 2017

December 8
Can we make Life?
Science fiction movies show scientists bringing ancient creatures back to life. Is this a possibility? Can science really use DNA to resurrect extinct animals? Furthermore, can genetic biology improve our lives by eradicating disease? Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2018.

December 15
Canada: Surviving the North
Behold some of the world's most astonishing wildlife, and see how they live, from Canada's high arctic and tundra to the boreal forest. Each animal has innate abilities that allow it to hunt and survive in all seasons. These capabilities range from astounding hearing, to incredible speed and to patient silent stalking.
Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2022

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

January 12
Engineering Our World
This inspiring film follows engineers who have devoted their lives to seemingly impossible challenges and against all odds have made them happen. It is a story about human ingenuity and innovation. Closed Captions.45 minutes..2017.

January 19
The Megafalls of Iguaca
Follow the lives of animals that live in the Iguacu National Park, near the largest waterfalls on earth. This Atlantic rainforest houses swifts, who fly through the massive quantities of falling water, as well as spotted jaguars and a family of coatis. The film also shows the park rangers who battle to keep the reserve from destruction. Closed Captions.60 minutes. 2016.

January 26
Age of Stars
The sun is the source of our light, heat and energy. This film explores the birth of stars like our sun as well as their exit as exploding supernova .Billions of years from now our sun will die and will usher in the age of darkness. Closed Captions.55 minutes.2021.

February 2
Wild Metropolis: Residents
As cities grow larger, many residents have been pushed out of their homes in the wild and are adapting to their new urban habitat.in the city. From pythons in Bangkok to otters in Singapore, many animals learn adjust to these unlikely conditions. Closed Captions. 55 minutes.2019


February 9
Destination Northern Australia: Queensland
Enjoy a trip to Queensland in Northern Australia with the magnificent sunny beaches that draw surfers from all over, the oldest tropical forest in the world and the Great Barrier Reef.
60 minutes. 2002


February 16
Dynasties: Chimpanzees
David, the alpha male chimpanzee in his troupe in Senegal, tries to overcome threats to his leadership by younger males and by doing so ensure an heir. His determination to hang on to his position in the light of drought conditions and other difficulties is moving. Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2019


February 23
Secrets of Lost Empires 2: Roman Baths
Ancient Roman baths were used not only to stay clean but to socialize. However, the technology behind the baths was lost more than 2,000 years ago. What did the Romans do when there was no soap and how did they remain fashionable with hairless bodies? How did the Romans manage to pipe enough water for the community and control the temperature? Using ruins as a guide, scientists set out to recreate a Roman bath as the Romans did. 53 minutes.2008

March 1
Natures Great Race: Zebras
Follow Africas longest migration as scientists track thousands of zebras through the Botswana wilderness on their way to the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. It is a harrowing journey as the animals and their young face starvation, wild dogs , lions and drought. Closed Captions. 54 minutes.2017


March 8
Alien Solar Systems
Is our solar system unique? How was our solar system created? Since the first discovery of a planet orbiting another star, some 280 alien solar systems have been identified. It's only by looking at solar systems far beyond our own, that we can understand how remarkable our universe is.
Closed captions. 48 minutes. 2011


March 15
India: Natures Wonderland
Our guide starts in the Gir Forest, home to the worlds last Asiatic lions, tracks elephants as they travel an old path through a tea plantation, and observes gibbons that begin each morning by singing. This is an unusual view of Indias rarely seen natural world. Closed Captions. 60 minutes.2016


March 22
Royal Myths & Secrets 11: George IV and the Regency
Lucy Worsley reveals how mental health problems forced King George to relinquish power to his debauched and extravagant son. Was this really an era of extravagance and regal splendour or was it a darker time of concealed revolution? Closed captions. 53 minutes.2020

title: **CLASS FULL** Excel Basics 1: Create a Simple Spreadsheet
description:
**CLASS IS FULL** An introductory class on Microsoft Excel 2019 for absolute beginners with little or no Excel experience.

In this first session you will:

- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files
- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average
- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.

Registration required. Registration for November classes begins Monday, October 23, 2023 at 9 a.m.

Please register in-person at the first floor reference desk or by calling 416-395-5672.

title: PowerPoint Basics 3
description:
Create a more sophisticated PowerPoint 2019 presentation with more advanced features.

In this session you will learn to:

- Crop pictures, add picture borders and add picture effects.
- Align and distribute objects.
- Insert and edit SmartArt graphics.
- Animate objects.
- Edit a theme.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 and 2 or equivalent experience. Keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min] 

Registration required. Please register at the branch or by calling 416-396-8890.

title: Being Prime Minister: Behind the Scenes with Canada's leaders
description:
Author J.D.M Stewart presents his book, Being Primer Minister, taking us behind the scenes to see what our prime ministers were like as people like us. The Talk provides humorous anecdotes and other insights into Canada's leaders - everyone from Sir John A. MacDonald to Justin Trudeau - examining them through the prisms of travels, family, pets, sports, privacy, celebrity and dealing with the demands of the job.

This is a free event with seating capacity limits. First-come, first served. Registration is not required.

title: Computers for Beginners: Using Gmail
description:
This class if for those that wish to set up and/or learn how to use Gmail. Participants should have basic mouse and keyboarding skills. In this class you will:

- Learn how to Sign-in and Sign-out of a Gmail account
- Learn how to use basic email functions (opening an email, sending an email, sending attachments, etc.)
- Review the basics of Gmail's security and privacy policy
- Review additional resources to help you learn more

Feel free to bring in your own laptop. Limited laptops available.
Space is limited. To register, call the branch at 416-396-3599.

title: Building Portfolio Website Using WordPress
description:
Are you looking to showcase your work and attract clients or employers? Join us for the "Building Portfolio Website Using WordPress" workshop, featuring a no-code approach! Gain skills in customizing themes, creating content, optimizing for search engines, and more. Register now to unlock your potential and enhance your professional portfolio.

Tanveer is a Certified Web Analyst with a background in Digital Marketing & Analytics. He has worked in diverse sectors such as Non-Profit, Consumer Packaged Goods, and Media Agency. His proficiency spans across Media and Communication, allowing to deliver strategic insights and data-driven solutions across industries.

Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Register in person in the branch or by calling 416-394-1000.

description:

title: Sphero Funday
description:
Control a gyroscopic robot in a Robo-Battle! This is a fun after school event for kids. No coding experience required, just bring your team spirit!

Drop-In Program.

Eventbrite sends some participants requests for additional information after events take place. TPL does not receive any of the feedback provided to Eventbrite. You can change your email preferences at any time in your Eventbrite Account settings if you do not wish to receive these surveys.

title: 3D Animation with Blender
description:
Participants will learn how to create a simple animation through the use of Keyframes, F-Curves, and Dope Sheets, while gaining a basic understanding of the principles of animation. Participants are welcome to bring a USB stick or SD card should they want to save their projects.

Although not required, it is strongly recommended that participants take "3D Design with Blender" prior to this workshop.

Computers will be provided for this class

**Registration will be online through Eventbrite and will open 2 weeks prior to the date of the class. To register, please follow the link below.

Guitar, piano & djembe provided. 7 minutes for each performance. For adults, teens, and seniors.

Sign-up is at 5:30pm. For more information, contact the Language, Literature & Fine Arts Department at 416-395-5639.

title: This is NOT a Book Club!
description:
Come out and join us once a month to gain knowledge and share resources on a particular topic in a fun and friendly atmosphere. Unlike a traditional book club, here you will have the freedom and flexibility to read, listen to, or even watch the contents of your choice and discuss them with fellow club members.

Whether it is books, magazine issues, essays, newspaper articles, audiobooks, podcasts, films, or documentaries, read, watch, or listen to content on a topic of your interest in your leisure time, then come share it. You are welcome to attend even if you have nothing to share.

*For our upcoming November meeting, we will take a look at an interesting article on the topic of mental health and perhaps some
other materials (i.e., poems, short clips) to go with it.*

No registration is required. New members are welcome.

title: Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus


Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]


Accessibility: Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

A presentation of the Society and Recreation Department of the North York Central Library.

Optional registration here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/indigenous-storytelling-and-history-tickets-747481987747?aff=oddtdtcreator

title: Computers for Beginners 1:  Use a Mouse
description:
A class on how to use a mouse for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this first session you will:

- Observe and practice how to operate a mouse effectively
- Understand various mouse pointers and cursors
- Review basic keyboard functions
- Use the mouse for basic Windows functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: No computer experience required.

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Malvern Library or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. description:

Join us Saturday, November 11, for an information session on upcycling in sewing and fashion. We will discuss how to transform old or unused clothing into trendy and eco-friendly fashion pieces.
At the end of the session, there will be a Q&A .
Also bring your sewing questions and/or project to have your questions answered.
No registration required. *Eventbrite cap free accounts to 25 tickets. If you can't get a ticket, you can still attend.

title: *REGISTRATION FULL* 'For The Love Of Writing' Beginner Workshop
description:
Have you wanted to start writing but feel nervous about where or how to start? Do you have an idea or story that needs to be let out? Join author, playwright and screenwriter, Laurel Brady, for her "For the Love of Writing" beginner workshop.

Whether youre a professional writer wanting to fall back in love with your process or you want to start writing for the joy of it, we all have stories we want to tell, and Im here to help you tell them. Come and work your writing muscle through a series of writing prompts and exercises.

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

Albion branch
1515 Albion Road
Toronto ON M9V 1B2
416-394-5170

title: Desired Futures Toolkit: Three Horizons
description:
The Three Horizons framework is simple and elegant tool that helps diverse stakeholders get to the heart of how the group experiences the current state, and what they desire in the future. It also works through how to transition from current state to the desired future state, while maintaining what is good and useful in the present. 

Desired Futures Toolkit Series:
In each of the two Desired Futures Toolkit session, a strategic foresight tool that can be used to work through a desired future with a group of stakeholders will be presented. Participants will get hands-on experience by working through the tool together in a workshop-style session.

For 1 on 1 Consultations with IIR Alexis Tennent, book through: calendly.com/clsr/iir-1on1-consultation

title: Remembrance Day Program: Sergeant Billy
description:
Children's author Mireille Messier presents her picture book, Sergeant Billy: The True Story of the Goat Who Went to War. Commemorate Remembrance Day as she reads and talks about a little known part of Canada's WWI history --along with sharing some interesting facts about goats!-- and leads participants in a simple craft making purple poppies to honour our military service animals.

Drop-in. No registration required. Space permitting.
Lower Level, Children's Department.


If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the Albert Campbell library.

title: Lest We Forget
description:
Use primary source documents to uncover the lives and service records of real soldiers from WWI in this interactive workshop that brings names to life. Learn tools and tricks that will help you in finding out more about service members in your family's history, whenever they served.

REGISTRATION REQUIRED. Please contact the branch in person or at 416-393-7744 to register.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: How to Establish Prices for a Craft or Maker Business
description:
Setting a price for your crafts and handmade items can be a tricky process. Learn about the different factors that you should take into consideration when determining the right price for your work.

Led by Heather Young, professor with Humber Colleges Arts Administration programs. She has taught accounting and financial management to diploma and continuing education students and published a self-study guide, Finance for the Arts in Canada.

Drop-in. No registration necessary. This is a program aimed at younger adults and individuals looking to begin a small craft or maker business.

description:
Join us to learn and play chess each week. Boards and pieces will be provided. Laptops will also be available for those who want to play on chess.com or chesskid.com. Players of all strengths are welcome. No previous experience is required.

For ages 6+. Drop-in, no registration required.

title: STEM Saturdays
description:
Each week, come in for a fun tech surprise as we explore Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math through coding, circuitry, robotics and more!

Will we play a song with Dash? Will we teach Sphero robots to complete a maze? Will we make a fan spin with Snap Circuits? Will we build a bridge?

Join us to find out!

For ages 4-12. Space is limited.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Transform Your Photos into Stunning 3D Printable Lithophanes
description:
Preserve your precious memories in stunning three-dimensional artwork. Witness the magic unfold, as your photos are modified using Photoshop and online software converted into textured 3D designs. These designs can be viewed in front of a light source, creating a beautiful display. Perfect for gifts, home décor, special occasions, and more!

*Must bring a .jpeg file on a USB drive or SD card. Cannot be printed on the same day!*

To register, please visit or call the branch at 416-396-3599

title: Adobe Premiere Rush
description:
Do it all with the video editing app for creating and sharing online.

Adobe Premiere Rush is the free mobile and desktop video editing app for creativity on the go. Wherever you are, from your phone to your computer, you can shoot, edit, and share high-quality videos. Fun, intuitive, and as fast as social media, its the easiest way to star in your followers feeds.

The Premiere Rush video editing app has the creative flexibility to make your content stand out from the crowd. With simple desktop and mobile tools for audio, motion graphics, and more, its easier than ever to create videos that connect with your audience from wherever you work.


Registration begins November 4, 2023 at 9:00 a.m.

title: Introduction to 3D Printing
description:
Learn the basics of 3D printing , including how to 3D print at the Toronto Public Library!

In this lecture, staff members will show participants how to get access and use the 3D printer at the Digital Innovation Hub. Topics includes:
* Basics of 3D Printing
* How to prepare a 3D design file for print
* How to access and use 3D printer at the Digital Innovation Hub at Toronto Public Library
* Best practice for 3D printing and where to find designs.
* Review of the rules and guidelines to using the 3D printer at the Toronto Public Library


This is an in-person event.
*Registration Required.

description:
A class on basic keyboard functions for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this second session you will:

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)
- Practice proper keyboarding posture

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and know how to go online for additional practice.

title: The Outer and the Heart Wood - Crafting with Cedar and Birch
description:
In this workshop, participants will learn about the differences between the outer wood of threes and the heart wood, and how to work with both. They will create strong cords with cedar wood, and roses with birch bark, while reflecting on what the layers of wood can teach us. In creating cords and roses, we will discuss the outer wood as representing our values, and the heart wood as being the story of our family.

Please call 416-394-5350 or visit the New Toronto Branch to register.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

- Insert a screenshot or video
- Add Speaker notes and Print presentations

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 or equivalent experience. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Introduction to Adobe Premiere Pro
description:
Adobe Premiere is the industry-leading video editing software. With this powerful tool, you can edit virtually any type of media create professional productions for film, TV and the web. Premiere is a time-line based video editing application and can also integrate with the rest of the Adobe suite such as After Effects, Photoshop and more.

In this introductory Premiere class you will learn basic video editing techniques such as adding clips, transitions and titles. Add audio to your project, along with cutting and splicing on your project's timeline.

Located in the 2nd floor eLearning Lab. *No prior knowledge is required. Recommended age is 13+. Free Adobe ID account also recommended.

Please note your spot is guaranteed only for the first five minutes of the class.

Registration is required for this class. Free e-tickets will be available on October 30th at 12:30 pm.

description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. description:

- Become familiar with the Windows (10) operating system

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

title: Computers for Beginners 1: Use the Mouse
description:
A class on how to use a mouse for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience. This is class 1 of 5 in a series for computer novices interested in learning the basics.

In this first session you will:

- Observe and practice how to operate a mouse effectively
- Understand various mouse pointers and cursors
- Review basic keyboard functions
- Use the mouse for basic Windows functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

Nov 20th: Computers for Beginners 2 - Use the Keyboard
Nov 27th: Computers for Beginners 3 - Use the Web
Dec 4th: Computers for Beginners 4 - Use Google Search & Maps
Dec 11th: Computer for Beginners 5: Use Gmail

description:

Whether it's exploring the wonderful world of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) with robots and circuitry or using your creativity to make digital art, there is always something exciting to do. title: Stories of Turtle Island with Counter Story Conversations
description:
Counterstory Conversations will facilitate "Stories of Turtle Island Project", a residency at Richview Branch for four artists and four to five youth participants to develop and publish a children's book to tell the stories of First Nations, Inuit, and Metis leaders whose impact has transcended generations. Artists will be chosen through a formal selection process before the start of the project. The youth participants who identify as First Nations, Inuit, and/or Metis from across Canada will lead the development of the project.

To submit an interest to participate, questions and more information email Tyana Chiblow at projects@counterstory.ca or click the related link below.

title: CapCut: Free all-in-one video editor
description:
CapCut is a free all-in-one video editor that turns your videos into pro-quality content. Looking to create videos for social media sites such as TikTok, YouTube and Instagram, CapCut offers various templates and tools to make it easy.

CapCut can be used to edit videos and images on multiple platforms such as browsers, Windows, Mac, Android, and iOS.

In this lesson we'll explore the editing interface and the various templates that you can use to create your videos. In addition the tools you can add from effects, text, captions, and transitions.

Registration

Registration is required. Registration begins one week prior to the class starting at 9:00 a.m.

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you have a request for accommodation. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. Phone 416-393-7009 or email accessibilityservices@tpl.ca.
