description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Zara Wong, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you dont have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

This is an in-person program. Drop-in, no registration required. Please call 416-393-6240 if you have any questions about the program.

title: Computer for Beginners 3 - Use the Internet
description:
This is an introductory class on the Internet for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this third session you will:

- Understand how to read a web site address
- Practice using web addresses
- Search for information using a search engine
- Explore a web site in detail to understand its key components

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use the internet at a beginner level and complete simple searches.

Prerequisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills.

Register in person or by calling 416 396 8890.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. description:

Please inquire at the branch or phone us at 416-396-3820. October: Brooklyn by Toibin. November: H is for Hawk by Macdonald. December: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes by Arthur Conan Doyle.

title: Canadian Citizenship Education Mentoring Circle
description:
Join a 10-session mentoring program whose aim is to help newcomers learn more about Canada. All 10 sessions are facilitated by a CultureLink staff member and a team of trained citizenship education mentors. Mentors review and discuss the Discover Canada study guide in easy English in small group settings.

Please note: there is no session on October 9 (Thanksgiving, the library is closed).

To register call Hashem Rahin, Program Worker, CultureLink at 437-288-4915.

title: Monday Night at the Movies
description: Join us every Monday night for a movie! We will be showing some old favorites and newer releases.  This is a drop in program.  For more information call the Port Union Library:  416-396-8885.

title: Jane-Finch: what you need to know about low-income communities
description:
Wanda MacNevin--author of "By Us! For Us! Activism in the Jane-Finch, A Working-Class Community"--former resident and community worker for 41 years in the Jane-Finch community, will share stories about the Jane-Finch community, where housing was rapidly built without the resources to support an immigrant, racialized, and working-class population from around the world.

Books will be available for purchase from the author.

title: Introduction to Serger Sewing
description:
Learn to use a Juki MO-735! In this class we will go over the basic operation and key functions of a serger sewing machine. Threading the machine and safety will be discussed. This course is mandatory in order to book the serger. Children under 13 must be accompanied by an adult.

Registration is required for this class and begins October 30, 2023 at 12:30pm.

Note: Your spot will not be guaranteed after 5 minutes of the start of the program. Class is held in the Fabrication Studio.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred.

Eventbrite sends some participants requests for additional information after events take place. TPL does not receive any of the feedback provided to Eventbrite. You can change your email preferences at any time in your Eventbrite Account settings if you do not wish to receive these surveys.

title: Vincenzo Natali: TECH
description:
Join us for a book talk and interview with filmmaker and graphic novel creator Vincenzo Natali. Mark Askwith will interview him about his new book, TECH.

In TECH, Shel is a courier, peddling alien tech secrets on the black market to pay for her daughter's medical treatments. It's dangerous work - but unbeknownst to Shel, it contains the key to the life she truly desires.

A Q&A and book signing will follow the interview.

Vincenzo Natali is a Toronto-based writer-director known for science fiction and horror films such as CUBE, SPLICE and IN THE TALL GRASS as well as TV series HANNIBAL and the Amazon Prime adaptation of William Gibson's THE PERIPHERAL and GUILLERMO DEL TORO'S CABINET OF CURIOSITIES.

Mark Askwith is a writer, interviewer, and TV producer. He created the award-winning Prisoners of Gravity, and was one of the Founding Producers of SPACE. Mark has written comics for DC, Image, and SpiderBaby Grafix.

This free event will be held on the lower level of the Lillian H. Smith Branch in the Auditorium. Hosted by the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy. Contact the Merril Collection at 416-393-7748 or email lsmestaff@tpl.ca for more information.

Doors will open at 6:15pm and the event will start at 6:30pm. No registration is required. Everyone is welcome.

Books will be available for sale by The Beguiling at the event.

Place a hold on TECH by Vincenzo Natali.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: The History of Canadian Women Pilots and Other Airborne Superstars
description:
Discover how Canadian women broke through the sky blue ceiling as Dr. Elizabeth Muir discusses her book, Canadian Women in the Sky: 100 Years of Flight.

It took 100 years from the time the first woman flew in a plane until the first woman entered the International Space Station. Learn about the female pioneer balloonists, parachutists, glider, blimp and helicopter pilots who struggled to become aviators along the way.

Registration
No registration required, but encouraged. You can register for the event on EventBrite

description:

Amanda Smyth, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you dont have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

title: Naomi Alderman: The Future
description:
Naomi Alderman - bestselling novelist and author of The Power, upon which the hit Amazon Prime series is based - discusses her new dystopian thriller, a tour de force in which a handful of friends plot a daring heist to save the world from the tech giants whose greed threatens life as we know it.

In The Future, a few billionaires are leading the world to destruction while safeguarding their own survival with secret, lavish bunkers. This is a world of private weather, technological prophecy, and highly deniable weapons.

The daughter of a cult leader, a non-binary hacker, an ousted Silicon Valley visionary, the concerned wife of a dangerous CEO, and an Internet-famous survivalist hatch a daring plan that could be the greatest heist ever. Or the cataclysmic end of civilization.

Naomi Alderman speaks with Vass Bednar about The Future, a dazzling exploration of the world we have made and where we are going.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on October 30 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Naomi Alderman
Vass Bednar

Read more:
The Future
The Power

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7pm, but doors open at 6pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.


***

title: Domenico Losurdo: A Counter-Historian
description:
The English translators of Stalin: History and Critique of a Black Legend, Henry Hakamäki and Salvatore Engel-Di Mauro join co-authors to the introduction of the upcoming English translation of Western Marxism (Monthly Review Press, Spring 2024), Gabriel Rockhill and Jennifer Ponce de León and editor and contributor to Red Sails, Roderic Day, to talk about their relationships to and real-life applications of the collected works of Italian historian Domenico Losurdo.

Who was Domenico Losurdo? What was his impact on the fields of Philosophy, History, and Politics? And what is driving a renewed interest in his life and work? A professor at the University of Urbino and member of the Italian Communist Party, Domenico Losurdo was a people's intellectual whose methodology included placing ideas and events in their concrete reality. Losurdo viewed dominant ideologies as manipulations of history and obstacles in the path to emancipation. A critic of Liberalism, he devoted himself to revealing these manipulations and producing work on twentieth-century history, Stalin, and class struggle.

Join a panel of Losurdo scholars, translators, and readers as they celebrate the life and legacy of Domenico Losurdo, a beloved "counter-historian."

About this event's guests:
Henry Hakamäki
Salvatore Engel-Di Mauro
Gabriel Rockhill
Jennifer Ponce de León
Roderic Day

Read more:
Stalin: History and Critique of a Black Legend
Class Struggle: A Political and Philosophical History
War and Revolution: Rethinking the Twentieth Century
Liberalism: A Counter-History

***
This event is part of our signature On Civil Society series, where we host local and international authors, activists and academics in conversation about the most critical topics of our time. Generously supported in part by Chris M. Reid.

title: Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus


Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

October 24 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
October 31 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 7 - Elder Abuse
November 14 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 21 - Physical Health and Exercise During
November 28 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Register in person or call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

title: Tea and Books
description: Part One... The Crime/Detective genre. When was the first Modern Crime/Detective Novel Written? Which authors were responsible for developing the genre as we know it today. From skilled Private Investigators, to bumbling local constabularies. The story behind the story of the Crime/Detective genre.

title: Digital Privacy 101
description:
This session introduces you to essential online privacy tools and concepts.

Pre-requisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills required.

In this class you will:
-Learn how to maintain your online privacy through good habits and through securing your accounts and devices.
-Develop a strong password, and review the best methods for storing your passwords.
-Learn about various online threats such as malware, phishing, and hacking.
-Gain an understanding of the limitations of these tools and habits.

title: Social Media 101 for Small Businesses & Entrepreneurs *New Date: Tues Nov 14*
description:
Social Media 101 is a concise and beginner-friendly workshop designed to equip business owners with a solid foundation and practical strategies for leveraging social media effectively.

Participants will learn how to identify and reach their target audience, develop a strong brand presence, and create engaging content. The workshop also focuses on leveraging social media to generate leads, nurture customer relationships, and ultimately drive sales conversions. By the end of the workshop, business owners will be equipped with practical knowledge and actionable techniques to make a positive impact on their social media presence and drive business results.

The Social Media 101 workshop is the perfect opportunity for business owners to gain valuable knowledge and skills in a short time frame, enabling them to kickstart their social media efforts and make a meaningful impact on their business growth.

Hafsa Taher is a Certified ICF Business Coach with over 10 years of business experience while running two small sized businesses in Canada. Hafsa has coached and mentored over 200 aspiring entrepreneurs all over the world. She is currently running a mentorship mastermind for women in business, evaluating business ideas and plans for success.

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 3. Formes documentaires : le montage
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions d'esthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Cet atelier questionne la forme à travers le montage : à quel moment le montage intervient dans la réalisation et quelles sont ses possibilités ? Comment le travail de montage influence-t-il la forme documentaire ? Les témoignages de monteu·r·se·s donnent des éclairages sur cette étape majeure.

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 24 octobre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Adventurer's Night for Teen (A Monthly Dungeons and Dragons Session)
description:
Come to our monthly dungeons and dragons game! Team up with a group of adventurers to conquer whatever the world throws at you!

Whether you are season player, or new to the game all are welcome to join us for a two hours monthly table-top roll playing mini session! Pre-generated characters will be provided to participants as we guide you through an exciting one-shot adventure.
No prior experience required, come with an open mind and ready for adventure!

Open to ages 13-19, Adventurer's Night for Adults is also available, see schedule for details.
This a in person program held in our digital innovation hub.
Registration required*

title: Excel Basics 2: Do More with your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.


In this second session you will:

- Practice data entry and formatting

- Manipulate rows and columns

- Create and copy simple formulas

- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter

- Create your first chart


Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.


Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: The Birth, Life, and Bizarre Death of Stars
description:
How are the sun and stars born? How can they live for billions of years? How do they turn into bizarre objects such as white dwarfs, neutron stars, pulsars, and black holes? Lots of time for questions and discussion -- on any aspect of astronomy that you wish!

Led by John Percy, Professor Emeritus at the University of Toronto, in Astronomy & Astrophysics, and in Science Education.

Drop-in, no registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Microplastics: Tiny But Dangerous
description:
Microplastics are tiny pieces of plastic that are having a big impact on our waterways. In this hands-on session, learn why microplastics pose a problem and what can be done to raise awareness of the issue.

Participants will sort through terrestrial and aquatic samples for various types of plastic debris, and examine the results with microscopes.

Presented by the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA).

This in-person and in-branch program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

Questions? Please contact the branch.

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

description:

November 14- The Retreat

description:

title: Non-Fiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a staff moderated discussion of The great Halifax explosion : a World War I story of treachery, tragedy, and extraordinary heroism by John U. Bacon. Click on the title link for other available formats.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book club/book discussion. For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

No registration is required. Join the discussion on Jitsi at the appointed date/time.

For questions, reminder calls or assistance in getting the title, please email aguay@tpl.ca.

For a full list of upcoming dates/titles, check out Non-Fiction Book Club Titles or visit our website.

  • 2023 December 12: The Library Book by Susan Orlean
  • 2024 January 9: 21 lessons for the 21st century by Yuval N. Harari
  • 2024 February 13: No time like the future : an optimist considers mortality by Michael J. Fox
  • 2024 March 12: Burnout:The Secret to unlocking the Stress Cycle by Emily Nagoski
  • 2024 April 9: Chatter : the voice in our head, why it matters, and how to harness it by Ethan Kross
  • 2024 May 14: Nomadland : surviving America in the twenty-first century by Jessica Bruder
  • 2024 June 11: Eats, shoots & leaves : the zero tolerance approach to punctuation by Lynne Truss

    If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: The Joy of Writing
description:

title: Croisée des mots avec Mélanie Guillaume
description:
L'Association des auteures et auteurs de l'Ontario français (AAOF) et la Bibliothèque publique de Toronto (BPT) ont le plaisir de vous convier à une Croisée des mots virtuelle et gratuite !

L'autrice et slameuse torontoise, Mélanie Guillaume s'invite dans votre salon avec au programme : lecture, entrevue et discussions virtuelles avec le public en direct !

Féministe engagée, elle abordera avec notre animateur la réalité des femmes milléniales, de la génération #metoo, et de cette rage de vivre qui les habite.

Biographie : Mélanie Guillaume est originaire de France où elle a vécu jusqu'à ses trente ans. Bien qu'ayant suivi une formation scientifique, Mélanie raffole de littérature depuis qu'elle est toute petite. En 2015, elle décide de tout quitter et part s'installer à Toronto. Au cours de son aventure canadienne, elle met sa plume au service du journal francophone local, L'Express, pour lequel elle rédige les portraits des personnages inspirants qui croisent sa route. En 2017, elle monte sur les planches pour partager ses poèmes. C'est l'occasion pour la jeune femme de laisser sortir les traumatismes qui ont jalonné son enfance et d'expier sa colère. Féministe et révoltée, elle clame ensuite ses convictions dans des textes souvent sombres et engagés au sein du groupe de slam Mouton Noir. Plurielle est son premier roman.

Animateur : Originaire d'Ottawa, Hugues Beaudoin-Dumouchel est animateur, chroniqueur, artiste de voix hors champ, interprète de conférence et maître de cérémonie. Cet intervieweur, anime régulièrement des conférences et des tables-rondes, en plus d'avoir mené environ une centaine d'entrevues avec divers auteurs. À la télévision, Hugues a animé les soirées électorales de TV Rogers, ainsi que les émissions Coups Francs et Court-Circuit. Le samedi matin, Hugues assure la revue des médias aux émissions Les Malins et À échelle humaine, sur les ondes d'Ici Radio-Canada Première. On peut l'entendre occasionnellement en remplacement à l'animation des diverses émissions radio d'Ici Radio-Canada Première à Ottawa-Gatineau.


Ce programme est rendu possible grâce au partenariat avec L'Association des auteures et auteurs de l'Ontario français (AAOF).

Diffusion sur la plateforme ZOOM d'AAOF. Pour y participer, il faut s'inscrire à l'avance en cliquant sur le lien ici

Cet événement se déroule sur ZOOM et est géré par AAOF qui est responsable de tous les aspects incluant les règles de protection de la confidentialité.

****

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca
Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines à l'avance.

title: Introduction to 3D Printing
description:
This class/lecture is DROP-IN.

Learn how 3D printers work and how you can print at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs. This class includes instruction with PrusaSlicer, the software used to prepare your 3D object file for printing on an Prusa MK3S printer.
Note: Customers are no longer required to attend a mandatory 3D printing class prior to using a 3D printer at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs.
This class is for those who are interested in learning more about 3D printing and how to use the PrusaSlicer software and understanding how to get started with our 3D printing service.

description:

title: Managing Your Finances in Retirement
description:
Learn how to better manage your finances and make the most of you money in retirement. Find out how to create a budget. Learn about the different stages of retirement. Gain valuable tools and resources to stretch your retirement funds.

Presented by Sanjar Farzaneh, CPA.

Program Room A, 2nd floor. Drop in, no registration required.

description:

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at Albert Campbell Library.

title: Poetry Saved Our Lives
description:
Poetry Saved Our Lives is an eight-week spoken word series for teens to explore their creative voices and make friends. Develop your writing, poetry and stories with a supportive and experienced coach.

Coach Desiree Mckenzie is an award-winning poet, National Poetry Slam Champion and photographer from Toronto. Desiree has led community poetry programming with JAYU, VIBE Arts and more.

The program is relocated to Evelyn Gregory branch from Oakwood Village branch.

This is an in-person program. For more information, call the branch at 416-394-1040.

title: Cercle de conversation bilingue / Bilingual Conversation Circle
description:
Le Programme Connexions Communautaires du Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto ainsi que la Bibliothèque publique de Toronto vous invitent au prochain cercle de conversation bilingue qui aura lieu le 8 septembre 2023 de 18h à 19h30.

Les cercles de conversation bilingues constituent une bonne opportunité pour pratiquer votre anglais et/ou français. C'est aussi un moment d'échange et de réseautage entre participants.
Veuillez noter que le nombre de places est limité, prière de vous inscrire afin de confirmer votre participation :
jnoufissa@centrefranco.org ou tbamanthia@centrefranco.org

***

Come join us for the bilingual conversation circle! The bilingual conversation circle is a good opportunity for French-speakers to practice English and for English-speakers to improve their French. It is a great chance to meet new people and to explore networking opportunities.

The number of places is limited.

For further information, contact jnoufissa@centrefranco.org ou tbamanthia@centrefranco.org

description:
Vous voulez améliorer votre français ? La meilleure façon est de pratiquer ! Joignez-vous à notre cercle de conversation en ligne pour échanger avec d'autres passionnés de la langue française et de la culture francophone. Une connaissance de base de la langue est recommandée.

description:
Join Joëlle, our 2023 Entrepreneur in Residence, to learn how to to achieve better work-life balance. In this session you will learn about tools and techniques to improve your productivity, so that you can focus your time on what matters most to you.

P﻿art of the 2023 Entrepreneur in Residence series.

title: Retiring on a Low Income: Understanding the Personal Income Tax System
description:
Join John Stapleton of Open Policy Ontario for a series of programs meant to support you in planning for retirement. In Part 2, you'll learn what taxable income is and how tax credits (refundable and non-refundable), deductions, entitlements, and exemptions can help you reduce your taxable income.

This is a drop-in program; no registration is required.

***

This program is part of Toronto Public Library's Financial Empowerment initiative.

***

If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Word Basics Series
description:
Word Basics is a 3-week course designed to build your confidence by introducing new skills that you will build on each week. Learn how to create, save, print and delete Word documents, basic text formatting and style features, creating bulleted, numbered and sorted lists and how to format a simple resume.

Word Basics 1 - November 8
Word Basics 2 - November 15
Word Basics 3 - November 22

The class is limited to 10 participants. Please register starting October 25 in-branch or by phoning 416-395-5460.

title: Knitting Circle
description: Come out and join other knitters and crafters. Learn and share new tips and skills weekly. A limited supply of materials will be available, so please bring your own, if you have them.

title: Make Sense of Managing Your Money (Cash Chat)
description:
These days, with so many options available, how can a person make sense of managing their money? Where can people find sound advice so they can reach their financial goals, especially if they are on their own?

Regardless of your age, life stage, or financial situation it's important to be informed and learn how to make the best decision for yourself regardless of what the media and your friends may be promoting. Join the discussion with consumer Ardelle Harrison, co-author of the book Bank on Yourself: Why Every Woman Should Plan Financially to be Single, Even If Shes Not.

Visit the branch in person or call us at 416 396 8890 to register.

If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Beaches Library or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request.

title: Club de lecture avec Le Théâtre français de Toronto
description:
La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto et le Théâtre français de Toronto s'associent pour créer un club de lecture « théâtre ». Ce rendez-vous mensuel est l'occasion de discuter et d'explorer des scènes mythiques ayant marqué le monde du théâtre. Avec Georges Som, médiateur culturel, nous essayerons de comprendre les enjeux de ces scènes, de découvrir leurs sens et de partager nos sentiments sur leurs auteurs et autrices. Chacun est le bienvenu au club, qu'il soit néophyte ou amateur de théâtre confirmé. Les seuls prérequis pour participer sont la curiosité et le plaisir d'échanger autour du théâtre !

Le 15 novembre nous aborderons la pièce « La mort et l'écuyer du roi » de Wole Soyinka. Pour ceux qui s'inscrivent à la rencontre du 15 novembre, le texte d'une scène sera fourni par le Théâtre.

Pour vous inscrire, c'est gratuit ! Envoyez un courriel à gsom@theatrefrancais.com

On se réunit à la Bibliothèque de référence de Toronto au 4e étage du département des langues et des littératures. Pour les directions, demandez au bureau d'information.

title: English Conversation Circle
description:
New to Canada? Learning to speak English? Practice and improve your English skills, make new friends, network & share experiences, learn about Canada, and get information about upcoming events in Toronto. No registration required. NOTE: THE OCT/25 SESSION IS CANCELLED.
* Please note that this is not a formal English class *

title: Intro to 3D Design: Fusion360 Evening
description: Learn to design simple 3D objects and prepare them for printing. Explore the application Autodesk Fusion360 and get a hands-on demo. Registration is required.

title: Learn to Play Magic: The Gathering
description:
Magic: The Gathering is a popular collectable card game and was launched in 1993. Celebrate 30 years of wizard battles with us by trying it out for the very first time! A registered Level 1 Judge will teach participants the basics of the game. Learn about the different colours of magic, building decks, phases in a turn, card types and more.

This program is intended for participants who have never played Magic: The Gathering or Magic: The Gathering Arena.

Registration is required for this free program. Please register online through our Eventbrite. Cards and supplies will be provided. Participants will get to keep the cards after the program.

title: Making Autobiographical Comics: A Four-Week Workshop
description:
This recurring seminar selects a small group of comics makers looking to develop a pre-existing project over four sessions. Seminar participants will be driven by the open-ended question: What makes a "good" comic? Sessions will provide a safe, constructive environment to provide and receive generative criticisms and beneficial affirmations.

This program is presented by Jamie Michaels, TPL's Fall 2023 Writer in Residence whose focus is Graphic Novels. Learn more about TPL's Writer in Residence program, including upcoming programs and one-on-one consultation sessions.

Spaces are limited, submit applications to trllanglit@tpl.ca for consideration. Applications will be considered as they are received. The final deadline to apply is October 20th. Applications should include:
-a sample of an autobiographical comic project in process (1-5 pages in length)
-a brief biographical statement (1 paragraph in length)
-a brief description of the project (1 paragraph in length)

**

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Futures Club: Trends - Futures of Work, Session 1
description:
Using the work done in the Horizon Scan sessions, we we will work together to develop insightful trends around the Futures of Work.

Futures Club Series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

title: City of the Dead: The History of Toronto's Early Cemetaries
description:
Join Virginia Van Vliet for an evening of discovery. Delve into the history of Toronto's first cemeteries, their impact on our local communities, and some of their famous - and infamous - residents.


​Virginia Van Vliet has been involved in researching Toronto history for community heriatge organizations for at least 25 years, including writing and leading historic walking tours for the Cabbagetown Preservation Association and Royal Ontario Museum. She is also a member of the Association for Gravestone Studies, and has been published in their journal.

Please register by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

Join us for a lively book discussion of novel novels. We will be discussing Shuggie Bain by Douglas Stuart. The title is available as eAudiobook and eBook from Toronto Public Library's OverDrive eBooks & eAudiobooks collection. It is also available as Audiobook CD and Large Print.

title: An Evening with the Scotiabank Giller Prize Winner
description:
Join the winner of the 2023 Scotiabank Giller Prize, a literary award presented to a Canadian author of a novel or short story collection, for an evening of celebration and conversation with Ryan B. Patrick, the host of CBC's The Next Chapter.

Books available for purchase. Book signing to follow.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on November 1 at 9:00am ET.

***
This is the 29th year of the Scotiabank Giller Prize. Established in 1994 by Jack Rabinovitch in honour of his late wife, literary journalist Doris Giller, who passed away from cancer the year before. The award recognized excellence in Canadian fiction - long format or short stories - and endowed a cash prize annually of $25,000.00, the largest purse for literature in the country. This year's jury includes award-winning authors Sharon Bala, Brian Thomas Isaac, Rebecca Makkai, Neel Mukherjee and Ian Williams.

Learn more about the Scotiabank Giller Prize and the finalists:
Scotiabank Giller Prize

***
This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***
Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The prize ceremony starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Raising Confident Kids: Fostering a Positive Relationship with Food
description:
Join us for a workshop all about children and food. Andrea Carpenter is a Registered Dietitian with over 15 years of pediatric nutrition experience in clinical and community settings and brings a realistic and family-centered approach to her nutrition strategies.

In this one-hour nutrition program, Andrea will equip parents and caregivers with skills to guide and shape their children's relationship with food. Understand how social media messaging and other external influences may affect how your child thinks about food and their growing body. Regardless of age, learn how to raise intuitive and confident eaters from infancy to toddlerhood to school age and beyond.


This program is part of the Raising Confident Kids: Workshops for Parents Series.

title: Understanding Responsive Behaviours in People Living with Dementia
description:
This program is for anyone looking for practical strategies and techniques to help de-escalate situations, manage crises, and preserve compassion. Join a team of Baycrest@Home social workers to learn about the 3 D's: dementia, depression, and delirium as it relates to behavioural changes.

This program is part of the online program series Caregiver 101: The Fundamentals of Dementia Caregiving, developed by Baycrest@Home.
Whether you are a spouse, partner, adult child, family member, friend, or neighbour and find yourself thrust into the role of caregiving for someone living with dementia or memory changes - knowing what to do and how to plan can feel overwhelming. Caregiver 101 was developed to help you care with confidence, and specifically designed to equip family caregivers with the tools, knowledge and skills to become a care partner.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay for one week.

Register and receive a reminder, or tune in live on November 16

title: Toronto in Literature Book Club (Online)
description:
Join us each month to discuss literature set in Toronto. See our city in a new light through stories about its past and present.

This November, join us for an online discussion of The Mother of All Degrassi: A Memoir by Linda Schuyler.

'When a young schoolteacher decides to teach her Grade 8 class about filmmaking and creates a documentary that ends up being broadcast internationally, she sets in motion a career of storytelling for an age group largely ignored by TV executives...and creates one of the most-loved television franchises of all time.

Lindas deep fondness for teenagers has made her a champion for adolescents. In The Mother of All Degrassi, she shares her strong belief that television is all about the story, and a good story is all about making the political personal. Through anecdotes and introspection  and some great behind-the-scenes stories for Degrassi fans  Linda examines her philosophy to dream big, think small, meet life head-on, and always keep an open heart. [Source]

Copies of the title are available to borrow in Print, eBook and eAudiobook format from the Toronto Public Library collection.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book discussion. Registration is limited and specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to the registrants one day before the book club meeting.

For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out our Getting Started with Jitsi guide. Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

title: *REGISTRATION FULL* Hexagon Quilt Workshop
description:
REGISTRATION FULL

Learn to sew fabric hexagons, a quilt-making technique popular during the 1700's right up to today. The hexagons will be combined to create a 6-petal flower. Participants can make their own hexagon quilt-top at home using this technique or the flower can be appliquéd on a jacket, pillow, fabric pencil case, etc. Several methods to create a fabric hexagon will be explained during this 2-hour workshop.

description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

- Manipulate rows and columns
- Create and copy simple formulas

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.

title: Excel Basics 3: Tables, Pivots and Formula
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Excel 2019 skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this third session you will:

- Sort and filter the data in tables
- Learn the basics of Pivot Tables
- Create and format charts
- Practice IF, VLOOKUP and IFERROR functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using Pivot tables and formulas.

Pre-requisites: Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

title: Roz Chast: I Must Be Dreaming
description:
New York Times bestselling, award-winning New Yorker cartoonist Roz Chast joins us to discuss her new graphic narrative, exploring the surreal nighttime world inside her mind and untangling one of our most enduring human mysteries: dreams.

In I Must Be Dreaming, Roz Chast illustrates her own dream world, a place that is sometimes creepy but always hilarious, accompanied by an illustrated tour through "Dream-Theory Land" guided by insights from poets, philosophers, and psychoanalysts alike.

Roz Chast speaks about I Must Be Dreaming, an illuminating, surprising, funny, and often profound journey through her newest subject of fascination, and one of the strangest phenomena we all experience: dreaming.

Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on November 2 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guest:
Roz Chast

Read more:
I Must Be Dreaming
Going Into Town: A Love Letter to New York

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7pm, but doors open at 6pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.


***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library:

title: Hacking for the Holidays
description:
Join us to learn about the Makers Making Change program and to switch-adapt toys. Participants will learn how to take apart a toy, identify buttons that control the toy, and solder in jacks that will allow someone to control the toy with an assistive switch. All switch-adapted toys will be donated to children with disabilities across Ontario as part of the Hacking for the Holidays campaign, a campaign by Neil Squire's Makers Making Change program to make play accessible to families with children with disabilities across Canada.

Makers Making Change (MMC) is a program of Neil Squire, a non-profit which works to empower Canadians with disabilities. MMC connects people with disabilities to volunteer makers who can build affordable assistive technologies.

Please register in-branch or by calling (416) 393-7717. Spots are limited. This is a program for teens only.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

title: 1-on-1 Career Consultations with ACCES Employment *PROGRAM FULL, JOIN WAITLIST*
description:
Are you feeling stuck in your job search? Look no further! Explore the incredible resources and expertise offered by ACCES Employment. Step into a world of endless possibilities as you connect with their dedicated team of Employment Consultants, ready to transform your career trajectory. Unleash your potential with tailored resume reviews, invaluable interview tips, and a wealth of additional support. Book a free 30-minute appointment with an Employment Consultant and embark on a remarkable journey toward your dream job.

Consultations are limited to 1 per person. Registrants will receive an email reminder a week before their appointment and are required to confirm their attendance. If attendance has not been confirmed by 5 PM two days before the appointment date, the spot will be released to the waitlist.

Consultations will take place in the Business, Science and Technology Department (4th Floor). Appointment slots are currently fully booked for the rest of 2023. To be added to the waitlist for one or more of the remaining consultation dates, please call the North York Central Library's Business, Science and Technology Department at 416-395-5613.

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 1

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 2

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 20 - Financial Freedom in Retirement (CANCELLED)
October 27 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
November 3 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 10 - Elder Abuse
November 17 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 24 - Physical Health and Exercise
December 1 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Registration is required for each session. Register in person or call Centennial Library at (416) 395-5490.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

October 6
Cubas Wild Revolution
Cuba is home to some of the most unusual creatures in the world. From the tiniest bird, the bee hummingbird to the smallest frog, jumping crocodiles and thousands of migrating crabs. The island has remained untouched until recently when the pressure to develop has increased. Will Cuba be able to save its wildlife? Closed Captions.55 minutes. 2020

October 13
Planet Food: Malaysia
Travel the country of Malaysia and discover just how multicultural it is by exploring their rich variety of foods. Whether you like spicy Laksa soup, mackerel curry or food cooked in a blowpipe, the adventure is delicious.
50 minutes. 2011

October 20
Worlds Greatest Engineering Icons: Civic Buildings
Throughout history, people have strived to make monumental buildings that communicate power, wealth and great architectural accomplishments. This film showcases many of these extraordinary achievements highlighting structures places such as Red Square, Petra, the United States Capital and the pyramids among others. Closed captions. 55 minutes. 2021

October 27
Cameroon
Explore Cameroon in western Africa. Join an adventurer as he struggles to climb Mount Cameroon, meet a pygmy tribe and take part in some of their celebrations, meet a chief with 50 wives and track lions in Waza National Park. Closed captions. 59 minutes.2020

November 3
The Green Planet: Tropical Worlds
Sir David Attenborough takes a plants-eye view of life in a rainforest, a world of stunning beauty but also fierce competition. From fast-growing trees to flowers that mimic dead animals, this is a journey into a magical world that operates on a different timescale to our own. Closed Captions. 50 minutes. 2022.

November 10
Secrets of the Sky Tombs
The Himalayas are among the most difficult places to live. Who were the people who chose to live at impossibly high altitudes surrounded by sheer cliffs. What strange rituals did they have that required gold masks and Chinese silk to ward off the spirits of the dead? 60 minutes. Closed Captions, 2017

November 17
Edible Insects
From crunchy crickets to nutty fly grubs, NOVA takes a tasty look at using insects as food and gives us insight into how they benefit us. Besides building larger and therefore smarter brains, insect protein actually makes us healthier and even helps to protect the environment by reducing meat consumption Closed Captions. 55 minutes .2021.

November 24
Worlds Greatest Natural Icons: Fire
Fire has created some of our most memorable and beautiful icons as well as destroyed some of our most valuable places. This film captures many of the worlds most magnificent volcanoes such as those in Hawaii and Japan as well as bubbling hot springs and mud baths in Iceland. However, it also shows us the dark side of fire especially land that has been laid to waste.2021

December 1
The Story of Cats: Asia to Africa
Discover how the first cats began in the forests of Asia and how they spread across the continent, eventually conquering Africa. How did they evolve from lions and tigers to house cats? What special adaptations do they need to survive in so many different environments? Closed Captions. 60 minutes. 2017

December 8
Can we make Life?
Science fiction movies show scientists bringing ancient creatures back to life. Is this a possibility? Can science really use DNA to resurrect extinct animals? Furthermore, can genetic biology improve our lives by eradicating disease? Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2018.

December 15
Canada: Surviving the North
Behold some of the world's most astonishing wildlife, and see how they live, from Canada's high arctic and tundra to the boreal forest. Each animal has innate abilities that allow it to hunt and survive in all seasons. These capabilities range from astounding hearing, to incredible speed and to patient silent stalking.
Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2022

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

January 12
Engineering Our World
This inspiring film follows engineers who have devoted their lives to seemingly impossible challenges and against all odds have made them happen. It is a story about human ingenuity and innovation. Closed Captions.45 minutes..2017.

January 19
The Megafalls of Iguaca
Follow the lives of animals that live in the Iguacu National Park, near the largest waterfalls on earth. This Atlantic rainforest houses swifts, who fly through the massive quantities of falling water, as well as spotted jaguars and a family of coatis. The film also shows the park rangers who battle to keep the reserve from destruction. Closed Captions.60 minutes. 2016.

January 26
Age of Stars
The sun is the source of our light, heat and energy. This film explores the birth of stars like our sun as well as their exit as exploding supernova .Billions of years from now our sun will die and will usher in the age of darkness. Closed Captions.55 minutes.2021.

February 2
Wild Metropolis: Residents
As cities grow larger, many residents have been pushed out of their homes in the wild and are adapting to their new urban habitat.in the city. From pythons in Bangkok to otters in Singapore, many animals learn adjust to these unlikely conditions. Closed Captions. 55 minutes.2019


February 9
Destination Northern Australia: Queensland
Enjoy a trip to Queensland in Northern Australia with the magnificent sunny beaches that draw surfers from all over, the oldest tropical forest in the world and the Great Barrier Reef.
60 minutes. 2002


February 16
Dynasties: Chimpanzees
David, the alpha male chimpanzee in his troupe in Senegal, tries to overcome threats to his leadership by younger males and by doing so ensure an heir. His determination to hang on to his position in the light of drought conditions and other difficulties is moving. Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2019


February 23
Secrets of Lost Empires 2: Roman Baths
Ancient Roman baths were used not only to stay clean but to socialize. However, the technology behind the baths was lost more than 2,000 years ago. What did the Romans do when there was no soap and how did they remain fashionable with hairless bodies? How did the Romans manage to pipe enough water for the community and control the temperature? Using ruins as a guide, scientists set out to recreate a Roman bath as the Romans did. 53 minutes.2008

March 1
Natures Great Race: Zebras
Follow Africas longest migration as scientists track thousands of zebras through the Botswana wilderness on their way to the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. It is a harrowing journey as the animals and their young face starvation, wild dogs , lions and drought. Closed Captions. 54 minutes.2017


March 8
Alien Solar Systems
Is our solar system unique? How was our solar system created? Since the first discovery of a planet orbiting another star, some 280 alien solar systems have been identified. It's only by looking at solar systems far beyond our own, that we can understand how remarkable our universe is.
Closed captions. 48 minutes. 2011


March 15
India: Natures Wonderland
Our guide starts in the Gir Forest, home to the worlds last Asiatic lions, tracks elephants as they travel an old path through a tea plantation, and observes gibbons that begin each morning by singing. This is an unusual view of Indias rarely seen natural world. Closed Captions. 60 minutes.2016


March 22
Royal Myths & Secrets 11: George IV and the Regency
Lucy Worsley reveals how mental health problems forced King George to relinquish power to his debauched and extravagant son. Was this really an era of extravagance and regal splendour or was it a darker time of concealed revolution? Closed captions. 53 minutes.2020

title: PA Day Movie: The Super Mario Bros. Movie
description:

A Brooklyn plumber named Mario travels through the Mushroom Kingdom with a princess named Peach to find Mario's brother, Luigi, and to save the world from a fire-breathing Koopa named Bowser. This film is rated PG. Drop in. Space is limited.

If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email at accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least 3 weeks in advance.

title: Richard III: The Real Man, not the Shakespearean Villain
description:
​Fake News!

William Shakespeare was not an historian, nor did he ever claim to be. Yet people continue to believe his depiction of Richard III is true. Members of the Richard III Society will explain who Richard III actually was, how this differs from the play and why such a character was created.

Please register at the front desk or by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: **CLASS FULL** Excel Basics 2: Do More with your Data
description:
**CLASS IS FULL** An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this second session you will:

- Practice data entry and formatting
- Manipulate rows and columns
- Create and copy simple formulas
- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter
- Create your first chart

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.

Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.

Registration required. Registration for November classes begins Monday, October 23, 2023 at 9 a.m.

Please register in-person at the first floor reference desk or by calling 416-395-5672.

For children ages 6 - 12 only.

Space is limited to 30 participants. Registration begins on October 20th. Please register by asking staff or by calling 416-394-5240.

title: Jurassic Code: Spheroraptor Escape
description:
Join us for an exciting Jurassic themed hour of coding & robots!
"Dr. Malcom won't stop going on about these Spheroraptor pens. He keeps jabbering about the "history of evolution" and how "life will not be contained." I'm not sure what he's getting at. The electrified fences should hold them in just fine, right? Right?

In this activity you will work for both sides. You must create a fortified pen to keep the Spheroraptors at bay...all the while you will create a program to help the Spheroraptors escape. From loops, to conditionals, to operators and even comparators, you will need as much coding knowhow you can muster.

In the end, see how fast your Spheroraptor can escape the pen. Some say it's "survival of the fittest." For the Spheroraptors, it's survival of the FASTEST!"

Ages 6+. Please register on eventbrite here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/jurassic-code-spheroraptor-escape-tickets-739618638257?aff=oddtdtcreator

description:
Spend a cozy afternoon at the library and join us for a screening of an old favourite: the critically acclaimed Ratatouille!

The movie tells the story of a rat named Remy, who dreams of becoming a great chef despite his family's wishes and the obvious problem of being a rat in a decidedly rodent-phobic profession. When Remy forms an unlikely partnership with Linguini, the new garbage boy at one of Paris's most exclusive restaurants, the two set into motion a hilarious chain of events that turns the city's culinary world upside down.

Please note this movie is rated G and has a run time of 1h 51m.

November 3: Computers for Beginners 1 - Use the Mouse
November 10: Computers for Beginners 2 - Use the Keyboard
November 17: Computers for Beginners 3 - Use the Web

title: Making Music with Pure Data, a Multimedia Programming Language, for Beginners
description:
You can do more with music on a computer than record, playback, or compose. With the right tools, you can program a computer to make music itself! In this workshop, we will introduce the Pure Data environment, where you can manipulate audio and music notes by coding simple programs where the computer makes music automatically. You will learn the basics of using Pure Data, including how it represents audio and note information, and how to code a simple instrument that works by itself to make music.

Hosted by Dr. Jason Cullimore, TPL Innovator in Residence (Fall 2022).

This is drop-in program is for teens only. No registration required. Space is limited. Arrive early to ensure you have a spot.

description:
Tinkercad is a browser based software that can be used by designers of all ages. In this class we will explore how to go from simple shapes to complex 3D designs. Once we've completed the design process we will also talk about how to get our models ready for 3D printing!

Computers will be provided for this class.

For ages 8 - 12.

title: Rise and Sprawl: The Condominiumization of Toronto
description:
In this talk, Alexander Josephson discusses the rapid verticalization of our city while examining the role of developers, architecture, marketing agencies, and governing bodies. Josephson also offers variations and imaginative alternatives to the condominiumization of Toronto.

Alexander Josephson is co-founder of PARTISANS, lecturer at the University of Toronto, and co-author of Rise and Sprawl (2016).

Register in person or by phone, (416) 393-7727.

In this class you will:

Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

description:

How to use the equipment properly and safely

Exploring the many resources around 3D Printing

Followed by the introduction to printing, class participants will be given a hands-on workshop where they learn how to create simple 3D designed key chain and become familiar with design tools.

Registration is required for this class. You can order free tickets by clicking the link below. Tickets will become available one week prior to the class at 9 a.m.

title: Hacking for the Holidays
description:
Join us to learn about the Makers Making Change program and to switch-adapt toys. Participants will learn how to take apart a toy, identify buttons that control the toy, and solder in jacks that will allow someone to control the toy with an assistive switch. All switch-adapted toys will be donated to children with disabilities across Ontario as part of the Hacking for the Holidays campaign, a campaign by Neil Squire's Makers Making Change program to make play accessible to families with children with disabilities across Canada.

Makers Making Change (MMC) is a program of Neil Squire, a non-profit which works to empower Canadians with disabilities. MMC connects people with disabilities to volunteer makers who can build affordable assistive technologies.

Please register in-branch or by calling (416)395-5460. Spots are limited. This is a program for teens only.

title: Computers for Beginners 3:  Use the Internet
description:
An introductory class on the Internet for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this third session you will:

- Understand how to read a web site address
- Practice using web addresses
- Search for information using a search engine
- Explore a web site in detail to understand its key components


Upon completion of this class students will be able to use the internet at a beginner level and complete simple searches.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 & 2 or basic mouse and keyboarding skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

title: The Bark / The Inner Bark - Clay Activity and Nature Walk
description:
Creating forms with clay, we will explore and learn about the textures and symbolism of outer bark vs. inner bark. Participants will reflect on how the layers of bark are like ourselves, what we see on the outside versus the spirit that is underneath. Afterword, we will take a nature walk, bringing our clay forms with us to place them on trees and in nature, creating land-based artwork.

Please call 416-394-5350 or visit New Toronto Branch to register.

title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

title: Repair Café
description:
The Repair Café is excited to launch a new community repair model at the Richview Library in Etobicoke. We will be hosting a series of mending workshops for clothing and textiles on a monthly basis. Participants will bring in items needing repair and learn ways of mending and/or embellishing their pieces. The meet-ups will be offered as a series of repair skills in which we spotlight a particular set of techniques in each.

Saturday, October 21. (Registration opens September 14):

This two-hour workshop provides an introduction to working with a sewing machine. Participants will also learn how to do free motion/darning on the sewing machine for beautiful and unique embellishment and repair.

*A few machines will be available for shared use and participants are encouraged to bring in their own. Participants are encouraged to bring in their own garment/textile and any project-specific supplies. Basic sewing supplies will be provided.

Saturday, November 18. (Registration Opens October 12):

In this two-hour workshop, participants will learn a range of visible mending techniques, including patching, sashiko stitching, and simple knit repairs to transform garment defects into beautiful, one-of-a kind details.

*Participants are encouraged to bring their own garment/texile and any project-specific supplies. Basic sewing supplies will be provided.


Registration required. To register, visit in-person or call the Richview Library at (416) 394-5120. Space is limited.


If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the Albert Campbell library.

title: L'Art Déco « hors les murs » ; les décors de théâtre et de cinéma (1910-1930).
description:
Désirant diffuser plus largement l'esthétique nouvelle, les peintres et les décorateurs sont très tôt recrutés, en France mais aussi en Europe, pour réaliser des décors de pièces de théâtre, de ballets, mais aussi de films ; Paul Iribe, Georges Lepape, Robert Mallet-Stevens, Sonia Delaunay, Fernand Léger, et tant d'autres, imaginent alors des intérieurs aussi modernes qu'audacieux. Souvent peu connues parce que ces films, à l'exception de ceux d'Abel Gance, sont tombés dans l'oubli, ces réalisations éphémères n'en demeurent pas moins parmi les plus réussies de l'Art Déco.

La conférence est proposée par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art.

En collaboration avec Alliance Française de Toronto.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard.

****

Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

title: Quantum Kidz Lego- Under the Sea
description:
Come join us with Quantum Kidz Lego where we will learn about environmental issues of our oceans, submarines, shipwrecks, coral reefs and sunken treasure.

Registration begins October 10, 2023
Call the branch at 416-396-8916 or come on in to register.
Space is limited.

title: Saturday Knit & Crochet Circle
description:
Want to learn how to knit or crochet with a fun group of people? Looking for help with your knitting or crochet project? Join our Knitting & Crochet Circle! You can also share your projects with other knitters/crocheters, teach a technique, learn a technique, and enjoy great conversation. All level of knitters welcome. Bring your own yarn, needles, and crochet hooks.


For more information speak with branch staff or call 416-395-5940.

title: Family movie afternoon: "The Little Mermaid"
description:
Come join us for the magical live version of the classic "The Little Mermaid". Run time of 135 min. Rated PG. Suitable for ages 7 plus. Bring your own snacks, drinks, and blankets for a comfy experience. This is a drop-in program.

Summary/Review: The youngest of King Triton's daughters, and the most defiant, Ariel longs to find out more about the world beyond the sea, and while visiting the surface, falls for the dashing Prince Eric. While mermaids are forbidden to interact with humans, Ariel must follow her heart. She makes a deal with the evil sea witch, Ursula, which gives her a chance to experience life on land, but ultimately places her life and her father's crown in jeopardy.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Turtles of Toronto:  Who they are and why they matter
description:
Turtles are the most imperiled group of animals in Toronto and arguably the world. Join Jenny Davis, Turtle Protectors co-founder to learn how to identify the most common turtles living in the city, where to best spot them and why they matter through a presentation and hands-on activities. Special guests from the Toronto Wildlife Centre, Victoria Badham, Education & Outreach Manager and Hot Dog, Snapping Turtle Ambassador will join the program to story the importance of leaving turtles in the wild in Toronto and beyond. This is a great opportunity to learn about turtle from turtle!

Photo Credit: James Beaton

To register please visit Parliament Street Branch or call 416-393-7663.

This Environmentalist in Residence program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Chess Club
description:
Join us to learn and play chess each week. Boards and pieces will be provided. Laptops will also be available for those who want to play on chess.com or chesskid.com. Players of all strengths are welcome. No previous experience is required.

For ages 6+. Drop-in, no registration required.

description:
Join us to make a beautiful acrylic painting of the galaxy night sky and let your creativity flow! Guided tutorial and supplies will be provided. This program is for teens. Limited Space. Registration required. Register in branch or call 416-396-8975 or email ststaff@tpl.ca

This is an in-person program.

title: STEM Saturdays
description:
Each week, come in for a fun tech surprise as we explore Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math through coding, circuitry, robotics and more!

Will we play a song with Dash? Will we teach Sphero robots to complete a maze? Will we make a fan spin with Snap Circuits? Will we build a bridge?

Join us to find out!

For ages 4-12. Space is limited.

title: Community Writing Group
description:
Looking for somewhere to share your writing with like-minded creative folks? The Community Writing Group welcomes creative writers and poets to bring their in-progress poetry and short fiction to share and discuss in a friendly, welcoming environment. The group meets every second Saturday.

Drop in; no registration required.

description:
Explore electricity and circuitry through Snap Circuits in this hands-on program! Make circuits that can turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker, and more!

description:

title: How to Teach Your Kids About Money with Teri Courchene
description:
This session is designed to help parents and caregivers learn how to teach their children money sense and good financial habits. Teri will walk through ideas for all ages ranging from preschool to young adult. She will cover many topics, including learning through playing games, different approaches to giving allowance, how to build your child's budgeting skills, and the pros and cons of credit cards.

description:
​Learn how to write and draw comics & graphic novels with the award-winning creator of Jellaby and March Grand Prix! Kean will lead you through the foundations of creating fun, compelling characters, plot outlines, and pulling it all together by laying out and drawing your own comic!

For ages 6 to 12.
