Ages 8-12.

Registration is required as spaces are limited. Registration begins November 7. Please call the branch (416-395-5460) or come in in person to register.

title: LSP: English Conversation Circle
description:
Are you learning English? Practice and improve your English conversation skills in a relaxing environment while making new friends and learning what the library has to offer! Beginner and intermediate learners are welcome. Please note that this is not a formal English class.

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, Kababayan Multicultural Centre & Toronto Public Library.

This is a drop-in program. For more information visit Parkdale library or call 416-393-7686.

description:
Bring your imaginations and crafty skills and join us in creating artifacts from the future based on the trends we are seeing today.

Imagination Lab Series:
Step into a world of endless possibilities with Imagination Lab, a captivating futures thinking workshop series that welcomes participants of all ages, including curious children. Through a blend of games, crafts, and creative exploration, we'll embark on a journey to craft and explore the vast landscapes of potential future worlds. Join us in this hands-on adventure, where youthful minds and seasoned thinkers unite to shape the narratives of tomorrows yet to come.

For 1 on 1 Consultations with IIR Alexis Tennent, book through: calendly.com/clsr/iir-1on1-consultation

title: The SciFi and Fantasy Book Club
description:
Join a brand-new book club hosted by The Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy! Each month we will read a book from a different sub-genre such as space opera, high fantasy, cyberpunk and more. Dates, genres and books are listed below.

Saturday September 9
The Left Hand of Darkness by Ursula K. Le Guin
Available in regular print, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday October 14
What Moves the Dead by T. Kingfisher
Available in regular print, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday November 18
The Deep by Rivers Solomon
Available in regular print, CD audiobook, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday December 9
An Ocean of Minutes by Thea Lim
Available in regular print, large print, CD audiobook, ebook and eaudiobook.

No registration is required and everyone is welcome. Want an email reminder? Sign up for a free ticket through our Eventbrite.

Book club meetings will take place in the Merril Collection Reading Room on the third floor of Lillian H. Smith Branch.

If you need help getting a copy of the book or have any questions, please contact us at lsmestaff@tpl.ca or 416-393-7748.

title: PowerPoint Basics 3: Add Visual Style to Your Presentation
description:
Create a more sophisticated PowerPoint 2019 presentation with more advanced features.

In this session you will learn to:

- Crop pictures, add picture borders and add picture effects.
- Align and distribute objects.
- Insert and edit SmartArt graphics.
- Animate objects.
- Edit a theme.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 and 2 or equivalent experience. Keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min] 

Registration required. Please register at the branch or by calling 416-396-8890.

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Introduction to Vinyl Printer with Illustrator
description:
This workshop is an introduction to making cutlines in Adobe Illustrator for the Roland Versa STUDIO BN-20, a desktop vinyl printer with a cutting function. It can be used to create signage, stickers, labels, transfers for apparel, POP displays, window stickers, posters and more.

Cutlines are essentially lines which indicate the shape of a sticker. They can be a certain shape, or follow the outline of an image.

Registration is required and begins November 6 at 12:30pm. Note: Your spot will not be guaranteed after 5 minutes of the start of the program.

Class takes place in the 2nd floor eLearning Lab. Before using Illustrator, please be expected to log into your existing Adobe account, or through your Apple ID, Facebook or Gmail account, respectively.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. description:

Space is limited. Please register starting Tuesday, September 5 in-branch or by phoning 416-395-5460.

title: Make A Will with the Ontario Bar Association
description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Kathryn Balter, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you don't have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. Sand, water play, painting, cut and paste, markers, crayons, circle time, and free play are all part of this program. Children are free to rotate between activities throughout the room. title: Computers for Beginners 2: Use the Keyboard
description:
A class on basic keyboard functions for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this second session you will:

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)
- Practice proper keyboarding posture

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and know how to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 or basic mouse skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)

title: **CLASS FULL** Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
**CLASS IS FULL** Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Registration required. Registration for November classes begins Monday, October 23, 2023 at 9 a.m.

Please register in-person at the first floor reference desk or by calling 416-395-5672.

title: Computers for Beginners 3: Use the Web
description:
In this class you will:
1. Build on tools and experience from Mouse, Keyboard, & Windows Basics.
2. Understand and learn how to use web site addresses.
3. Learn about different areas of a web site. Practice using a web site home page to explore the site.
4. Learn how search engines work and practice using them.
5. Test new skills learned by working on challenges.
6. Review additional resources to help you learn more.

Drop-in only.

title: Laptop Computers for Beginners 6: Use Email
description:
Pre-requisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills required.

In this class you will:
-Learn how to sign-in and sign-out of a Gmail account
-Learn how to read an email, write and send an email, reply to an email, forward an email, delete an email, and open or send attachments
-Review the basics of Gmails security and privacy policy

Registration: visit or call Riverdale Library at 416-393-7720. Drop-ins welcome.

title: Baby Time
description:
Introduce your child to sounds and actions at a 6 week storytime session with bouncing and tickling rhymes, songs and stories. For babies 0-18 months with their parents or caregivers. No registration required.

If you or your child lives with a disability and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Scrabble and Chess Club
description: Come and play a friendly game of Scrabble or Chess at the library! Drop-in, no registration required. For more information, please call 416-394-5270.

title: Book Club
description:
Join us in-person to discuss books in a fun and welcoming book club. Drop-in, no registration required.

September: Deacon King Kong by James McBride
October: The Sisters from Hardscabble Bay by Beverly Jensen
November: The Immortalists by Chloe Benjamin
December: Brain on Fire by Susan Cahalan

Please place the titles on hold.

Program will take place in Room B, 2nd floor.

title: Computers for Beginners 4: Google Search and Maps
description:
This is a class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fourth session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Computers for Beginners 1, 2 & 3 or basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills.

Register in person or by telephone, (416) 393-7727.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Dystopia Nonfiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a lively discussion. We read and talk about topical nonfiction books on how our world is being shaped negatively by forces beyond our control, and dystopian imaginings are becoming present-day realities. It takes place in the third-floor discussion room.

Sep 18 - The Ghost: The Secret Life of CIA Spymaster James Jesus Angleton by Jefferson Morley
Oct 16 - American Kleptocracy by Casey Michel
Nov 20 - The Wolfpack: the millennial mobsters who brought chaos and the cartels to the Canadian underworld by Peter Edwards
Dec 18 - The Decadent Society: how we became the victims of our own success by Ross Douthat

For more info, please call the Humanities and Social Sciences Department at 416-393-7175.

Register on Eventbrite or just drop in.

title: After School Tech Club
description:
Join the Jones Library Tech Club every Monday this fall! Whether it's exploring the wonderful world of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) with robots and circuitry or using your creativity to make digital art, there is always something exciting to do. Join us each week to make new friends while learning and having lots fun!

Drop in only, no registration required. For ages 6-12.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Nov. 13: Music Mixes - Incredibox
Nov. 20: Video Game Coding: Space Invaders
Nov. 27: Pokémon Digital Cards

description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids and have fun! For ages 6-12.

description:
Open to children ages 6-12, this free workshop offers an introduction into art and history in Canada. Working with different mediums, kids will create their own art while learning about Canadian artists and their inspiring creative journeys.

Week 1, Nov 6: Introduction to Canadian Art History and Oil Pastels Inspired by the Group of Seven
Week 2, Nov 13: Inuit Soapstone Carvings
Week 3, Nov 20: Jennifer Sparacino's Contemporary Art Exploration
Week 4, Nov 27: Introduction to Quebec Automatistes - Expressive Abstract Painting

description:
Rekindle your enjoyment of creating art by painting in a relaxed atmosphere. The Acrylic Painting workshop is intended to provide a reintroduction to art with acrylic paint and sometimes other mediums. Participants will get a hands-on step-by-step approach and instruction on a particular painting or free-flow art in a relaxing, creative environment.
Ages 18 - 24.

title: Stories of Turtle Island with Counter Story Conversations
description:
Counterstory Conversations will facilitate "Stories of Turtle Island Project", a residency at Richview Branch for four artists and four to five youth participants to develop and publish a children's book to tell the stories of First Nations, Inuit, and Metis leaders whose impact has transcended generations. Artists will be chosen through a formal selection process before the start of the project. The youth participants who identify as First Nations, Inuit, and/or Metis from across Canada will lead the development of the project.

To submit an interest to participate, questions and more information email Tyana Chiblow at projects@counterstory.ca or click the related link below.

title: Adobe InDesign I
description:
Adobe InDesign is the industry-leading page design and layout app lets you create, preflight, and publish beautiful documents for print and digital media. InDesign CC has everything you need to make posters, books, digital magazines, eBooks, interactive PDFs, and more.

In this beginner's class, we will work on a poster design utilizing the common tools in InDesign.

Registration

Registration is required. Registration begins one week prior to the class starting at 9:00 a.m.

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you have a request for accommodation. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. Phone 416-393-7009 or email accessibilityservices@tpl.ca.
relatedlinktext: Click Here to Register for the Class

title: English Conversation Circle
description:
Are you learning English or new to Canada?

Practice your English conversation skills in a relaxing environment while making new friends and learning what the library has to offer!

Beginner and intermediate learners welcome. Please note that this is not a formal English class.

This is a drop-in program. For more information visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

title: Introduction to 3D Printing
description:
This class/lecture is DROP-IN.

Learn how 3D printers work and how you can print at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs. This class includes hands-on instruction with PrusaSlicer, the software used to prepare your 3D object file for printing on an Prusa MK3S printer.
Note: Customers are no longer required to attend a mandatory 3D printing class prior to using a 3D printer at the Toronto Public Librarys Digital Innovation Hubs.

This class is for those who are interested in learning more about 3D printing and how to use the PrusaSlicer software and understanding how to get started with our 3D printing service.


Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you have a request for accommodation. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. Phone 416-393-7009 or email accessibilityservices@tpl.ca.

title: Canadian Citizenship Education Mentoring Circle
description:
Join a 10-session mentoring program whose aim is to help newcomers learn more about Canada. All 10 sessions are facilitated by a CultureLink staff member and a team of trained citizenship education mentors. Mentors review and discuss the Discover Canada study guide in easy English in small group settings.

Please note: there is no session on October 9 (Thanksgiving, the library is closed).

To register call Hashem Rahin, Program Worker, CultureLink at 437-288-4915.

title: Monday Night at the Movies
description: Join us every Monday night for a movie! We will be showing some old favorites and newer releases.  This is a drop in program.  For more information call the Port Union Library:  416-396-8885.

title: Photo Editing with Adobe Photoshop
description:
Learn how to alter and retouch images using Adobe Photoshop CC, an industry standard software for PC & Mac. In this hands-on class, you will learn to work with basic tools to resize, crop, modify colour, filter and add text to an image using our MacBook laptops.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of computer skills -- basically, if you can use a word processor or surf the web you can learn Photoshop.

** Registration will start 2 weeks before this class. Computers will be provided. **

Please register using the link below.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Introduction to Serger Sewing
description:
Learn to use a Juki MO-735! In this class we will go over the basic operation and key functions of a serger sewing machine. Threading the machine and safety will be discussed. This course is mandatory in order to book the serger. Children under 13 must be accompanied by an adult.

Registration is required for this class and begins November 6, 2023 at 12:30pm.

Note: Your spot will not be guaranteed after 5 minutes of the start of the program. Class is held in the Fabrication Studio.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. title: Make A Will with the Ontario Bar Association
description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Jack Fallon, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you don't have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

No registration required.

If you live with a disability, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Club de lecture de Brentwood
description:
Aimez-vous lire en français ? Avez-vous envie de participer à des discussions autour des livres dans une ambiance détendue en toute convivialité ? Venez rejoindre le club de lecture pour échanger vos impressions, pour analyser, avec le regard d'autres lecteurs, ce qui vous a marqué, et pour faire de belles découvertes littéraires.

On se réunit le lundi 20 novembre pour découvrir La petite dernière de Fatima Daas.

Le livre sera disponible à la succursale de Brentwood à partir du 17 octobre.

Pour obtenir plus d'informations sur la disponibilité du livre pour la prochaine réunion à la succursale de Brentwood, composez 416-394-5240.

Si vous voulez en savoir plus sur nos clubs de lecture, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

title: Make A Will with the Ontario Bar Association
description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Nancy Burton-Vulovic, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you dont have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

November 20th - Northanger Abbey
January 15th - Persuasion
February 19th - Lady Susan
March 18th - The Watsons

description:

You will learn how to:
- create your MyAccesstoHousingTO client account
- manage your account
- apply for subsidized housing (or Rent-Geared-to-Income) listings.

Find out more or register at: https://reservation.frontdesksuite.ca/torontoprod/housing

Note: A valid email address, proof of status in Canada and most recent Notice of Assessment (NOA) are required to apply or register for subsidized housing or Rent Geared to Income (RGI) housing.

title: Word Basics 3: Basic Resumes with Word
description:
Practice your Microsoft Word 2019 skills while creating a simple resume.

In this class you will:

- Format a simple resume
- Practice advanced formatting using Ruler Tools and Format Painter
- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Words built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF

Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 & 2 or equivalent skills. Keyboarding and mouse skills are required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

description:
Beginning Tuesday, September 19th, join us weekly for a drop-in knitting and crochet circle! Bring your yarn, needles and crochet hooks and enjoy the company of other knitters and crocheters.

Drop-in. No registration required.

This program will be held downstairs at the Childrens Department.

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 24 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
October 31 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 7 - Elder Abuse
November 14 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 21 - Physical Health and Exercise During
November 28 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Register in person or call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

title: Together Time with MFRC
description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. Sand, water play, painting, cut and paste, markers, crayons, circle time, and free play are all part of this program. Children are free to rotate between activities throughout the room. Co-sponsored with Malvern Family Resource Centre (MFRC). DROP-IN PROGRAM.

title: Rent Geared to Income Subsidy - Navigating MyAccesstoHousingTO (MATHTO)
description:
Join us for an in-person workshop at Toronto Reference Library.

You will learn how to:
- create your MyAccesstoHousingTO client account
- manage your account
- apply for subsidized housing (or Rent-Geared-to-Income) listings.

Find out more or register at: https://reservation.frontdesksuite.ca/torontoprod/housing

Note: A valid email address, proof of status in Canada and most recent Notice of Assessment (NOA) are required to apply or register for subsidized housing or Rent Geared to Income (RGI) housing.

title: Get F.R.E.S.H. at the Library - Crafting a Community
description:
Take a moment out of your hectic week and unwind at the library with relaxing activities, and good conversation. Meet new folks, build connections, and tell us about programs and services you would like to see in the neighbourhood!

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's F.R.E.S.H. initiative.

Each Tuesday participants are welcome to put their crafting skills to use! All materials will be provided.

title: Toddler Food Basics
description:
Your toddler means the world to you. Nutrition and care means the world to them. Each of our Toddler Food Basics workshops share the skills and build the confidence you need, to make your own nutritious and healthy food. Learn about when and how to introduce new foods, food safety, and what equipment to use for making food from scratch.

This program is presented by FoodShare Toronto.

Register in-branch or by calling 416-393-7663.

In this fourth session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Computers for Beginners 1, 2 & 3 or basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills.

title: Invasive Plant Species To Avoid Growing- New date! Nov 21, 2023
description:
Oct 25th date has been cancelled!
Did you know that some common plants that are often readily available at your local garden center can negatively impact our natural environment and local ravines?
A Toronto Master Gardener will bring in examples of invasive species and discuss:
What it means to say a plant is invasive
Identification of some commonly available invasive plants
Alternative plants to consider that also enhance the ecosystem
Management and safe disposal of existing invasive species

Please register by calling Hillcrest Library at 416-395-5830

This in-person and in-branch program is part of Toronto Public Library's environmental program series, Our Fragile Planet, supported by the TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

description:

This panel is part of the Career Coaches in Residence Networking and Mentorship Series powered by RBC Future Launch.

title: History of Hip Hop, Part 1
description:
Join us for Part 1 of a series on the history of Hip Hop!

​Explore the roots and foundations of Hip-Hop history, tracing its origins in the 1970s amidst the socio-cultural landscape of the Bronx, New York. Uncover the transformative influence of African-American and Afro-Caribbean/ Latino Deejaying, musical traditions, street art, and block parties. Discover how Hip-Hop became a powerful platform for expression, activism, and community building. We will also explore the differences between Rap and Hip-Hop culture, and between Rappers and Emcees.

​Presented by marcus singleton, Ph.D.(c) at OISE and Hip-Hop Community connector for the U of T Hart House Hip-Hop Education program and the Director of Community and Youth Engagement for the Roots Rhymes Collective.

No registration required. For more information, please contact the Arts Department at 416-393-7157.

title: E.J. Koh: The Liberators
description:
E.J. Koh, the author of the multi-award winning memoir The Magical Language of Others, talks about her debut novel, The Liberators - an elegantly wrought family saga of memory, trauma, and empathy that begins at the height of the military dictatorship in South Korea and echoes for generations to come.

The couple at the center are Insuk and Sungho who are arranged to be married and move from South Korea to San Jose, California with an infant and Sungho's overbearing mother-in-law. Adrift in a new country, Insuk grieves the loss of her past and her divided homeland, finding herself drawn into an illicit relationship. Throughout the novel, E.J. draws exquisite portraits and testimony from guards, prisoners, perpetrators, and liberators that span continents and four generations of two Korean families forever changed by fateful past decisions made in love and war.

E.J. Koh talks with Toronto-based art and storytelling facilitator Erin Kang about The Liberators, a powerful and poetic account of a divided country and the impact of that division on the Korean diaspora.

About this event's guests:
E.J. Koh
Erin Kang

Read more:
The Liberators
The Magical Language of Others

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Asian Heritage series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

title: Audiobook Club
description:
Join us for a discussion of "The Vanishing Half" by Brit Bennett, audiobook performed by Shayna Small. The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern black community and running away at age sixteen, it's not just the shape of their daily lives that is different as adults, it's everything: their families, their communities, their racial identities. Many years later, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happen to the next generation, when their own daughters' storylines intersect?

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book discussion. For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

New members are welcome and no registration is required. This program is hosted virtually by TPL staff: Reagan Kapasi and Max Hare. For a reminder email or discussion slides in advance, please email rkapasi@tpl.ca.

For a full list of future Audiobook Club Titles, visit the link.

Tuesday December 19, 2023 BYOA (Bring Your Own Audiobook)

title: Radon: What You Need to Know
description:
Join Health Canada for a program that will dive into the possible health risks of radon, how radon gets into the home, how you can find out the level of radon in your home, and what to do if the amount is above the Canadian guideline.

What is radon? Radon is a soil gas that can be found in elevated levels in certain homes. Radon is the second-leading cause of lung cancer, surpassed only by smoking. It's important that everyone test their homes for radon, and take action to reduce their radon level if required.

Why November? November is Radon Action Month - a perfect time to start your home radon test! Health Canada suggests measuring radon for a minimum of three months' time, preferably during the heating season. This makes November the perfect time to order a radon test kit, and start measuring the level in your home.

This program will be available for replay at the same link after the program airs.

Read Crowdcast's Privacy Policy

See Crowdcast's Attendee Guide

Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Artist in the Library Program:  'I am Scarborough' with Artist Kseniya Tsoy
description:
'I am Scarborough' is a collaborative mural project that bridges art collage, photography, digital illustration and visual storytelling. The project intends to tell the story of Scarborough through telling personal stories of people and communities who live here.

Artist Kseniya Tsoy will guide participants through art and collage techniques and as a result everyone can walk away with an artful self-portrait. Everyone is invited to join in the fun of collaborative art making, and as this project is intended to be intergenerational - all ages and abilities are welcome!

Registration is required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at Albert Campbell Library.

description:

title: Dionne Irving: The Islands
description:
Join author Dionne Irving for a reading and conversation with Donna Bailey Nurse about Irving's Giller-nominated debut short story collection, The Islands, which follows the lives of Jamaican women, immigrants or the descendants of immigrants, who have relocated all over the world to escape the ghosts of colonialism on what they call the Island.

These are powerful stories that explore the legacy of colonialism and issues of race, immigration, sexual discrimination and class in the lives of Jamaican women from London, Panama, France, Florida and more.

The Islands has been shortlisted for this year's Giller Prize and was a finalist for the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, a New York Times Book Review Editor's Choice, and NPR Best Book of the Year.

This program is drop-in. No registration is required.

title: Futures Club: Trends - Futures of Work, Session 2
description:
Using the work done in the Horizon Scan sessions, we we will work together to develop insightful trends around the Futures of Work.

Note: Please feel free to join us in any or all of the Trends sessions even if you haven't participated in the Horizon Scanning sessions.

Futures Club series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

title: Club de lecture de la Bibliothèque de référence
description:
Aimez-vous lire en français ? Avez-vous envie de participer à des discussions autour des livres dans une ambiance détendue en toute convivialité ? Venez rejoindre le club de lecture pour échanger vos impressions, pour analyser, avec le regard d'autres lecteurs, ce qui vous a marqué, et pour faire de belles découvertes littéraires.

On se réunit le mercredi 22 novembre 2023 dans Discussion Room au 3e étage pour découvrir L'homme qui n'aimait plus les chats d'Isabelle Aupy.

Le livre sera disponible en prêt à la Bibliothèque de référence, Département des langues et littératures (4e étage) à partir du 19 octobre 2023.

Pour obtenir plus d'informations sur la disponibilité du livre pour la prochaine réunion à la Bibliothèque de référence, veuillez contacter le Département des langues et littératures en composant 416-393-7085.

Si vous voulez en savoir plus sur nos clubs de lecture, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

title: Generation of Lost Causes
description:
What's at stake when polarized generations allow media outlets to frame their understanding of the world?

As our global population faces increasing threats from climate change, political divisions and other existential crises, self-serving forces simultaneously distract from and escalate the problems.

Cory Doctorow, journalist, activist and author, and Vass Bednar, executive director of McMaster University's Master of Public Policy program, discuss generational divides, opposing viewpoints and the risk of media-induced polarization.

What's at stake when we allow profit-driven corporations to define our views? And how do we mitigate crises when we can't agree on what is true?

Join the conversation.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Due to the high demand for this event, free tickets will be available to book via Eventbrite two weeks in advance, beginning on November 8th at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:

Cory Doctorow
Vass Bednar

Read more:

The Lost Cause
Red Team Blues
Internet Con How to Seize the Means of Computation

***

This event is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened.

It is also part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7pm, but doors to the Toronto Reference Library and Appel Salon open at 6pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:

Join Pediatric Sleep Consultant Alana Metallo for a one-hour webinar, where you will learn:

- Benefits of sleep
- Impacts of sleep deprivation
- How much sleep is needed for your infant/toddler
- Top sleep tips that can be implemented into your home
- Q&A session at the end to answer your personal sleep questions.

This program is part of the Raising Confident Kids: Workshops for Parents Series.

title: Dementia Caregiving: Tips for Navigating the Health Care System
description:
A team of Baycrest@Home social workers will share resources and supports available within the healthcare system for people living with dementia and their care partners, and where to access them. This program will also include discussion on transitions in care including living at home, retirement home, and long-term care.

This program is part of the online program series Caregiver 101: The Fundamentals of Dementia Caregiving, developed by Baycrest@Home.
Whether you are a spouse, partner, adult child, family member, friend, or neighbour and find yourself thrust into the role of caregiving for someone living with dementia or memory changes - knowing what to do and how to plan can feel overwhelming. Caregiver 101 was developed to help you care with confidence, and specifically designed to equip family caregivers with the tools, knowledge and skills to become a care partner.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay for one week.

Register and receive a reminder, or tune in live on November 23

Read Crowdcast's Privacy Policy

See Crowdcast's Attendee Guide

Questions about online programs? Please email us at programproposals@tpl.ca

title: Make A Will with the Ontario Bar Association
description:
November is Make a Will Month. Learn about the importance of having a will and powers of attorney for you and your family. Lisa Laredo, a member of the Ontario Bar Association who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you don't have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

title: Dive into Documentaries - Manufactured Landscapes
description:
Twice a month, we present an engaging and thought-provoking documentary. We will explore the social, political and historical aspects of issues important to the state of our world today. Engage with complex social conditions, complicated events, and their consequences, while watching revealing documentaries from around the world at the Toronto Reference Library (with closed captions.)

With the large-scale photography of Ed Burtynsky, this film reveals the alarming scale of industrial projects that are changing the face of the planet.

Drop-in, no registration.

title: Grow Your Own Native Plants From Seeds - *Rescheduled*
description:
*Please note that this program was originally planned for October 28, 2-4 pm. The rescheduled session is on November 23, 6:30-8 pm. We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.*

Native plants have a long relationship with this land. Not only are they beautiful, they are also homes and food for other beings. Join Earthworker Joce Two Crows Tremblay and EnvIR Jenny Davis to learn everything you need to know to grow your own native plants from seed. You will learn what cold stratification means and why the fall is the best time to plant native plants. Come dressed to get dirty for this hands on workshop.

To register please visit Parliament Street Branch or call 416-393-7663.

This Environmentalist in Residence program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

Accessibility

title: Aging, Hearing Loss and Memory Loss: What You Can Do About It
description:
Both hearing and cognitive loss increase with age. Research shows strong
evidence of association between hearing loss and cognitive impairment. Older
adults with untreated hearing loss are more likely to develop dementia. Hearing
aid use may mediate cognitive decline through reduced social isolation and
depression or increased cognitive stimulation. Managing hearing loss can improve quality of life and reduce caregiver burden.

Presented by Akram Keymanesh, Doctor of Audiology at Hearing Help Canada.

Free. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Gardening in a Changing Climate
description:
***DATE CHANGED from Thursday September 14, 2023, to Thursday, November 23, 2023. Sorry for any inconvenience.***

Climate change is rapidly impacting natural spaces on both a local and global scale, including our yards. Join us for an introductory gardening webinar with a focus on climate change resiliency. We will introduce concepts like rainwater harvesting, native plant gardening, rain gardens, and permeable paving. Receive a free copy of the Greening Your Grounds Homeowner's Guide with detailed instructions on how to implement these projects at home!

Presented by the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA).

This in-person and in-branch program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

title: Digital Privacy 101
description:
This session introduces you to essential online privacy tools and concepts.

Pre-requisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills required.

In this class you will:
-Learn how to maintain your online privacy through good habits and through securing your accounts and devices.
-Develop a strong password, and review the best methods for storing your passwords.
-Learn about various online threats such as malware, phishing, and hacking.
-Gain an understanding of the limitations of these tools and habits. To register, please call 416-396-8890

description:
Learn how to alter and retouch images using Adobe Photoshop CC, an industry standard software for PC & Mac. In this hands-on class, you will learn to work with basic tools to resize, crop, modify colour, filter and add text to an image using our MacBook laptops.
This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of computer skills -- basically, if you can use a word processor or surf the web you can learn Photoshop.

Computers will be provided for this class.

description:

title: History of Hip Hop, Part 2
description:
Join us for Part 2 of a series on the history of Hip Hop!

​Explore the roots and foundations of Hip-Hop history, tracing its origins in the 1970s amidst the socio-cultural landscape of the Bronx, New York. Uncover the transformative influence of African-American and Afro-Caribbean/ Latino Deejaying, musical traditions, street art, and block parties. Discover how Hip-Hop became a powerful platform for expression, activism, and community building. We will also explore the differences between Rap and Hip-Hop culture, and between Rappers and Emcees.

​Presented by marcus singleton, Ph.D.(c) at OISE and Hip-Hop Community connector for the U of T Hart House Hip-Hop Education program and the Director of Community and Youth Engagement for the Roots Rhymes Collective.

No registration required. For more information, please contact the Arts Department at 416-393-7157.

title: Estate Planning
description: Understand the what and why of Estate Planning. Michelle Connolly, a member of CPA Canada, will discuss the various tools of Estate Planning. Learn more about various aspects of estate planning like powers of attorney, wills, trust, and more.

title: Using Technology and Media to Educate on the Legacy of Residential Schools
description:
This panel discussion will feature on conversations about how media and technology can be used to educate Canadians on the legacy of residential schools. Using the Weengushk Film Institute and 360 Storylab collaboration, Residential School Survivors: Honouring the Memory, as an example, the panelists will explore how these projects can spark conversation and encourage viewers to seek further information and educate themselves. Hosted by Andre Morriseau, panelists include Shaun Vincent and Jeff Preyra.


Register and receive a reminder, or watch live via Crowdcast on November 23.

This program will be recorded and available for replay at this same link for a period of six months.

Read Crowdcast's Privacy Policy

Questions about online programs? Please email us at programproposals@tpl.ca

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

Andre Morriseau is a member of Fort William First Nation (Ojibway) and is the Communications Manager for the Ontario Native Womens Association. Andre has served on numerous boards of directors including the Ontario Arts Council (OAC), ImagineNATIVE Film and Media Arts Festival, and is currently serving as a Director on the Anishnawbe Health Foundation board. Mr. Morriseau is also a former host of Nation to Nation on the former Aboriginal Voices Radio network, CKAV 106.5 FM, and UrbaNative at CIUT, University of Toronto.

Shaun Vincent (Métis) is an artist, graphic designer and entrepreneur. He is the founder and creative director of Vincent Design and has designed hundreds of logos, specializing in those that require a deep understanding and sensitivity to the people and stories they represent. Shaun also serves on the board of Building Urban Industries for Local Development, or BUILD, a social enterprise non-profit contractor and a training program for people who face barriers to employment.

Jeff Preyra is the founder and CEO of 360 Story Lab and an innovator in Mixed Reality, Film and Television.He has been in the storytelling business for more than 25 years. His work has appeared on broadcast and interactive platforms in dozens of languages around the world. Jeff was a co-founder and creative partner in the company that produced the international megahit shows Arresting Design, Style by Jury and Brides of Beverly Hills.

Content Warning: This program features information about residential schools. The National Indian Residential School Crisis Line (1-866-925-4419) is available 24/7 for survivors and their families who are experiencing pain as a result their experience in Residential Schools.

title: Searching For Franklin with Ken McGoogan
description:
Please join author Ken McGoogan as he discusses his new book, Searching For Franklin, New Answers to the Great Arctic Mystery. Arctic historian Ken McGoogan approaches the legacy of nineteenth- century explorer Sir John Franklin from a contemporary perspective and offers a surprising new explanation of an enduring Northern mystery.

Ken McGoogan is an award-winning and best-selling Canadian author who travels the world researching for his writing. He has published numerous fiction and non-fiction books, including several Arctic histories. His best-selling books include Dead Reckoning (Patrick Crean Editions, 2017), Fatal Passage, 50 Canadians Who Changed the World and Lady Franklin's Revenge (Phyllis Bruce Books: 2001, 2013 and 2005. McGoogan has appeared in several documentaries to discuss Arctic exploration and is a fellow of the Explorers' Club and the Royal Canadian Geographical Society. McGoogan was born in Montréal and now lives in Guelph, ON. Copies of the book will be available for purchase.

Drop-in only. No registration required.

title: Sanderson Book Club
description:
Please join us as we explore a range of Canadian experiences through books. Canadian authors provide a unique view through their fiction and non-fiction. We see the diverse impact that culture, age, world events and life experiences can have on our country and communities. Our personal experiences expand and enliven our discussions.
All are welcome. Registration not required.

Upcoming book titles are:


September 21: Fayne: a novel by Ann-Marie MacDonald
October 19: Talking to Canadians: a memoir by Rick Mercer
November 23: The Beautiful Mystery ( a Chief Inspector Gamache Novel) by Louise Penny

title: The Billionaire Murders: The Mysterious Deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman
description:
​Toronto Star investigative journalist Kevin Donovan chronicles the unsettling story of the infamous Barry and Honey Sherman murder case which occurred in Toronto in 2017 from the beginning, drawing on interviews with family members, friends, and colleagues. Donovan sheds new light on the Shermans' lives and the disturbing double murder while discussing his best-selling book, The Billionaire Murders: The Mysterious Deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman.

A presentation of the Society and Recreation department of the North York Central Library. No registration required.

title: Play Reading with Makram Ayache
description:
Makram Ayache is a multiple award winning playwright, performer, director, and educator living between Alberta and Toronto. His playwriting explores representations of queer Arab voices and aims to bridge political struggles to the intimate experiences of the people impacted by them.

Makram will be reading part of his new play "Small Gods (at the Start of the World)" which will have its premiere in Toronto next fall, followed by a Q&A session with the audience.

Presented in partnership with the Playwrights Guild of Canada.

Space is limited so registration is required.

For more information please contact the Toronto Reference Library Arts department at trlarts@tpl.ca or 416-393-7157.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: Episode 4 of 5: AI, so what!? : AI as an Artist
description:
A 5-part virtual series will examine how AI development is moving toward the creation of a separate species beyond human comprehension. Whether you are one of the ambivalent or one of concerned, this series will make you ponder everything from how you live, work & play all while discovering how AI is literally changing everything.

At the start of each episode, we will travel 100 years into the future to observe what happens when full on AI consciousness exists. We will imagine how society has adapted to AI and how most surviving humans see AI as nothing special or new. Each topic will look at current AI developments including generative AI (e.g., ChatGPT) and general Artificial Intelligence. More importantly, episodes will address the importance of making necessary changes.

This is a 5-part virtual series hosted by Keith McDonald. Founder and Chief Curator of Toronto's the "literacy AI project". The series is intended for those who are curious about AI but have not had the time to investigate the nuances and developments that are taking place every day.

Separate registration is required for each session. Please click on the link below to start the registration process.

Episode 4:
AIso what!? : AI as an Artist
(film, music, art & literature)
November 23rd, 2023
7:00 PM - 8:00PM

Episode 5: (Please click on the link below to register for episode 5)
AIso what!?: AI as a hobbyist
(recreation, hobbies & downtime pursuits)
December 7th, 2023
7:00 PM - 8:00PM

description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 20 - Financial Freedom in Retirement (CANCELLED)
October 27 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
November 3 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 10 - Elder Abuse
November 17 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 24 - Physical Health and Exercise
December 1 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Registration is required for each session. Register in person or call Centennial Library at (416) 395-5490.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

October 6
Cubas Wild Revolution
Cuba is home to some of the most unusual creatures in the world. From the tiniest bird, the bee hummingbird to the smallest frog, jumping crocodiles and thousands of migrating crabs. The island has remained untouched until recently when the pressure to develop has increased. Will Cuba be able to save its wildlife? Closed Captions.55 minutes. 2020

October 13
Planet Food: Malaysia
Travel the country of Malaysia and discover just how multicultural it is by exploring their rich variety of foods. Whether you like spicy Laksa soup, mackerel curry or food cooked in a blowpipe, the adventure is delicious.
50 minutes. 2011

October 20
Worlds Greatest Engineering Icons: Civic Buildings
Throughout history, people have strived to make monumental buildings that communicate power, wealth and great architectural accomplishments. This film showcases many of these extraordinary achievements highlighting structures places such as Red Square, Petra, the United States Capital and the pyramids among others. Closed captions. 55 minutes. 2021

October 27
Cameroon
Explore Cameroon in western Africa. Join an adventurer as he struggles to climb Mount Cameroon, meet a pygmy tribe and take part in some of their celebrations, meet a chief with 50 wives and track lions in Waza National Park. Closed captions. 59 minutes.2020

November 3
The Green Planet: Tropical Worlds
Sir David Attenborough takes a plants-eye view of life in a rainforest, a world of stunning beauty but also fierce competition. From fast-growing trees to flowers that mimic dead animals, this is a journey into a magical world that operates on a different timescale to our own. Closed Captions. 50 minutes. 2022.

November 10
Secrets of the Sky Tombs
The Himalayas are among the most difficult places to live. Who were the people who chose to live at impossibly high altitudes surrounded by sheer cliffs. What strange rituals did they have that required gold masks and Chinese silk to ward off the spirits of the dead? 60 minutes. Closed Captions, 2017

November 17
Edible Insects
From crunchy crickets to nutty fly grubs, NOVA takes a tasty look at using insects as food and gives us insight into how they benefit us. Besides building larger and therefore smarter brains, insect protein actually makes us healthier and even helps to protect the environment by reducing meat consumption Closed Captions. 55 minutes .2021.

November 24
Worlds Greatest Natural Icons: Fire
Fire has created some of our most memorable and beautiful icons as well as destroyed some of our most valuable places. This film captures many of the worlds most magnificent volcanoes such as those in Hawaii and Japan as well as bubbling hot springs and mud baths in Iceland. However, it also shows us the dark side of fire especially land that has been laid to waste.2021

December 1
The Story of Cats: Asia to Africa
Discover how the first cats began in the forests of Asia and how they spread across the continent, eventually conquering Africa. How did they evolve from lions and tigers to house cats? What special adaptations do they need to survive in so many different environments? Closed Captions. 60 minutes. 2017

December 8
Can we make Life?
Science fiction movies show scientists bringing ancient creatures back to life. Is this a possibility? Can science really use DNA to resurrect extinct animals? Furthermore, can genetic biology improve our lives by eradicating disease? Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2018.

December 15
Canada: Surviving the North
Behold some of the world's most astonishing wildlife, and see how they live, from Canada's high arctic and tundra to the boreal forest. Each animal has innate abilities that allow it to hunt and survive in all seasons. These capabilities range from astounding hearing, to incredible speed and to patient silent stalking.
Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2022

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

January 12
Engineering Our World
This inspiring film follows engineers who have devoted their lives to seemingly impossible challenges and against all odds have made them happen. It is a story about human ingenuity and innovation. Closed Captions.45 minutes..2017.

January 19
The Megafalls of Iguaca
Follow the lives of animals that live in the Iguacu National Park, near the largest waterfalls on earth. This Atlantic rainforest houses swifts, who fly through the massive quantities of falling water, as well as spotted jaguars and a family of coatis. The film also shows the park rangers who battle to keep the reserve from destruction. Closed Captions.60 minutes. 2016.

January 26
Age of Stars
The sun is the source of our light, heat and energy. This film explores the birth of stars like our sun as well as their exit as exploding supernova .Billions of years from now our sun will die and will usher in the age of darkness. Closed Captions.55 minutes.2021.

February 2
Wild Metropolis: Residents
As cities grow larger, many residents have been pushed out of their homes in the wild and are adapting to their new urban habitat.in the city. From pythons in Bangkok to otters in Singapore, many animals learn adjust to these unlikely conditions. Closed Captions. 55 minutes.2019


February 9
Destination Northern Australia: Queensland
Enjoy a trip to Queensland in Northern Australia with the magnificent sunny beaches that draw surfers from all over, the oldest tropical forest in the world and the Great Barrier Reef.
60 minutes. 2002


February 16
Dynasties: Chimpanzees
David, the alpha male chimpanzee in his troupe in Senegal, tries to overcome threats to his leadership by younger males and by doing so ensure an heir. His determination to hang on to his position in the light of drought conditions and other difficulties is moving. Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2019


February 23
Secrets of Lost Empires 2: Roman Baths
Ancient Roman baths were used not only to stay clean but to socialize. However, the technology behind the baths was lost more than 2,000 years ago. What did the Romans do when there was no soap and how did they remain fashionable with hairless bodies? How did the Romans manage to pipe enough water for the community and control the temperature? Using ruins as a guide, scientists set out to recreate a Roman bath as the Romans did. 53 minutes.2008

March 1
Natures Great Race: Zebras
Follow Africas longest migration as scientists track thousands of zebras through the Botswana wilderness on their way to the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. It is a harrowing journey as the animals and their young face starvation, wild dogs , lions and drought. Closed Captions. 54 minutes.2017


March 8
Alien Solar Systems
Is our solar system unique? How was our solar system created? Since the first discovery of a planet orbiting another star, some 280 alien solar systems have been identified. It's only by looking at solar systems far beyond our own, that we can understand how remarkable our universe is.
Closed captions. 48 minutes. 2011


March 15
India: Natures Wonderland
Our guide starts in the Gir Forest, home to the worlds last Asiatic lions, tracks elephants as they travel an old path through a tea plantation, and observes gibbons that begin each morning by singing. This is an unusual view of Indias rarely seen natural world. Closed Captions. 60 minutes.2016


March 22
Royal Myths & Secrets 11: George IV and the Regency
Lucy Worsley reveals how mental health problems forced King George to relinquish power to his debauched and extravagant son. Was this really an era of extravagance and regal splendour or was it a darker time of concealed revolution? Closed captions. 53 minutes.2020

title: Digital Life Skills: Online Shopping
description:
For people who have basic internet skills, and want to learn how to shop online with confidence. Whether you need groceries or home appliances, almost anything can be purchased and delivered to your home. We teach you how to find goods and services online, look for customer reviews or consumer testing results and provide tips and guidelines on how to shop safely, securely and with confidence. This class will be delivered in a lecture format.

Registration required. Registration for November classes begins Monday, October 23, 2023 at 9 a.m.

Please register in-person at the first floor reference desk or by calling 416-395-5672.

November 17: Computers for Beginners 3 - Use the Web
November 24: Computers for Beginners 4 - Use Google Search and Maps

title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

title: Computers for Beginners 4:  Use Google Search and Maps
description:
A class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fourth session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.
- Compare several search engines

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Computers for Beginners 1, 2 & 3 or basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

title: Get Hooked On Responsible Fishing
description:
Join Archer Pechawis, member of Mistawasis Nehiyawak, Saskatchewan, to learn how fishing has sustained people on these lands since time immemorial and continues to be an important practice. But with fewer wetlands and more people sport fishing, the animals who call water home are being impacted by hooks and fishing line. Mariah and Nicole from Rouge National Urban Park will explore the impacts of irresponsible fishing on marsh birds and turtles and what is being done in response to ensure human wildlife co-existence. There will also be representatives from City of Toronto Animal Services, Evergreen Brickworks and Turtle Protectors present to respond to your fishing related questions and a special guest appearance from Randy, a three-toed box turtle.

Whether you are a new or experienced fisher person or a concerned community member, you will leave this program knowing how your hook and sinker choice matters and what to do if you accidentally hook a marsh bird or turtle.

To register please visit Parliament Street Branch or call 416-393-7663.

This Environmentalist in Residence program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

Photo credit: Toronto Wildlife Centre

Bo Louie Siu, MDes: Future Well-Being of Transgender People in the Workplace

Inclusive Futures Series:
Embark on an illuminating journey with the Toronto Public Library's Inclusive Futures series, as we venture beyond the boundaries of conventional narratives to delve into futures often overshadowed. Guided by a commitment to authenticity, our series goes beyond what's easy or comfortable, inviting you to envision bold, transformative paths. Join us in challenging norms, igniting conversations, and shaping a tapestry of inclusive, vibrant, and interconnected tomorrows.

title: Travel Talk:  Islands of Greece
description:
Greece has thousands of islands of which 227 are inhabited. While some are busier and larger than others, they all offer great scenery, history, architecture and friendly people that enchanted tourists in unique ways. In September 2022, experienced travel talk presenter Chris Myers revisited Rhodes, Santorini, Milos, Paros and Naxos, 18 years after his first trip in 1994. His presentation include photos, texts, narrations, and all the changes on the five islands he discovered in a span of almost two decades.

This program is designed for adults. Drop in. No registration is required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: SOUNDBOX: A SONIC PLAYGROUND FOR ALL
description:
Artists Braeden Doane and Sabrina Brathwaite will create a weekly interactive exhibit for all ages in the Downsview Branch. Each week the exhibit will offer a buffet of tools and activities that encourage community members to play and connect through multisensory explorations of sound and listening.

Amplification Station - Like holding a magnifying to a leaf, members will be able to listen to various objects through a microphone to more closely examine sonic textures and visual properties


Cassette Station - A weekly curation of cassette tapes for members to listen on cassette players while at the library


Haptic Station - Examining a catalogue of collected field recordings from the Downsview Library and surrounding neighborhood through equipment that translates these sounds

- Practice advanced formatting using Ruler Tools and Format Painter
- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Words built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF

Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

Keyboarding and mouse skills are required. Laptops will be provided.

Space is limited. Please register in person at Leaside branch or by calling 416-396-3835.

- Animate objects.
- Edit a theme.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 and 2 or equivalent experience. Keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Happy Place is a glimpse into lives filled with courage, compassion and startling surprise, lives which  in many ways  are not so different from our own.

-Learn about various online threats such as malware, phishing, and hacking.
-Gain an understanding of the limitations of these tools and habits.

No registration is required. Everyone is welcome.

This event is a tie-in with Handmade Humanoids: A Merril Collection Exhibit, located upstairs on the third floor in the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy. You can view the exhibit during the Merril Collection's open hours: Monday-Friday 10am-6pm, Saturday 9am-5pm, closed on Sunday.

title: Is Vaping Safe, or is It Just Bait and Switch from Big Tobacco?
description:
Nicotine is a more addictive drug than either alcohol or cannabis and has caused more health problems and deaths. Can vaping help smokers stop smoking or will its appeal to youth increase the number of cigarette smokers?

Retired Forensic Toxicologist and author James Wigmore presents a brief history of tobacco and nicotine from the evolution of smoking from pipes, cigars and chewing tobacco to the highly designed and addictive cigarettes. He will examine how vaping has been promoted as a safe alternative to smoking, but also has health risks.

Registration is strongly encouraged. Tickets are available via Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. title: Who Is Watching Big Tech?
description:
What's at stake when corporations dictate the information we see and don't see? Like never before, our access to information has been radically altered and put into the hands of a small group of powerful companies that claim to have our best interests at heart. But the reality is our views can often be shaped by those same corporations, without us even realizing we're being manipulated.

Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen talks with journalist, activist and author Cory Doctorow about standing up against one of today's most powerful organizations and the power of a single individual to demand transparency and accountability to Big Tech. In 2021, Haugen publicly disclosed her identity as the anonymous Wall Street Journal source in an investigative series, "The Facebook Files: A Wall Street Journal Investigation." The investigation included the social media platform's negative impact on youth, misinformation, weaknesses in its response to human trafficking and drug cartels, and revealed how Facebook's algorithm favoured anger and outrage to keep us doom scrolling.

What's at stake when social media giants continue their unchecked growth in power and information access? What are the impacts of technology on our society? And how can we maintain our individual voices when faced with an unrelenting tsunami of corporate power?

Join the conversation.

Question and answer session and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on November 13 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:

Frances Haugen
Cory Doctorow

Read: The Power of One: How I Found the Strength to Tell the Truth and Why I Blew the Whistle on Facebook

***

This event is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

This program is presented by Jamie Michaels, TPL's Fall Writer in Residence whose focus is Graphic Novels. Learn more about TPL's Writer in Residence program, including upcoming programs and one-on-one consultation sessions.

title: Discovering African-Canadian History through the Anderson Ruffin Abbott Archive
description:
oronto Public Library's Anderson Ruffin Abbott fonds, an archive of papers belonging to the first Canadian-born person of colour to be licensed as a physician, were recently added to UNESCO's Memory of the World Register. In celebration of this milestone, Historian Kathy Grant will discuss how African-Canadian History can be explored through this collection and other library resources. Come prepared to learn something new about a fascinating topic.

Presented by the Special Collections Department

title: Computers for Beginners 6: Use Gmail
description:
Learn to use Gmail, Googles free web-based email service.

In this sixth session you will:

- Practice basic email functions: send, read, reply, forward, delete email, and attach files
- Review how spam and junk mail work

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to use email.
Instructions on how to set up and manage your own free Gmail account are included in the handout.

Pre-requisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Please call 416-396-8970 to register. Space is limited. Registration begins on October 27th.
