title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 24 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
October 31 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 7 - Elder Abuse
November 14 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 21 - Physical Health and Exercise During
November 28 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Register in person or call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

**Must attend both Part 1 and 2
Learn to create a design on Cricut Design Space in Part 1. Then learn to transfer your design onto a t-shirt using a heat press in Part 2. Part 1 is held at the same time on Tuesday, November 21.

Note: A medium size black t-shirt will be provided. You may bring one cotton shirt or sweater instead.

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 4. Les méthodes : la note d'intention
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions d'esthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Cet atelier plonge dans la méthode qui précède la réalisation : l'écriture d'un film documentaire. En s'appuyant sur des dossiers existants, les intentions des cinéastes se précisent, et aident à distinguer ses propres intentions derrière ses désirs de film.

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 7 novembre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

description:

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: Mimico Book Club
description: Our November book is Nightmare Alley by William Lindsay Gresham, a noir classic written in 1946. Nightmare Alley begins with an extraordinary description of a carnival show geek going about his work at a county fair. Young Stan Carlisle is working as a carny, and he wonders how a man could fall so low. There's no way in hell, he vows, that anything like that will ever happen to him...Nightmare Alley has been filmed twice, first in 1947 with Tyrone Power, and most recently in 2021 by Guillermo del Toro and starring Bradley Cooper & Cate Blanchett. Copies are available at the branch, and it's also available as an eBook and eAudiobook

description: When a college professor in the remote mountains of the American West confronts two hunters she catches trespassing on her property, she's drawn into an escalating battle of wills with catastrophic consequences.

title: Banking on Yourself Whether You Are Single or Not

More people are finding themselves single either by choice or circumstance. Thus, it pays to plan and be prepared financially to be solo leading up to and including your senior years and retirement. description:

description:
​Careers in underground music and nightlife are very hard to navigate coming from a regular music environment. The industry is constantly changing. Learn how to bring these pathways together: where to work, what kind of programs to take, how to create opportunities, what organizations to align with and how to navigate the spaces at home and abroad.

title: Short Book Club
description:
Are you interested in joining a book club but are short on time? Join the Short Book Club, focusing on books that are 250 pages or less. We meet the last Wednesday of each month.

In November we will be discussing The Relatives by Camilla Gibb. Copies of the book are available for pickup in the branch or as an eBook or eAudiobook through Libby. There is also a DAISY Talking Book available.

Summary: "Lila is on a long, painful journey toward motherhood. Tess and Emily are reeling after their ugly separation and fighting over ownership of the embryos that were supposed to grow their family together. And thousands of miles away, the unknown man who served as anonymous donor to them all is being held in captivity in Somalia. While his life remains in precarious balance, his genetic material is a source of both creation and conflict. What does it mean to be a family in our rapidly shifting world? What are our responsibilities to each other with increasing options for how to create a family? As these characters grapple with life-altering changes, they will find themselves interconnected in ways they cannot have imagined, and forced to redefine what family means to them."


Future selections:
November 29: The Relatives by Camilla Gibb
December 27: The Refugees by Viet Thanh Nguyen

This is a drop-in program.
For more information, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

description:

In Part 4, you'll learn what benefits you might be eligible for if you've resided in Canada for fewer than 40 years between the ages of 18 and 65, or if you're planning on emigrating from Canada after retiring.

description:

Amanda Smyth, a member of the Ontario Bar Association, who practices Trusts and Estate Law will speak about the elements of a will, what happens if you dont have one, what are powers of attorney, why they are important and special considerations to keep in mind when preparing your estate and care plans.

title: Culture and Technology Book Club: If then
description:
The Culture and Technology Book club brings readers together once a month to discuss new and classic books that raise important questions about the way technology transforms our cultural and political lives. The group will read on relevant topics related to social-media, innovation, surveillance and infrastructure.

This month:

We look at New Yorker staff writer Jill Lepore's book on the Simulmatics Corporation, founded in 1959, which can be considered an early example of data mining and targeted advertising. Lepore argues that Simulmatics built the machine which now traps our world.

Register here

Ce programme est une combinaison de cercle de conversation en français et de club de cinéma. Chaque mois, les participants et participantes discuteront, en français, d'un film de langue française. Les participants et participantes doivent regarder le film avant la réunion. Nous ne regarderons pas le film à la bibliothèque.

C'est une excellente occasion de pratiquer votre français et d'explorer le cinéma francophone du monde entier. Les participants peuvent choisir de regarder les films avec ou sans sous-titrage. Tous les niveaux sont les bienvenus !

Tous les films sélectionnés sont disponibles sur les services de diffusion en continu proposés par la TPL, tels que Kanopy et Hoopla, qui sont gratuits avec votre carte de bibliothèque. La plupart des films sélectionnés sont également disponibles sur DVD à la bibliothèque.

///

Our November film is BAMAKO. Available on Hoopla and on DVD.

This program is a combination of conversation circle and movie club. Each month participants will discuss a French language movie; the conversation will be in French. Similar to a book club, participants will watch the movie before the meeting. We will not be watching the film at the library.

This is a great opportunity to practice your French and explore French language cinema from around the world. Participants can choose to watch the films with or without subtitles. All levels are welcome!

All selected movies are available on the streaming services offered by TPL, such as Kanopy and Hoopla, which are free with your library card. Most movie selections area also available on DVD from the library.

title: Futures Club: Trends - Futures of Work, Session 3
description:
Using the work done in the Horizon Scan sessions, we we will work together to develop insightful trends around the Futures of Work.

Note: Please feel free to join us in any or all of the Trends sessions even if you haven't participated in the Horizon Scanning sessions.

Futures Club Series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

title: Growing up in a North Toronto Chinese Laundry
description:
Harvey Low grew up in North Toronto, and went to John Fisher PS, Glenview, and North Toronto Collegiate. His family has been in the community since the 1920s, and in Toronto since the 1890s. His
grandfather opened his laundry at 2616 Yonge Street in 1923.
Harvey will share family slides, and his memories of growing up in
a Chinese Laundry, to show the challenges of balancing life
between old and new customs.

Sponsored by The Toronto Public Library and The North Toronto Historical Society.

title: Being Prime Minister: Behind the Scenes with Canada's Leaders
description:

The talk provides humorous anecdotes and other insights into Canada's leaders --everyone from Sir John A. Macdonald to Justin Trudeau-- examining them through the prisms of travels, family, pets, sports, privacy, celebrity and dealing with the demands of the job.

title: Dementia Caregiving: Caring and Coping with Ambiguous Loss
description:
Join a team of Baycrest@Home social workers to learn about how to cope with the common emotional challenges that arise when supporting a person living with dementia. This program will discuss grief, loss and the skills and supports that can help you along the caregiving journey.

This program is part of the online program series Caregiver 101: The Fundamentals of Dementia Caregiving, developed by Baycrest@Home.
Whether you are a spouse, partner, adult child, family member, friend, or neighbour and find yourself thrust into the role of caregiving for someone living with dementia or memory changes - knowing what to do and how to plan can feel overwhelming. Caregiver 101 was developed to help you care with confidence, and specifically designed to equip family caregivers with the tools, knowledge and skills to become a care partner.

This 1-hour program will be recorded and available for replay for one week.

Register and receive a reminder, or tune in live on November 30

Read Crowdcast's Privacy Policy

title: Stories We Retell: Myth & Legend in Three Novels
description:
Authors Kate Heartfield, S. L. Huang, and Phoenicia Rogerson join us to discuss their new novels, retelling classic Norse, Chinese, and Greco-Roman tales.

Kate Heartfield's The Valkyrie is a lyrical retelling of one of Norse mythology's greatest epics, introducing us to Brynhild, a Valkyrie in exile; Gudrun, a princess of Burgundy and prize for an invading king; and Sigurd, a warrior with a sword sharper than the new moon. As the legends tell, these names are destined to be rivals, fated as enemies. But in the world of Midgard, legends can be lies.

Inspired by a classic of martial arts literature, S. L. Huang's The Water Outlaws are bandits of devastating ruthlessness, unseemly femininity, dangerous philosophies, and ungovernable gender who are ready to make history - or tear it apart. Disgraced and on the run, Lin Chong is recruited by the Bandits of Liangshan, mountain outlaws on the margins of society who proclaim a belief in justice - for women, for the downtrodden, for progressive thinkers a corrupt Empire would imprison or destroy.

Phoenicia Rogerson's Herc is a queer, revisionist retelling of the myth of Hercules which gives voice to silenced characters. Told with humor and heart, this is not the story of Hercules, but the story of everyone else - his friends, his enemies, his wives, his children, his lovers, his rivals, his gods, and his victim.

Kate Heartfield, S. L. Huang, and Phoenicia Rogerson speak with journalist Tabassum Siddiqui about their new novels and what it means to reconsider, reimagine, and retell some of history's most beloved myths and legends.

About this event's guests:
Kate Heartfield
S. L. Huang
Phoenicia Rogerson
Tabassum Siddiqui

Read more:
The Valkyrie
The Water Outlaws
Herc
The Embroidered Book
Critical Point

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

title: Protecting Your Family Treasures
description:
​A lot of us have items like books, old photos, letters, and other documents that are connected to our families. Some of these items might be really old and delicate. Together these things are personal items, but also make up a big part of our shared cultural history. To make sure they last for the people who come after us, it's important to take special care of them. Conservator Andrew Huot will discuss ways to save, protect, and store these meaningful items.

Registration required. Register by calling the branch at 416-396-8920 or visit in branch.

title: Driven to Succeed - Why Not Me?
description:
​There are many children, especially those who are marginalized, that grow-up believing that certain life opportunities are not meant for them. This is usually the case due to the lack of representation and positive role models. Steve Anderson captures his personal story and shares his challenges and triumphs in his books, Driven to Succeed and Why Not Me? which inspire and encourage each child to believe that no career option is off limits if they work hard and surround themselves with the right people.

Steve Anderson grew up in Toronto's Jane and Finch community. He become the first Black lawyer hired by the Toronto Transit Commission and then was elected as the first Black Deputy Mayor for the Town of Shelburne and County of Dufferin.

title: The Last Waltz-SR Documentary Film Series
description:
Join the Society and Recreation department of the North York Central Library in Rm. 101 for monthly screenings of films that push the limits of non-fiction filmmaking. This month's movie is Martin Scorsese's The Last Waltz (1978).

Synopsis (The Criterion Collection): More than just one of the greatest concert films ever made, The Last Waltz is an at once ecstatic and elegiac summation of a vital era in American rock music. Invited to capture the farewell performance of the legendary group the Band at San Francisco's Winterland Ballroom on Thanksgiving, 1976, Martin Scorsese conceived a new kind of music documentary. Enlisting seven camera operators (led by director of photography Michael Chapman, and also including renowned cinematographers Vilmos Zsigmond and László Kovács) and production designer Boris Leven to design the strikingly theatrical sets, Scorsese created a grandly immersive experience that brings viewers onstage and inside the music itself. That music-as performed by the Band and a host of other generation-defining artists, including Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Van Morrison, the Staple Singers, Muddy Waters, and Neil Young-lives on as an almost religious expression of the transcendent possibilities of rock and roll.

Optional registration here: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/the-last-waltz-sr-documentary-screening-series-tickets-742303207877?aff=oddtdtcreator

title: Afroveganism: A Plant-based Lifestyle for Black People
description:
Afro-veganism is a reclamation of the plant-based lifestyle of pre-enslaved Africans. Because of the overwhelming prevalence of chronic diseases in Black communities, Afro-veganism is a critically conscientious focus on Black people's nutritional health and welfare.

Joe G Thomas of Black Vegans of Toronto , provides a brief historical review of the nutrient-poor diet of enslaved Africans and their creative efforts to make the food they were given palatable. It will link the devastating effects of the present-day consumption of traditional foods to the disproportionately high incidences of chronic diseases and comorbidities in Black communities.

Registration
No registration required, but encouraged. You can register for the event on EventBrite

description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors residing in Toronto with the information they require to age well. Over the course of the 6-week program participants will engage in workshops that will provide information and tools related to the following 6 topics: financial freedom in retirement, mental health and cognition, physical health and exercise, frauds and scams against seniors, elder abuse, and aging in place and other options.

Program Dates and Topics

October 20 - Financial Freedom in Retirement (CANCELLED)
October 27 - Financial Freedom in Retirement
November 3 - Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
November 10 - Elder Abuse
November 17 - Mental Health and Cognition
November 24 - Physical Health and Exercise
December 1 - Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Registration is required for each session. Register in person or call Centennial Library at (416) 395-5490.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

October 6
Cubas Wild Revolution
Cuba is home to some of the most unusual creatures in the world. From the tiniest bird, the bee hummingbird to the smallest frog, jumping crocodiles and thousands of migrating crabs. The island has remained untouched until recently when the pressure to develop has increased. Will Cuba be able to save its wildlife? Closed Captions.55 minutes. 2020

October 13
Planet Food: Malaysia
Travel the country of Malaysia and discover just how multicultural it is by exploring their rich variety of foods. Whether you like spicy Laksa soup, mackerel curry or food cooked in a blowpipe, the adventure is delicious.
50 minutes. 2011

October 20
Worlds Greatest Engineering Icons: Civic Buildings
Throughout history, people have strived to make monumental buildings that communicate power, wealth and great architectural accomplishments. This film showcases many of these extraordinary achievements highlighting structures places such as Red Square, Petra, the United States Capital and the pyramids among others. Closed captions. 55 minutes. 2021

October 27
Cameroon
Explore Cameroon in western Africa. Join an adventurer as he struggles to climb Mount Cameroon, meet a pygmy tribe and take part in some of their celebrations, meet a chief with 50 wives and track lions in Waza National Park. Closed captions. 59 minutes.2020

November 3
The Green Planet: Tropical Worlds
Sir David Attenborough takes a plants-eye view of life in a rainforest, a world of stunning beauty but also fierce competition. From fast-growing trees to flowers that mimic dead animals, this is a journey into a magical world that operates on a different timescale to our own. Closed Captions. 50 minutes. 2022.

November 10
Secrets of the Sky Tombs
The Himalayas are among the most difficult places to live. Who were the people who chose to live at impossibly high altitudes surrounded by sheer cliffs. What strange rituals did they have that required gold masks and Chinese silk to ward off the spirits of the dead? 60 minutes. Closed Captions, 2017

November 17
Edible Insects
From crunchy crickets to nutty fly grubs, NOVA takes a tasty look at using insects as food and gives us insight into how they benefit us. Besides building larger and therefore smarter brains, insect protein actually makes us healthier and even helps to protect the environment by reducing meat consumption Closed Captions. 55 minutes .2021.

November 24
Worlds Greatest Natural Icons: Fire
Fire has created some of our most memorable and beautiful icons as well as destroyed some of our most valuable places. This film captures many of the worlds most magnificent volcanoes such as those in Hawaii and Japan as well as bubbling hot springs and mud baths in Iceland. However, it also shows us the dark side of fire especially land that has been laid to waste.2021

December 1
The Story of Cats: Asia to Africa
Discover how the first cats began in the forests of Asia and how they spread across the continent, eventually conquering Africa. How did they evolve from lions and tigers to house cats? What special adaptations do they need to survive in so many different environments? Closed Captions. 60 minutes. 2017

December 8
Can we make Life?
Science fiction movies show scientists bringing ancient creatures back to life. Is this a possibility? Can science really use DNA to resurrect extinct animals? Furthermore, can genetic biology improve our lives by eradicating disease? Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2018.

December 15
Canada: Surviving the North
Behold some of the world's most astonishing wildlife, and see how they live, from Canada's high arctic and tundra to the boreal forest. Each animal has innate abilities that allow it to hunt and survive in all seasons. These capabilities range from astounding hearing, to incredible speed and to patient silent stalking.
Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2022

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Join us every Friday afternoon in the auditorium from 2 pm to 4 pm for a documentary film followed by refreshments.

January 12
Engineering Our World
This inspiring film follows engineers who have devoted their lives to seemingly impossible challenges and against all odds have made them happen. It is a story about human ingenuity and innovation. Closed Captions.45 minutes..2017.

January 19
The Megafalls of Iguaca
Follow the lives of animals that live in the Iguacu National Park, near the largest waterfalls on earth. This Atlantic rainforest houses swifts, who fly through the massive quantities of falling water, as well as spotted jaguars and a family of coatis. The film also shows the park rangers who battle to keep the reserve from destruction. Closed Captions.60 minutes. 2016.

January 26
Age of Stars
The sun is the source of our light, heat and energy. This film explores the birth of stars like our sun as well as their exit as exploding supernova .Billions of years from now our sun will die and will usher in the age of darkness. Closed Captions.55 minutes.2021.

February 2
Wild Metropolis: Residents
As cities grow larger, many residents have been pushed out of their homes in the wild and are adapting to their new urban habitat.in the city. From pythons in Bangkok to otters in Singapore, many animals learn adjust to these unlikely conditions. Closed Captions. 55 minutes.2019


February 9
Destination Northern Australia: Queensland
Enjoy a trip to Queensland in Northern Australia with the magnificent sunny beaches that draw surfers from all over, the oldest tropical forest in the world and the Great Barrier Reef.
60 minutes. 2002


February 16
Dynasties: Chimpanzees
David, the alpha male chimpanzee in his troupe in Senegal, tries to overcome threats to his leadership by younger males and by doing so ensure an heir. His determination to hang on to his position in the light of drought conditions and other difficulties is moving. Closed Captions. 55 minutes. 2019


February 23
Secrets of Lost Empires 2: Roman Baths
Ancient Roman baths were used not only to stay clean but to socialize. However, the technology behind the baths was lost more than 2,000 years ago. What did the Romans do when there was no soap and how did they remain fashionable with hairless bodies? How did the Romans manage to pipe enough water for the community and control the temperature? Using ruins as a guide, scientists set out to recreate a Roman bath as the Romans did. 53 minutes.2008

March 1
Natures Great Race: Zebras
Follow Africas longest migration as scientists track thousands of zebras through the Botswana wilderness on their way to the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. It is a harrowing journey as the animals and their young face starvation, wild dogs , lions and drought. Closed Captions. 54 minutes.2017


March 8
Alien Solar Systems
Is our solar system unique? How was our solar system created? Since the first discovery of a planet orbiting another star, some 280 alien solar systems have been identified. It's only by looking at solar systems far beyond our own, that we can understand how remarkable our universe is.
Closed captions. 48 minutes. 2011


March 15
India: Natures Wonderland
Our guide starts in the Gir Forest, home to the worlds last Asiatic lions, tracks elephants as they travel an old path through a tea plantation, and observes gibbons that begin each morning by singing. This is an unusual view of Indias rarely seen natural world. Closed Captions. 60 minutes.2016


March 22
Royal Myths & Secrets 11: George IV and the Regency
Lucy Worsley reveals how mental health problems forced King George to relinquish power to his debauched and extravagant son. Was this really an era of extravagance and regal splendour or was it a darker time of concealed revolution? Closed captions. 53 minutes.2020

title: Trek to the Snows of Kilimanjaro & Beyond (Armchair Traveller)
description:
Pilot, adventurer and photographer Lola Reid Allin transports us to exotic destinations around the world from the comfort of our chairs.
Through personal narration and professional photography, Allin will take us from the heights of Kilimanjaro to the plains of Serengeti by Cessna 208 Caravan (which she actually flew). Our journey concludes on the exotic Spice Island of Zanzibar in the Indian Ocean.
Please register at the front desk or by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

description:

With your valid Toronto Public Library card, this class will explore eLearning resources such as Mango Languages, Road to IELTS, Learning Express Library, and Tense Buster.

November 10: Computers for Beginners 2 - Use the Keyboard
November 17: Computers for Beginners 3 - Use the Web
November 24: Computers for Beginners 4 - Use Google Search and Maps
December 1: Computers for Beginners 5 - Use Windows 10

Registration is required and begins on October 20th. Register at the information desk on the second floor or call 416-394-5240.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

title: Persian Paintings & the Art of Bookmaking *REGISTRATION FULL
description:
Inspired by the captivating world of Persian Miniatures and the art of bookmaking practiced in the royal library of Persian Safavid king Shah Tahmasp, artist Sarvenaz Rayati leads a series of hands-on workshops and invites participants to delve into the history, vibrant colours, and mesmerizing compositions of Persian Paintings. Through the use of traditional techniques, attendees will tap into their creativity and create a collection of artworks culminating in a handcrafted art book. The program includes engaging activities such as book binding, painting, paper marbling, lino cut, stamping, typography and character design across 9 sessions.

Please call the branch at 416-394-1000 to register. Registration is required and participants should plan to attend all nine workshops. Workshops take place at the branch on Saturdays from 11am - 2pm.

title: L'Europe Art Déco ; vers le « Style international » des années 30.
description:
Tandis qu'en France la tradition du « beau métier » domine, le « Style International », issu de l'alliance entre le design et l'industrie, s'impose progressivement en Europe dans les années 1930. En Hollande le groupe « De Stijl » refuse tout ornement superflu, tandis qu'en Allemagne, le « Bauhaus » de Walter Gropius, jette les bases d'un design renouvelé. Bientôt menacé par la montée du Nazisme, absent de l'exposition de Paris en 1925, le Bauhaus rayonne toutefois en 1929 à Barcelone avec le Pavillon construit par Mies van der Rohe. Ce design « Streamline » s'épanouira, avec des artistes tels que Raymond Loewy ou Norman Bel Geddes, aux USA dans la seconde moitié du XXème siècle.

La conférence est proposée par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art.

En collaboration avec Alliance Française de Toronto.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard.

****

Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. title: SkyTurtle, Star Lantern Making Workshop and Community Parade
description:
According to the Wyandot cosmogony or Creation Story, Spotted or Little Turtle was the maker of the stars in the night sky for Sky Woman.
Join, Catherine Tammaro, (People of the Little Turtle Clan; Keepers of the Heavens, Carriers of the Fire), Wyandot of Anderdon Nation, Wendat Confederacy - and multidisciplinary artist, to learn how these lands we call home, came to be.
Then we'll create simple turtle and star lanterns and journey outside just as the sun sets to light up the sky like Spotted Turtle did at the beginning of time!
Archer Pechawis, member of Mistawasis Nehiyawak, Saskatchewan will drum and sing while we walk and honour the night.

For more information about Catherine Tammaro, please visit: Catherine Tammaro
For more information about Archer Pechawis, please visit: Archer Pechawis

Photo credit: Catherine Tammaro

This Environmentalist in Residence program is part of Toronto Public Library's Our Fragile Planet program series, supported by TD Friends of the Environment Foundation (TD FEF).

To register please visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

title: Stephanie Land & Deborah Dundas: On Class
description:
New York Times bestselling author and inspiration for the hit Netflix series Maid, Stephanie Land joins Toronto Star Books editor Deborah Dundas to talk about their shared experience of growing up poor and struggling to overcome the barriers faced by the working class.

Stephanie Land's new gripping memoir Class, discusses life after Maid, and takes us with her as she finishes college and pursues her writing career. Facing barriers at every turn including a complex loan system, not having enough money for food, and navigating the judgements of professors and fellow students who didn't understand the demands of attending college while under the poverty line - Land finds a way to survive once again, finally graduating in her mid-thirties.

Deborah almost didn't make it to university, but even after graduating and overcoming many of the usual barriers faced by working class people, she still felt anxious about her place and reluctant to broach the subject of class. In On Class, she talks to writers, activists, those who work with the poor and those who are poor about what happens when we don't talk about poverty or class - and what will happen when we do.

In this timely conversation, Stephanie Land and Deborah Dundas consider the ways in which we talk about class: who tells the stories and who doesn't, which ones tend to be repeated most often, and why this has to change.

About this event's guests:
Stephanie Land
Deborah Dundas

Read more:
Class
On Class
Maid

***

This event is part of our signature On Civil Society series, where we host local and international authors, activists and academics in conversation about the most critical topics of our time. Generously supported in part by Chris M. Reid.

***

description:

Embark on an illuminating journey with the Toronto Public Library's Inclusive Futures series, as we venture beyond the boundaries of conventional narratives to delve into futures often overshadowed. Guided by a commitment to authenticity, our series goes beyond what's easy or comfortable, inviting you to envision bold, transformative paths. Join us in challenging norms, igniting conversations, and shaping a tapestry of inclusive, vibrant, and interconnected tomorrows.

title: Indigenous Film: The Lake Winnipeg Project
description:
The Lake Winnipeg Project calls attention to stories of ingenuity and resilience in four diverse communities surrounding Lake Winnipeg, at a time when many external forces are imposing change. Anishinaabe/Cree director Kevin Settee takes an own-voices approach to storytelling that gives Lake Winnipeg communities and peoples the opportunity to tell their own stories and speak to the challenges and successes they experience.

Four-part documentary series (10-15 min shorts).

Join us for this in-person program. Drop in, no registration.

title: 1-on-1 Career Consultations with ACCES Employment *PROGRAM FULL, JOIN WAITLIST*
description:
Are you feeling stuck in your job search? Look no further! Explore the incredible resources and expertise offered by ACCES Employment. Step into a world of endless possibilities as you connect with their dedicated team of Employment Consultants, ready to transform your career trajectory. Unleash your potential with tailored resume reviews, invaluable interview tips, and a wealth of additional support. Book a free 30-minute appointment with an Employment Consultant and embark on a remarkable journey toward your dream job.

Consultations are limited to 1 per person. Registrants will receive an email reminder a week before their appointment and are required to confirm their attendance. If attendance has not been confirmed by 5 PM two days before the appointment date, the spot will be released to the waitlist.

Consultations will take place in the Business, Science and Technology Department (4th Floor). Appointment slots are currently fully booked for the rest of 2023. To be added to the waitlist for one or more of the remaining consultation dates, please call the North York Central Library's Business, Science and Technology Department at 416-395-5613.

Discovery Club is a new ongoing program where kids can try new activities, flex their creativity, step outside their comfort zone and cultivate friendships. Each 4-week workshop is sure to spark a new hobby or interest for your child.

title: Death Cafe
description:
A Death Café is a gathering of people, often strangers, who will drink tea, have a snack and discuss death together. The aim is to increase the awareness of death with a view to helping people make the most of their lives. Join us for small group discussions with no agenda, no objectives, and no particular theme. Prepare to hear and tell stories. This is not a grief support or counselling session. The facilitator for this Death Café will be Laura Hartley.
Death Cafes are a global movement.


This is an in-person program. No registration required.

If you live with a disability, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services at accessibleservices@tpl.ca or phone 416-393-7099. Please contact us at east three weeks in advance.

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 5. Les méthodes : la note de réalisation
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions d'esthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Dans cet atelier nous explorons les questionnements auxquels doit faire face un cinéaste avant de se lancer dans la réalisation. Comment communiquer autour d'un film qui est dans son esprit ? Comment mettre en mots ce que le film doit mettre en image ?

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 14 novembre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

description:

- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets

description:

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

description:

Featuring Dr. Tor Oiamo (Toronto Metropolitan University), and Ingrid Buday (No More Noise Toronto).

To register, please call the branch at 416-395-5710.

***
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: I'll Burn That Bridge When I Get to It
description:
What's at stake for academic institutions when faculty are hemmed in or censored for unpopular or politically-challenging opinions or research? What do students lose when they're not exposed to ideas that challenge their worldviews or which question long-established ideas or perspectives? How can we encourage universities to push boundaries and challenge the dominant narratives while at the same ensuring that universities are safe spaces for everyone?

American political scientist Norman Finkelstein speaks with Christian Parenti, investigative journalist and Professor of Economics at John Jay College, about their shared experiences facing institutional repercussions for both their personal views and theoretically-based work, and what they consider to be the reasoning and implications of this backlash. Moderated by longtime activist and former broadcast journalist Jeanne McGuire.

Why is the fight for academic freedom relevant to those outside of academia? How do dominant narratives keep us divided and distracted? What does society lose when ideas aren't allowed free reign in debate, research or even exploration? 

Join the conversation.

Question and answer session and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on November 21 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Norman Finkelstein
Christian Parenti
Jeanne McGuire

Read more:
I'll Burn That Bridge When I Get to It
Radical Hamilton

***
This event is part of our new series exploring what's at stake when intellectual freedom is threatened.

***  
Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).  

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.  

***  
Accessibility at Toronto Public Library: 
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Protecting Your Family Treasures
description:
A lot of us have items like books, old photos, letters, and other documents that are connected to our families. Some of these items might be really old and delicate. Together these things are personal items, but also make up a big part of our shared cultural history. To make sure they last for the people who come after us, it is important to take special care of them. Conservator Andrew Huot will discuss ways to save , protect, and store these meaningful items.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. title: Futures Club: Scenarios - Futures of Work
description:
In this session, we will explore drivers alongside the trends developed in Futures Club to develop scenarios around our topic: The Future of Work. Learn how to create distinct possible future worlds that you can use in program, policy, and business development.

Note: While this session builds off previous Futures Club work, it is not necessary to have attended any previous sessions to participate in this one. All are welcome to join us in this final stage of our foresight project.

Futures Club Series:
Dive into the world of strategic foresight with Futures Club. Our meetings are a delightful blend of imagination, intuition, observation, and engaging research. This fall, we're delving deep into The Futures of Work, where we'll uncover signals of change, craft insightful trends, and lay the foundation for policy, programming, and business development. Explore the realms of risk and opportunity while contributing to the creation of a compelling future visions.

Futures Club is your opportunity to engage in a transformative Strategic Foresight project. Over the first 5 weeks, we'll learn the art of "Horizon Scanning"  a technique that uncovers early signs of change with profound implications for our communities, economies, health, environment, and daily lives. The final 4 weeks will be dedicated to synthesizing the gathered signals, forging insightful trends, and exploring the intricate tapestry of opportunities and risks across diverse possible futures.

Note: Please feel free to attend as many Futures Club sessions as you'd like. Those who attend regularily will benefit from practicing foresight methodologies and learning from a community of peers and subject matter experts. Those who only attend one or two will come away from the experience with a valuable introduction to strategic foresight.

title: Introduction to Deep Learning with Tensorflow for Beginners
description:
AI and Deep Learning are transforming the world around us by permeating daily life, industry, and public institutions. The advent of AI raises many concerns like algorithmic bias and privacy.

One core way to advance socially responsible AI is to promote AI literacy and explainable AI.

In 2015 Google released its in-house developed AI Python library called Tensorflow on an open-source license. Since then Tensorflow has emerged as a core industry standard and one of the most accessible AI libraries.

In this tutorial you will learn how to build a simple single-layer deep learning image classifier using Tensorflow. The workshop will introduce participants to the key ideas behind a deep learning model as well as the core Tensorflow functions needed to build a sequential model. We will be using Google Colaboratory environment to build and run our model.

Some knowledge of Python or coding is encouraged. For participants that have no prior Python knowledge, TPL offers on-going user education tutorials on Python you can enroll in here. While Python knowledge is encouraged, the core functions will be explained from the ground up in the class. Participants also need a valid google account.

Register Here

Accessibility

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus


Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: The Three-headed Hydra: A Comparison of Alcohol, Cannabis, and Nicotine
description:
​Retired Forensic Toxicologist and author, James Wigmore, compares the medicolegal aspects of three legal psychoactive drugs: alcohol, THC, and nicotine. He will lead the audience in a discussion to determine which of the drugs are most harmful to the public and what can be done to tame this "Three-headed hydra."

Registration is strongly encouraged. Tickets are available via Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Astrobiology with Professor John R Percy
description:
Is there life elsewhere in the universe? Intelligent life? Join us for this presentation on how astronomers are trying to answer these questions.

This is a non-technical, highly illustrated presentation - no math or science background needed.

About Professor John R. Percy
Prof. John Percy is an active Professor Emeritus in Astronomy & Astrophysics, and in Science Education at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education (OISE-UT). His research deals with the nature and evolution of stars, as deduced from variable stars which change in brightness.

Percy is deeply engaged in astronomy outreach: giving courses for later-life learners, and public lectures in libraries and other venues, exploring the interdisciplinary nature of astronomy, and promoting and supporting the teaching of astronomy in schools.

Registration
No registration required, but encouraged. You can register for the event on EventBrite

title: Dystopia Book Club & BYOBook
description:
Welcome to Dystopia Book Club, a place to discuss the revealing predictions and interpretations for our world in speculative fiction and science fiction.

We will be discussing Our Missing Hearts by Celeste Ng. Copies of the title are available as eAudiobook and eBook through Toronto Public Library's OverDrive eBooks & eAudiobooks.

After our discussion we will hold a short BYOB (bring your own book) and share book recommendations with the group. These titles do not have to be dystopian - just ones that you th8ink others would enjoy.

This is an in person event that will be held at the Lillian H. Smith branch.

Questions? Please email lsstaff@tpl.ca.

title: Episode 5: AI, so what!? : AI as a Hobbyist
description:
A 5-part virtual series will examine how AI development is moving toward the creation of a separate species beyond human comprehension. Whether you are one of the ambivalent or one of concerned, this series will make you ponder everything from how you live, work & play all while discovering how AI is literally changing everything.

At the start of each episode, we will travel 100 years into the future to observe what happens when full on AI consciousness exists. We will imagine how society has adapted to AI and how most surviving humans see AI as nothing special or new. Each topic will look at current AI developments including generative AI (e.g., ChatGPT) and general Artificial Intelligence. More importantly, episodes will address the importance of making necessary changes.

This is a 5-part virtual series hosted by Keith McDonald. Founder and Chief Curator of Toronto's the "literacy AI project". The series is intended for those who are curious about AI but have not had the time to investigate the nuances and developments that are taking place every day.

Please click on the link below to start the registration process.


Episode 5:
AIso what!? : AI as a hobbyist
(recreation, hobbies & downtime pursuits)
December 7th, 2023
7:00 PM - 8:00PM

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

description:

How to prepare a 3D design file for print

Will we play a song with Dash? Will we teach Sphero robots to complete a maze? Will we make a fan spin with Snap Circuits? Will we build a bridge?

description:
Join a brand-new book club hosted by The Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy! Each month we will read a book from a different sub-genre such as space opera, high fantasy, cyberpunk and more. Dates, genres and books are listed below.

Saturday September 9
The Left Hand of Darkness by Ursula K. Le Guin
Available in regular print, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday October 14
What Moves the Dead by T. Kingfisher
Available in regular print, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday November 18
The Deep by Rivers Solomon
Available in regular print, CD audiobook, ebook and eaudiobook.

Saturday December 9
An Ocean of Minutes by Thea Lim
Available in regular print, large print, CD audiobook, ebook and eaudiobook.

No registration is required and everyone is welcome. Want an email reminder? Sign up for a free ticket through our Eventbrite.

Book club meetings will take place in the Merril Collection Reading Room on the third floor of Lillian H. Smith Branch.

If you need help getting a copy of the book or have any questions, please contact us at lsmestaff@tpl.ca or 416-393-7748.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: Computers for Beginners 5: Use Windows
description:
A class on essential basic Windows skills for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fifth session you will:

- Become familiar with the Windows (10) operating system
- Practice using common Windows features: File Explorer, Desktop, Taskbar, Windows, Applications

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to create and organize files in the Windows environment.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 & 2 or basic mouse and keyboarding skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min] 

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

title: Computers for Beginners 5: Use Gmail
description:

In this Fifth session you will:

- Practice basic email functions: send, read, reply, forward, delete email, and attach files
- Review how spam and junk mail work

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to use email.

Instructions on how to set up and manage your own free Gmail account are included in the handout.

Pre-requisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Limited to 10 participants. Register in person at Northern District or by phone: (416) 393-7603.

title: Jhumpa Lahiri: Roman Stories
description:
Pulitzer Prize winning author Jhumpa Lahiri talks about her first short story collection since her number one New York Times bestseller Unaccustomed Earth, and a major literary event, Roman Stories - a splendid and searching collection that places the City of Rome as the protagonist.

In "The Boundary," one family vacations in the Roman countryside, though we see their lives through the eyes of the caretaker's daughter, who nurses a wound from her family's immigrant past. In "P's Parties," a Roman couple, now empty nesters, finds comfort and community with foreigners at their friend's yearly birthday gathering - until the husband crosses a line. And in "The Steps," a public staircase that connects two neighbourhoods and the residents who climb up and down it shows Italy's capital in all of its social and cultural variations, filled with the tensions of a changing city: visibility and invisibility, random acts of aggression, the challenge of straddling worlds and cultures, and the meaning of home.

Jhumpa Lahiri speaks with arts and life reporter Aparita Bhandari about Roman Stories, an ode to her adopted home and a collection steeped in the moods of Italian master Alberto Moravia and guided by the spirit of Dante Alighieri, whose words in the final story lead the protagonist toward a new way of life.

Question and answer session to follow. Signed books available for purchase. No unauthorized photography or recording of event permitted.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on November 27 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Jhumpa Lahiri
Aparita Bhandari

Read more:
Roman Stories
The Namesake
Unaccustomed Earth
Interpreter of Maladies

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7pm, but doors open at 6pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as sandwiches and snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.


***

title: Atelier cinéma documentaire 6. Les méthodes : la temporalité
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions desthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Chaque film a sa propre durée : de gestation, de création et de production. De l'idée à la sortie d'un film, en passant par le choix de durée du film lui-même, les temporalités des films en racontent parfois autant que le film lui-même. Qu'est-ce que le temps fait au film documentaire et à ceux qui y contribuent ? Quel temps peut-on accorder à la réalisation d'un film ?

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 21 novembre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Excel Basics 2: Do More with your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.


In this second session you will:

- Practice data entry and formatting

- Manipulate rows and columns

- Create and copy simple formulas

- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter

- Create your first chart


Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.


Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

title: City of the Dead:  The History of Toronto's Early Cemeteries
description:
Join Virginia Van Vliet for an evening of discovery. Delve into the history of Toronto's first cemeteries, their impact on our local communities and some of their famous - and infamous - residents.

Virginia Van Vliet has been involved in researching Toronto history for community heritage organizations for over 25 years, including writing and leading historic walking tours for the Cabbagetown Preservation Association and Royal Ontario Museum. She is also a member of the Association for Gravestone Studies and has been published in their journal.


This is an in-person program. No registration required.

description:
Have questions about your tablet, phone, laptop, email or an app? Need help with ebooks or other online library services?

We know keeping up with new technology can be difficult! Our staff are here to teach you technology tools and concepts in a friendly and casual setting. Please bring your personal device and any questions you may have.

No registration required. This is a drop-in event, come to the library to get one-on-one tech support! Space may be limited depending on attendance.

*Longer questions may be referred to a 1 hour Book a Librarian appointment at a later date.*

*No technology repairs at this event.*

title: Non-Fiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a staff moderated discussion of The Library Book by Susan Orlean. Click on the title link for other available formats.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book club/book discussion. For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

No registration is required. Join the discussion on Jitsi at the appointed date/time.

For questions, reminder calls or assistance in getting the title, please email aguay@tpl.ca.

For a full list of upcoming dates/titles, check out Non-Fiction Book Club Titles or visit our website.

  • 2024 January 9: 21 lessons for the 21st century by Yuval N. Harari
  • 2024 February 13: No time like the future : an optimist considers mortality by Michael J. Fox
  • 2024 March 12: Burnout:The Secret to unlocking the Stress Cycle by Emily Nagoski
  • 2024 April 9: Chatter : the voice in our head, why it matters, and how to harness it by Ethan Kross
  • 2024 May 14: Nomadland : surviving America in the twenty-first century by Jessica Bruder
  • 2024 June 11: Eats, shoots & leaves : the zero tolerance approach to punctuation by Lynne Truss

    If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: The Joy of Writing

title: Creating a Miniature Garden
description:
Create a miniature world or enchanted garden in a container! Get creative and learn how to choose your container and plants, and how to keep your garden lush and green. This is a great project to add some gorgeous greenery to your living space or as a project to introduce new gardeners to the joy of getting your hands in the dirt to create something magical. Participants will be provided with materials and be able to take their own garden home. Participants are welcome to bring in their own containers.

Part of the fall young adult series.

This is an in-person program. Spots are limited. Register in branch or call 416-393-7674.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Get F.R.E.S.H. at the Library: Community Drop-In
description:
Take a moment out of your hectic week and unwind at the library with the F.R.E.S.H. team. They offer Finding Recovery Through Exercise Skills and Hope (F.R.E.S.H.) through good conversations. Join us on Wednesday mornings to meet new folks, build connections, and tell us about programs and services you would like to see in the neighbourhood!
Light snacks and refreshments provided. Drop-ins are welcome.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's F.R.E.S.H. initiative.

title: Seniors Drop In

title: Wednesday afternoon @ the Movies: A Man Called Otto
description: Based on the comical and moving New York Times bestseller, it tells the story of Otto Anderson, a grumpy widower whose only joy comes from criticizing and judging his exasperated neighbors. When a lively young family moves in next door, he meets his match in quick-witted and very pregnant Marisol, leading to an unexpected friendship that will turn his world upside-down.

title: Club de lecture avec Le Théâtre français de Toronto
description:
La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto et le Théâtre français de Toronto s'associent pour créer un club de lecture « théâtre ». Ce rendez-vous mensuel est l'occasion de discuter et d'explorer des scènes mythiques ayant marqué le monde du théâtre. Avec Georges Som, médiateur culturel, nous essayerons de comprendre les enjeux de ces scènes, de découvrir leurs sens et de partager nos sentiments sur leurs auteurs et autrices. Chacun est le bienvenu au club, qu'il soit néophyte ou amateur de théâtre confirmé. Les seuls prérequis pour participer sont la curiosité et le plaisir d'échanger autour du théâtre !

Le 13 décembre nous aborderons la pièce « La vie utile » d'Evelyne de la Chenelière. Pour ceux qui s'inscrivent à la rencontre du 13 décembre, le texte d'une scène sera fourni par le Théâtre.

Pour vous inscrire, c'est gratuit ! Envoyez un courriel à gsom@theatrefrancais.com

On se réunit à la Bibliothèque de référence de Toronto au 4e étage du département des langues et des littératures. Pour les directions, demandez au bureau d'information.

title: Protecting Your Family Treasures
description:
A lot of us have items like books, old photos, letters, and other documents that are connected to our families. Some of these items might be really old and delicate. Together these things are personal items, but also make up a big part of our shared cultural history. To make sure they last for the people who come after us, it's important to take special care of them. Conservator Andrew Huot will discuss ways to save, protect, and store these meaningful items.

Register by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: Dive into Documentaries - Push
description:
Twice a month, we present an engaging and thought-provoking documentary. We will explore the social, political and historical aspects of issues important to the state of our world today. Engage with complex social conditions, complicated events, and their consequences, while watching revealing documentaries from around the world at the Toronto Reference Library (with closed captions.)

Push explains our current housing crises in terms of international real estate investment. The film follows United Nations special envoy Lelani Farha as she investigates the financialisation of housing in Europe and North America.
Drop-in, no registration.

title: Word Basics 3: Basic Resumes with Word
description:
Practice your Microsoft Word 2019 skills while creating a simple resume.

In this class you will:

- Format a simple resume
- Practice advanced formatting using Ruler Tools and Format Painter
- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Word's built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF

Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 & 2 or equivalent skills. Keyboarding and mouse skills are required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]


Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

title: Toronto in Literature Book Club
description:
Join us each month as we meet in person to discuss literature set in Toronto. See our city in a new light through stories about its past and present in works of fiction and history.

December's book is Much Ado About Nada by Uzma Jalaluddin, a sparkling second-chance romance inspired by Jane Austen's Persuasion.

"Contemporary Austen adaptations are exercises in seeing how far a tradition can be stretched without snapping. That's a natural fit for a Muslim romance author writing about characters of faith...Would-be tech engineer Nada encounters her ex, Baz, a musician and conference organizer; they are forced together despite their long-nursed resentments and ultimately come to a more complete understanding of their past and present selves...This book layers a steady strain of melancholy beneath messy and funny top notes - one of those romances where you feel the whole journey, all the little moments piling up into something roaringly powerful, like snowflakes forming an avalanche." [Source]

New members welcome. No registration required. This meeting will be held in the Founders' Room on the First Floor.

Program hosted by the Language and Literature Department. For more info, email trllanglit@tpl.ca.

title: 1-on-1 Career Consultations with ACCES Employment *PROGRAM FULL, JOIN WAITLIST*
description:
Are you feeling stuck in your job search? Look no further! Explore the incredible resources and expertise offered by ACCES Employment. Step into a world of endless possibilities as you connect with their dedicated team of Employment Consultants, ready to transform your career trajectory. Unleash your potential with tailored resume reviews, invaluable interview tips, and a wealth of additional support. Book a free 30-minute appointment with an Employment Consultant and embark on a remarkable journey toward your dream job.

Consultations are limited to 1 per person. Registrants will receive an email reminder a week before their appointment and are required to confirm their attendance. If attendance has not been confirmed by 5 PM two days before the appointment date, the spot will be released to the waitlist.

Consultations will take place in the Business, Science and Technology Department (4th Floor). Appointment slots are currently fully booked for the rest of 2023. To be added to the waitlist for one or more of the remaining consultation dates, please call the North York Central Library's Business, Science and Technology Department at 416-395-5613.

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 1

Book appointment with Employment Consultant 2

description:

Ms. Alatiit is a Canadian violinist with a diverse performing career in Europe and North America. When she isnt giving masterclasses, teaching, or performing solo, she plays with Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra of Toronto.

description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids and have fun! Ages 6-12.

After School Club will NOT take place on Oct 27 and Nov 17. Registration is required for the Snap Circuits and Sphero programs on the dates listed below. Registration begins two weeks before each date. LEGO programs are drop-in.

Oct 13: Snap Circuits
Oct 20: Sphero
Nov 3: LEGO
Nov 10: Snap Circuits
Nov 24: Sphero
Dec 1: LEGO
Dec 8: Snap Circuits
Dec 15: Sphero

Snacks are offered during the After School Club for participants. Food may contain or have come into contact with common allergens. Ingredient lists will be available. Snacks are generously supported, in part, by donors.

If your child lives with a disability or is Deaf, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099 to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:
Join us for a monthly Friday night screening of a series of fiction and non-fiction films about workers and workplaces in Canada and around the world.

August 25, 6pm:
Bombay Calling, 2006 (NFB, directed by Ben Addelman & Samir Mallal)

title: Knitting Circle
description:
Want to learn how to knit with a fun group of people? Looking for help with your knitting project? Join Port Union's Knitting Circle! You can also share your projects with others! This is a drop in program but limited to a room capacity of 20 participants. Arrive early to secure your spot!

No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099 or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. title: Excel Basics 3 - Pivot Tables
description:
In this third session you will use conditional formatting to visualize data, explore the power of PivotTables for data summary and analysis, and take-home practice data to improve your new skills. Prerequisites: Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.

To register call 416-393-7746

description:

title: Musical Story Studio
description:
This multigenerational artistic collaboration brings seniors and youth together by exploring personal stories through music.

Seniors will shape stories guided by storytellers Sarah Abusarar and Maria Del Carmon Ordonez, using a range of artistic modalities, games and personal
explorations. Each senior will then be paired with a youth participant who will create a song based on their story, guided by singer-songwriters Cassie Norton, and Chris Taeyoung-Kim, and bassist Chris Adriaanse.

The project will conclude with seniors and youth working together to combine their stories and songs into a performance for friends, family and community.

FOR CHILDREN 7-12 and SENIORS. CALL 416-394-5320 TO REGISTER!

**November 18th: Running Down a Dream

**December 16th: A Christmas Carol

title: Learn to Play Dungeons and Dragons for Adults
description:
Learn to play Dungeons and Dragons! Team up with a group of adventurers to explore unknown lands, meet allies, and battle foes. Maybe, you'll even be a hero.

Over the course of this three hour session, you will learn the game mechanics of Dungeons and Dragons and delve into a one-shot adventure. This is a free introductory session and no experience is required.

Registration is required for this free program. Please register online through our Eventbrite.

Another session of this program, exclusively for teens, will be held on Wednesday, October 18, 4-7pm.

Questions? Please contact Merril Collection staff at lsmestaff@tpl.ca or 416-393-7748.

This event will be held in the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy, on the 3rd floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: Saturday Knit & Crochet Circle
description:
Want to learn how to knit or crochet with a fun group of people? Looking for help with your knitting or crochet project? Join our Knitting & Crochet Circle! You can also share your projects with other knitters/crocheters, teach a technique, learn a technique, and enjoy great conversation. All level of knitters welcome. Bring your own yarn, needles, and crochet hooks.


For more information speak with branch staff or call 416-395-5940.

title: STEM Saturdays
description:
Each week, come in for a fun tech surprise as we explore Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math through coding, circuitry, robotics and more!

Will we play a song with Dash? Will we teach Sphero robots to complete a maze? Will we make a fan spin with Snap Circuits? Will we build a bridge?

Join us to find out!

For ages 4-12. Space is limited.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

Drop in; no registration required.

Accessibility: Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. description:
Come join us for our new adult and seniors crafting social. Socialize with one another in a safe environment. Every month we will have a new craft sure to entertain and delight.

If you have any questions please contact Woodview Park Library at 416-395-5960.

title: Exploring Watercolour: Art Workshop
description:
Explore watercolour artwork using a host of various media including pastels, transfer paper, candles, salt, watercolour crayons, and of course, watercolour paints. Be inspired by the water lilies of Monet and learn a little bit about impressionism while creating your own multimedia masterpiece! Professional artist and art educator Holly Wheatcroft will lead this program!
Ages 18-24.

Space is limited. Registration is required. To register, please visit the Amesbury Park Branch or call 416-395-5420. Registration begins November 1st.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request.
