description:

title: Securing Employment - Interviewing
description:
Are you looking to sharpen up your interview skills?

Join ACCES Employment's workshop on interviewing 101: learn the purpose of an interview, the structure of an interview, the types of interviews, the different interview questions, and what to do before, during and after an interview.

Registration is required. Spots are limited. Register online via the Eventbrite link below or by calling us at 416-395-5613.

title: Snap Circuits for Seniors
description:
Exercise your brain with Snap Circuits! Use simple wiring and electricity to make circuits that can turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker, and more! Hands-on program. We will start with beginner exercises and move on to more advanced.

Space is limited. Please register starting Tuesday, September 5 in-branch or by phoning 416-395-5460.

title: Together Time with MFRC
description: This program is for children from birth to 6 years old and their parents/caregivers. The program will provide the opportunity to socialize and learn in an early learning environment. Sand, water play, painting, cut and paste, markers, crayons, circle time, and free play are all part of this program. Children are free to rotate between activities throughout the room. Co-sponsored with Malvern Family Resource Centre (MFRC). DROP-IN PROGRAM.

title: Scrabble and Chess Club
description: Come and play a friendly game of Scrabble or Chess at the library! Drop-in, no registration required. For more information, please call 416-394-5270.

title: Word Basics 3: Basic Resumes with Word
description:
Pre-requisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills required.

In this class you will:
-Learn about basic resume styles and content
-Format a chronological resume from a basic text document
-Use Ruler tools such as Indent
-Use the Format Painter
-Use Spelling and Grammar check
-Learn how to save your resume as a PDF
-Use templates to start building your own resume

Registration: visit or call Riverdale Library at 416-393-7720. Drop-ins welcome.

title: Dystopia Nonfiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a lively discussion. We read and talk about topical nonfiction books on how our world is being shaped negatively by forces beyond our control, and dystopian imaginings are becoming present-day realities. It takes place in the third-floor discussion room.

Sep 18 - The Ghost: The Secret Life of CIA Spymaster James Jesus Angleton by Jefferson Morley
Oct 16 - American Kleptocracy by Casey Michel
Nov 20 - The Wolfpack: the millennial mobsters who brought chaos and the cartels to the Canadian underworld by Peter Edwards
Dec 18 - The Decadent Society: how we became the victims of our own success by Ross Douthat

For more info, please call the Humanities and Social Sciences Department at 416-393-7175.

Register on Eventbrite or just drop in.

title: Computers for Beginners 6: Use Gmail
description:
Learn to use Gmail, Googles free web-based email service.

In this sixth session you will:

- Practice basic email functions: send, read, reply, forward, delete email, and attach files
- Review how spam and junk mail work

Upon completion of this class students will have a basic understanding of how to use email.
Instructions on how to set up and manage your own free Gmail account are included in the handout.

Pre-requisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min] 

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Place au cinéma avec Cinéfranco : Welcome.
description:
Pour impressionner et reconquérir sa femme, Simon, maître nageur à la piscine de Calais, prend le risque d'aider en secret un jeune réfugié kurde qui veut traverser la Manche à la nage.

Réalisateur : Philippe Lioret.
Avec Vincent Lindon, Firat Ayverdi, Audrey Dana.

Durée : 1h 50 min.
Avec sous-titres en anglais. Entrée libre.

Présenté par Marcelle Lean, fondatrice et directrice de Cinéfranco.


****

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines à l'avance.

****

Pour toutes questions concernant ce programme, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

title: Jane Austen Book Club
description:
Your esteemed company is requested monthly, to discuss the works of Jane Austen. The Jane Austen Book Club will meet in person on the third Monday of the month (December excepted) to discuss the works of the author. Tea is not required, but encouraged!

Next meeting: October 16th - Emma - chapters 29-55

Questions? Email lsstaff@tpl.ca

October 16th - Emma - chapters 29-55
November 20th - Northanger Abbey
January 15th - Persuasion
February 19th - Lady Susan
March 18th - The Watsons

title: Concert: Music for the Heart
description:

Enjoy an interactive, beautiful performance designed to uplift and refresh you with a tasteful selection of arias, classical songs and other genres.

Registration starts on Monday, November 20, 2023 in person at the 3rd floor desk or by calling 416-395-5639. Registered spots are not guaranteed after the start of the concert.

Space limited. All ages are welcome.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred.

They also afford the children an opportunity to play and learn in a safe and nurturing environment. Geared towards parents and caregivers with children between the ages of 0  5
This kindergarten readiness program has proven to be successful in providing a much smoother integration process into school.

description:
Join us for a free tour of our current TD Gallery exhibition, Osborne 75, celebrating 75 years of the Osborne Collection of Early Childrens Books! A limited number of print copies will be available in the Malvern Youth Hub, otherwise place your holds through tpl.ca (print & e-copies are available). This is an in-person program for 13 to 17 year olds. No registration is required. 3:30 - 4:30 p.m..

Malvern Youth Hub
30 Sewells Road
416-396-8969

Tues Oct 24th: Toilet-Bound Hanako-Kun, Volume 1 by Aidalro
Tues Nov 28th: Komi Cant Communicate, Volume 1 by Tomohito Oda
Tues Dec 19th: Demon Slayer = Kimestsu no yaiba, Volume 1 by Koyoharu Gotoge

Have you ever wanted to express yourself with creative writing? Want to know the difference between a metaphor and a Haiku? By the end of the program, poets will take home a small collection of writing, and the confidence to continue their own creative writing journey!

For children ages 9 to 12.

Discovery Club is a new ongoing program where kids can try new activities, flex their creativity, step outside their comfort zone and cultivate friendships. Each 4-week workshop is sure to spark a new hobby or interest for your child.

This is an in-person 4-week program. We strongly encourage participants to attend all 4 sessions. Space is limited to 12 children. Please register in-person or by calling the branch at 416 395-5710.

title: Excel Basics 3: Tables, Pivots and Formula
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Excel 2019 skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this third session you will:

- Sort and filter the data in tables
- Learn the basics of Pivot Tables
- Create and format charts
- Practice IF, VLOOKUP and IFERROR functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using Pivot tables and formulas.

Pre-requisites: Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Space is limited.

To register please phone 416-396-3975.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Atelier cinéma documentaire  7. Transgressions du genre
description:
Réaliser un documentaire est un exercice personnel qui repose sur quelques éléments clefs. Cet atelier est ouvert à celles et ceux qui s'intéressent au cinéma et à ses processus de création ; il permet d'explorer ensemble les questions d'esthétiques et de narration, avec des exemples de films ou de dossiers écrits.

L'objectif est de déconstruire le processus de création et d'expérience du spectateur. Les frontières du genre documentaire sont poreuses. Beaucoup de cinéastes font abstraction des définitions et des genres pour produire des films qui ignorent ces frontières. Jacques Prévert disait, à propos d'Arletty dans « Les Enfants du paradis » : « Tout film est un documentaire. Des fois c'est la mer, des fois c'est n'importe quoi d'autre, des fois c'est les êtres humains, comme on les appelle ».

À travers son expérience de réalisation et d'accompagnement de films, Marine Ottogalli propose aux participant·e·s de questionner leurs propres envies de films et de les confronter aux étapes principales de la réalisation documentaire. Réalisatrice de documentaires (Ayi, 2019, Sveinn-à-Mulà, l'islandais qui n'avait plus d'essence), et directrice de la photo (Human, Yann-Arthus Bertrand, Les Reines du palace, Karine Morales, L'École est Finie, Julie Chauvin) Marine Ottogalli travaille depuis plus de dix ans dans l'industrie cinématographique.

Cet atelier se déroulera dans Founders' Room de la Bibliothèque de référence.

L'inscription à cet atelier commence le 28 novembre.

Si vous avez des questions, contactez-nous à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

****

La Bibliothèque publique de Toronto s'est engagée à assurer l'accessibilité. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous êtes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour répondre à votre demande. Un préavis d'au moins trois semaines est préférable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: Cercle de conversation bilingue / Bilingual Conversation Circle
description:
Le Programme Connexions Communautaires du Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto ainsi que la Bibliothèque publique de Toronto vous invitent au prochain cercle de conversation bilingue qui aura lieu le 8 septembre 2023 de 18h à 19h30.

Les cercles de conversation bilingues constituent une bonne opportunité pour pratiquer votre anglais et/ou français. C'est aussi un moment d'échange et de réseautage entre participants.
Veuillez noter que le nombre de places est limité, prière de vous inscrire afin de confirmer votre participation :
jnoufissa@centrefranco.org ou tbamanthia@centrefranco.org

***

Come join us for the bilingual conversation circle! The bilingual conversation circle is a good opportunity for French-speakers to practice English and for English-speakers to improve their French. It is a great chance to meet new people and to explore networking opportunities.

The number of places is limited.

For further information, contact jnoufissa@centrefranco.org ou tbamanthia@centrefranco.org

title: Knitting Circle
description: Come out and join other knitters and crafters. Learn and share new tips and skills weekly. A limited supply of materials will be available, so please bring your own, if you have them.

title: English Conversation Circle
description:

* Please note that this is not a formal English class *

title: Barbara Frum Book Club
description:
Join us the last Tuesday of every month to discuss great books written by BIPOC (Black, Indigenous and/or Person of Colour) authors! New members are always welcome. Pick-up your copy at Barbara Frum Library or get your eBook or eAudiobook copy on Libby app by OverDrive.

Please register in branch or call Barbara Frum branch at 416-395-5440.

Tues. Sept 26 - Crying in H Mart: A Memoir by Michelle Zauner
Tues. Oct 24 - Five Little Indians by Michelle Good
Tues. Nov 28 - We Have Always Been Here: A Queer Muslim Memoir by Samra Habib
Tues. Dec 19 - The Water Dancer by Ta-Nehisi Coates


Accessibility
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Reading Challenge Online Book Discussion
description:
Join us for another Reading Challenge-themed discussion all about books! Our hosts Silvia and Rathees will be talking about reading challenge category: a book published this year/favourite reads of the year. They'll be sharing their recommended books and asking for yours. Follow along and share your input.

This event is live on Crowdcast. You can register at the link below to get a reminder, or just tune in on the day of!

Please review Crowdcast's Privacy Policy.

This event will have live captions.

title: Flemingdon Park's Afternoon Book Club
description:
Attention all avid readers!! Join us in-person to discuss a new book every third Thursday of each month from 1:30-3:00 pm in a fun and friendly environment! Copies can be borrowed in advance at Flemingdon Park Library or you can use your own copy. On October 19, we will be discussing The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Society by Mary Ann Shaffer.

December 21 - Carol by Patricia Highsmith

title: Dive into Documentaries - My Winnipeg
description:
Twice a month, we present an engaging and thought-provoking documentary. We will explore the social, political and historical aspects of issues important to the state of our world today. Engage with complex social conditions, complicated events, and their consequences, while watching revealing documentaries from around the world at the Toronto Reference Library (with closed captions.)
There's more to Winnipeg than is generally known. Winnipeg-born Guy Maddin puts a creative spin on the history of this colourful city.
Drop-in, no registration.

title: Toronto in Literature Book Club (Online)
description:
Join us each month to discuss literature set in Toronto. See our city in a new light through stories about its past and present.

This December, join us for an online discussion on On the shores of darkness, there is light by Cordelia Strube.

Harriet is 11 going on 30. Her mixed-media art is a source of wonder to her younger brother, Irwin, but an unmitigated horror to the panoply of insufficiently grown-up grown-ups who surround her. She plans to run away to Algonquin Park, hole up in a cabin like Tom Thomson and paint trees; and so, to fund her escape, she runs errands for the seniors who inhabit the Shangrila, the decrepit apartment building that houses her fractured family.

Masterful and piercingly funny, Strube is at the top of her considerable form in this deliciously subversive story of love and revelation. [Source]

Copies of the title are available to borrow in Print, Large Print, eBook, DAISY talking book and eAudiobook format from the Toronto Public Library collection.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book discussion. Registration is limited and specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to the registrants one day before the book club meeting.

For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out our Getting Started with Jitsi guide. Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

Program hosted by the Language and Literature Department. For more info, email trllanglit@tpl.ca.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's F.R.E.S.H. initiative.

title: The Mystery of the Christmas Bell Story and Holiday Sing-Along with Pixie Irving
description:
Performance storyteller, Pixie Irving presents a colourful Christmas story featuring Santa Claus. In order to complete his deliveries around the world in one night, Santa creates a magical Christmas Bell, which tolls at the stroke of midnight on Christmas Eve. But when the evil Ice Queen of the North who hates Christmas steals the bell, its up to Santa to find allies to help him defeat the Queen and save Christmas. This fun-filled story is supported by a colorful picture book mounted on a projector screen. After the story, Pixie will lead participants in a classic holiday carol sing-along with lyrics and musical accompaniment featuring favourites like Jingle Bells, Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer, and more.

All ages are welcome.

Drop-in. No registration required.

Will we play a song with Dash? Will we teach Sphero robots to complete a maze? Will we make a fan spin with Snap Circuits? Will we build a bridge?

Join us to find out!

For ages 4-12. Space is limited.

title: Mimico Teen Club
description: Calling all teen artists. Join our teen club, where you can share, critique and discuss your paintings, drawings, spoken word, music, dance, and plays with each other and the community.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: Leaside's Non-Fiction, Biographies and Memoirs Book Club
description:
**PROGRAM IS NOW FULL. PLEASE CONTACT LEASIDE BRANCH TO BE ADDED TO THE WAITLIST**

Expand your mind and take part in Leaside's monthly book club! Pick up the upcoming month's book at each book club session or at the Leaside branch circulation desk. Come together to share your thoughts and opinions about the book in a friendly and cozy environment!

The September book will be available as of August 31, 2023.

Dates and Titles (September to December)
September 27 - Field Notes from an Unintentional Birder, Julia Zarankin
October 25 - Unspeakable Acts: True Tales of Crime, Murder, Deceit, and Obsession, Sarah Weinman
November 29 - Starry Messenger: Cosmic Perspectives on Civilization, Neil deGrasse Tyson
December 27 - House in the Sky, Amanda Lindhout & Sara Corbett

Please register for email reminders at the Leaside information desk or by calling 416-396-3835.

title: Short Book Club
description:
Are you interested in joining a book club but are short on time? Join the Short Book Club, focusing on books that are 250 pages or less. We meet the last Wednesday of each month.

In November we will be discussing The Relatives by Camilla Gibb. Copies of the book are available for pickup in the branch or as an eBook or eAudiobook through Libby. There is also a DAISY Talking Book available.

Summary: "Lila is on a long, painful journey toward motherhood. Tess and Emily are reeling after their ugly separation and fighting over ownership of the embryos that were supposed to grow their family together. And thousands of miles away, the unknown man who served as anonymous donor to them all is being held in captivity in Somalia. While his life remains in precarious balance, his genetic material is a source of both creation and conflict. What does it mean to be a family in our rapidly shifting world? What are our responsibilities to each other with increasing options for how to create a family? As these characters grapple with life-altering changes, they will find themselves interconnected in ways they cannot have imagined, and forced to redefine what family means to them."


Future selections:
November 29: The Relatives by Camilla Gibb
December 27: The Refugees by Viet Thanh Nguyen

This is a drop-in program.
For more information, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

Accessibility

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

description:

PG-13

107 minutes

description:

No registration required. Please meet at 3:00pm at the entrance of the TD Gallery, which is located to the right of the elevators on the first floor of the Toronto Reference Library.

title: Gustave Caillebotte, artiste, collectionneur et mécène des Impressionnistes
description:
L'histoire de Gustave Caillebotte (1848-1894) est paradoxale : peintre aujourd'hui célébré dans les grandes expositions internationales, il ne fut longtemps (re)connu que pour son rôle de mécène auprès de ses amis impressionnistes, de financier de leurs expositions, et par son activité de collectionneur. Il soutint régulièrement la présence des artistes femmes dans les expositions de groupe. Mais le don qu'il fit de sa collection en 1894, une des plus importantes de son temps (Manet, Monet, Renoir, Cézanne, etc.), fut refusée par l'État français,  puis acceptée  mais seulement, hélas, en partie. Son histoire est l'illustration d'un fabuleux destin personnel mais aussi des occasions manquées de l'Histoire.

La conférence est proposée par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art.

En collaboration avec Alliance Française de Toronto.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard.

****

Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines à l'avance.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: Tuesday Night Tech Support Drop-in
description:
Have questions about your tablet, phone, laptop, email or an app? Need help with ebooks or other online library services?

We know keeping up with new technology can be difficult! Our staff are here to teach you technology tools and concepts in a friendly and casual setting. Please bring your personal device and any questions you may have.

No registration required. This is a drop-in event, come to the library to get one-on-one tech support! Space may be limited depending on attendance.

*Longer questions may be referred to a 1 hour Book a Librarian appointment at a later date.*

*No technology repairs at this event.*

title: Non-Fiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a staff moderated discussion of 21 lessons for the 21st century by Yuval N. Harari. Click on the title link for other available formats.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book club/book discussion. For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

No registration is required. Join the discussion on Jitsi at the appointed date/time.

For questions, reminder calls or assistance in getting the title, please email aguay@tpl.ca.

For a full list of upcoming dates/titles, check out Non-Fiction Book Club Titles or visit our website.

  • 2024 February 13: No time like the future : an optimist considers mortality by Michael J. Fox
  • 2024 March 12: Burnout:The Secret to unlocking the Stress Cycle by Emily Nagoski
  • 2024 April 9: Chatter : the voice in our head, why it matters, and how to harness it by Ethan Kross
  • 2024 May 14: Nomadland : surviving America in the twenty-first century by Jessica Bruder
  • 2024 June 11: Eats, shoots & leaves : the zero tolerance approach to punctuation by Lynne Truss

    If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Dystopia Nonfiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a lively discussion. We read and talk about topical nonfiction books on how our world is being shaped negatively by forces beyond our control, and dystopian imaginings are becoming present-day realities. It takes place in the third-floor discussion room.

Sep 18 - The Ghost: The Secret Life of CIA Spymaster James Jesus Angleton by Jefferson Morley
Oct 16 - American Kleptocracy by Casey Michel
Nov 20 - The Wolfpack: the millennial mobsters who brought chaos and the cartels to the Canadian underworld by Peter Edwards
Dec 18 - The Decadent Society: how we became the victims of our own success by Ross Douthat

For more info, please call the Humanities and Social Sciences Department at 416-393-7175.

Register on Eventbrite or just drop in.

Your esteemed company is requested monthly, to discuss the works of Jane Austen. The Jane Austen Book Club will meet in person on the third Monday of the month (December excepted) to discuss the works of the author. Tea is not required, but encouraged!

title: Computers for Beginners 2: Use the Keyboard
description:
A class on basic keyboard functions for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience. This is class 2 of 5 in a series for computer novices interested in learning the basics.

In this second session you will:

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)
- Practice proper keyboarding posture

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and know how to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 or basic mouse skills

To register call 416-393-7746

title: PowerPoint 2
description:
Create a more sophisticated PowerPoint 2019 presentation with more advanced features.

In this session you will:

- Insert and format tables, simple charts, and SmartArt graphics
- Insert a screenshot or video
- Add Speaker notes and Print presentations

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 or equivalent experience

To register call 416-393-7746

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

description:

title: Un vrai goût ; les collectionneurs Montréalais (1880-1910)
description:
Le développement économique que connait le Canada au XIXe siècle, entraîne l'émergence de grandes fortunes ; les riches industriels montréalais acquièrent des oeuvres d'art, qui témoignent d'un véritable goût ; William Van Horne (1843-1915) achète directement aux meilleurs marchands français tels que Durand-Ruel ou Bernheim-Jeune. Charles Hosmer (1851-1927), s'intéresse quant à lui autant à la peinture ancienne que moderne ; sa collection, riche de quatre Canaletto, comprend également de magnifiques oeuvres romantiques (Constable, Turner, Delacroix) mais aussi impressionnistes telles que Monet, Sisley, Degas, Cézanne, Mary Cassatt. Ces collections témoignent aussi d'un vrai engagement sociétal ; George Drummond (1829-1910), dont la collection est de niveau international, préside l'« Art Association » de Montréal, ancêtre du Musée des Beaux-Arts qui lui doit tant.

La conférence est proposée par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art.

En collaboration avec Alliance Française de Toronto.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard.

****

Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel à programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

Si vous vous considérez comme une personne handicapée ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer à ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tôt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines à l'avance.

Crédit photo : Margot Richard

title: Mimico Teen Club
description: Calling all teen artists. Join our teen club, where you can share, critique and discuss your paintings, drawings, spoken word, music, dance, and plays with each other and the community.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person every Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Beginners are welcome to join. Some quilts are worked on together by the group and donated to a charity.

Please note: we do not work on sewing machines at the library. We do hand sewing, either piecing quilts by hand or adding the binding. People are encouraged to work on home machines if they have one. Currently we manage to make a good number of quilts, about 50 or so a year.

We meet for sharing ideas, donated fabric resources and for show-and-tell (encouragement).

Regarding dates: The quilters will not meet when school is out. E.g. March break and during the summer (July and August) and during December break.

title: Tuesday Night Tech Support Drop-in
description:
Have questions about your tablet, phone, laptop, email or an app? Need help with ebooks or other online library services?

We know keeping up with new technology can be difficult! Our staff are here to teach you technology tools and concepts in a friendly and casual setting. Please bring your personal device and any questions you may have.

No registration required. This is a drop-in event, come to the library to get one-on-one tech support! Space may be limited depending on attendance.

*Longer questions may be referred to a 1 hour Book a Librarian appointment at a later date.*

*No technology repairs at this event.*

title: Non-Fiction Book Club
description:
Join us for a staff moderated discussion of TNo time like the future : an optimist considers mortality by Michael J. Fox. Click on the title link for other available formats.

We will be using Jitsi Meet, an online meeting platform for our book club/book discussion. For more information about Jitsi Meet, check out the Getting Started with Jitsi Meet guide.

Please review Jitsi's Privacy Policy.

No registration is required. Join the discussion on Jitsi at the appointed date/time.

For questions, reminder calls or assistance in getting the title, please email aguay@tpl.ca.

For a full list of upcoming dates/titles, check out Non-Fiction Book Club Titles or visit our website.

  • 2024 March 12: Burnout:The Secret to unlocking the Stress Cycle by Emily Nagoski
  • 2024 April 9: Chatter : the voice in our head, why it matters, and how to harness it by Ethan Kross
  • 2024 May 14: Nomadland : surviving America in the twenty-first century by Jessica Bruder
  • 2024 June 11: Eats, shoots & leaves : the zero tolerance approach to punctuation by Lynne Truss

    If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.
